title: Cryptic Cryptids: A Merril Collection Exhibit
description:
Are there cryptids living among us? Are dinosaurs still walking the earth? Explore Bigfoot, Mothman, Nessie and more at this exhibit on cryptids and cryptozoology at the Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation and Fantasy.

Free. All are welcome.

Located in the Merril Collection of Science Fiction, Speculation & Fantasy, on the 3rd floor of the Lillian H. Smith Branch.

The exhibit can be viewed during the Merril Collection's open hours.

Are you an educator or group leader? We also offer group visits and exhibit talks! Contact the Merril Collection at 416-393-7748 or email lsmestaff@tpl.ca for more information.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to attend. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Maud's World: Celebrating 150 Years of Lucy Maud Montgomery
description:
Celebrate Lucy Maud Montgomery's 150th birthday with the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books. From first editions of her classic novels to original letters penned by Montgomery herself, this exhibition explores the author's fascinating life and timeless stories. Best known for Anne of Green Gables, Montgomery was a Canadian icon in her own right, publishing 20 novels and countless short stories during her long career.

Free. All are welcome.

Located in the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books, on the 4th floor of the Lillian H. Smith Branch.

The exhibit can be viewed during the Osborne Collection's open hours.

Contact the Osborne Collection at 416-393-7753 or email osstaff@tpl.ca for more information.

The exhibit can be viewed during the Osborne Collection's open hours.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to attend. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Learn about subsidized housing in Toronto
description:
Housing Help Centre staff will be hosting free in-person workshops at Maria A. Shchuka.

Join a session to learn:
- about subsidized housing options like Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI)
- how to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website
- how to manage your account

To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
- a valid email address;
- proof of Canadian status for all household members; and
- your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment.

To learn more and register for a session please visit the Access to Housing [http://Learn more and register for a session: https://tinyurl.com/3d46z64w]registration page. (https://tinyurl.com/3d46z64w)

Workshops will be held during the following dates and times:
- 22 June 2024, 10am to 12pm
- 25 June 2024, 10am to 12pm
- 02 August 2024, 1pm to 3pm
- 09 August 2024, 10am to 12pm
- 17 August 2024, 10am to 12pm

- 30 August 2024, 1pm to 3pm
- 06 September 2024, 1pm to 3pm
- 10 September 2024, 1pm to 3pm
- 19 September 2024, 10am to 12pm
- 30 September 2024, 10am to 12pm

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Works by Anne Erickson
description:
Throughout September, the works of artist Anne Erickson are on display at Agincourt branch. Anne began drawing in elementary school and briefly considered a career in commercial art, but did not begin painting until after her retirement. She is a member of the Scarborough Art Guild. Anne's spirituality is centred in nature and the natural world. She paints primarily to form a deeper connection with this world, one which can remind her of the source of our being.

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the Agincourt branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: Artist: Anne Erickson; Title of Piece: Georgian Bay Pine; Medium: Acrylic; Size/dimensions: 18 x 18'

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Merve Zeybekoglu - MZSON
description:
Throughout September, an exhibit by artist Merve Zeybekoglu titled MZSON is on display at Bloor/Gladstone branch.

"As a 7th generation tailor, working with the shapes of the body allowed me to develop as the artist I am today. A curious creative, I decided to pursue my love for math as an artistic medium at the University of Toronto. Today, I continue to develop my perspectives and my skills in expressing myself."

"Working with colours and shapes that form the back bone of everything that we see, feel, touch and even hear. The wavelengths of colour and the wavelengths of the world around us are what form our very realities. My artistic mission is to express such complicated concepts in their simplest, elementary forms."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the Bloor/Gladstone branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: Artist: Merve Zeybekoglu; Title of Piece: Snoopy; Medium: Oil; Size/dimensions: 20.32 x 25.4

title: Branch Art Exhibits: Works by Sari Richter
description:
Throughout September, the works of artist Sari Richter are on display at Deer Park Branch. Sari Richter (BFA, DTATI) is an artist, art therapist and illustrator living in Toronto. She works in a range of traditional drawing and painting media, with a focus on both nature and nurture. Peeling, pouring, clumping and smearing are integral actions in her work, which make her paintings eclectic and energetic. Sari is also a published children's book author, a children's book illustrator with over fifteen titles, storyboard artist and muralist.

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Artworks by Wendy Lu
description:
Throughout September, an exhibit called Artworks by Wendy Lu is on display at Don Mills branch.

Wendy Lu is a Hard of Hearing, Taiwan-born, Toronto-based multimedia artist, who graduated with Specialized Honours from York University with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Visual Arts. Wendy lost her hearing as an infant due to meningitis-related fever, and throughout her life, she has undergone left-brain surgery, as well as three cochlear implant surgeries. Her severe-to-profound bilateral hearing loss affects both ears, and her cochlear implant technology affects her hearing and speech.

"Art is powerful, experiential and experimental. I would like to make a positive difference in people's lives, advocate for social change and build better communities. My artworks show the transformation of portraits, landscapes and technologies. My hearing journey helps me to be strong, brave and courageous. I want to express myself in my artworks and promote public awareness of hearing disabilities. My art helps me to share my personal experience and my hearing journey in response to this fast-changing world. I want to overcome the stigma of hearing loss."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the Don Mills branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: Artist: Wendy Lu; Title of Piece: Group Portrait; Medium: Acrylic on Canvas; Size/dimensions: 36 x 46 inches

description:
Throughout September, the works of artist Mark Toffoli are on display at Leaside branch. Partly self-taught (books and online courses), Mark took many painting and sketching courses after school and on weekends when younger. While completing his nursing Honours degree he also took a 3rd year fine art course at York University after submitting a body of work (paintings) to be allowed to take the course. He has had work in juried shows and sold portraits via website and by commission.

"Mark Toffoli's work explores the beauty of nature and the spirituality that goes with it. Mark Toffoli's work supports the notion that paintings have the power to instruct, enhance life and influence the viewer."

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Stewart Stein - Canada's Secret Island
description:
Throughout September, the works of artist Stewart Stein are on display at North York Central Library in an exhibit titled Canada's Secret Island.

Stewart Stein is an award-winning photographer based in Toronto. Stewart's passion for photography began with the discovery of a Bakelite developing tank in the basement of his family home in Montreal. Used in pre-digital days to process 35mm film negatives, the tank belonged to Stewart's father who used the opportunity to teach Stewart the basics of film photography including darkroom techniques. Stewart's 'darkroom' is now his computer, and the magic of photography is still as thrilling as ever.

"I had never heard of Grand Manan Island until I visited there in 2013. Grand Manan is in the Bay of Fundy and is a jewel of an island, steeped in Maritime history and rich in natural beauty with abundant birds and sea life and varied geography. Grand Manan is the antithesis of touristy and its weathered heritage structures, active fishing community and interesting characters draw me back year after year."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the North York Central Library branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: Artist: Stewart Stein; Title of Piece: Dark Harbour; Medium: Photography; Size/dimensions: 61 x 40

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Julianne Gladstone - Spaces Between Thoughts
description:
Throughout September, an exhibit titled Julianne Gladstone: Spaces Between Thoughts is on display at Yorkville branch.

Julie Gladstone is a Toronto based painter, textile, multimedia artist, musician, writer and mother. She holds an MFA in Interdisciplinary Art, Media and Design from OCADU and a BFA in painting and drawing from Concordia. Her work is influenced by research into ancestral and generational inheritance, the Sephardic Diaspora, mindfulness meditation and trauma healing. Gladstone is a member of the Objective Collective. She has exhibited widely both nationally and internationally.

"The work submitted for this exhibition is part of a new series of abstract paintings that depicts the process of daily meditation; depicting an internal map of thought process, emotional states, and intuition. Each painting makes use of gesture, vibrant mark making and a layered process of removal, erasure, and embellishment of the original mark, so as to explore the passage of time on memory, and the fleetingness of thoughts and feelings. Using the language of abstraction, these works make use of the metaphor of weather and cloud forms. Much of my past work has explored weather patterns through a sublime aesthetic, blending Romantic landscape painting with Modernist abstraction. These influences can be felt, along with an intuition of mark making that is fresh and personal and conveys to the viewer, the richness of the inner world when we learn to drop the noise of our thoughtforms."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the Yorkville branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: Artist: Julianne Gladstone; Title of Piece: Thought Forms; Medium: Oil on Panel; Size/dimensions: 40' x 40'

description:
Throughout September, the works of May Cusask are on display at Woodside Square branch.

May Cusack has enjoyed paintings since the age of 7, and learned about Chinese paintings in Hong Kong. Upon arrival to Canada, May studied art part-time art at OCAD, Central Tech, and George Brown College. May's paintings were exhibited at the 260 Gallery (under the George Brown Students Section) and at Todmorden Mills Gallery.

"Nature is my greatest inspiration. I always admire the bright colours and contrasting textures found in landscapes in Canada. I hope my paintings will also inspire and bring happy thoughts to others."

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Works by Diana Abrera
description:
Throughout August, the works of Diana Abrera are on display at Agincourt branch. A Toronto-based Architect for 18 years, Diana enjoys capturing the seemingly mundane to celebrate them in unusual or new ways, altering the viewer's typical perspective. Diana's process involves a 'fly by the seat of your pants' approach in the hopes of embodying the unexpected in her works.

"These works aim to inspire viewers to get up close and personal with nature, and the environment they find themselves in. By actively engaging in different perspectives, especially those that may seem unfamiliar, or 'other', we gain new ways of seeing, understanding, and hopefully appreciating the world around us."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

title: Branch Art Exhibit: The Home I Never Knew by Sara Vargas
description:
Throughout August, the works of Sara Vargas are on display at Bloor/Gladstone branch in an exhibit titled "The Home I Never Knew". Sara is a Toronto-based visual artist with a background in theatre. She is originally from Caracas, Venezuela. In 2016, she graduated from Fine Arts Studio at Centennial College. She is currently pursuing an Honours Bachelor of Brand Design at George Brown. Sara's ongoing "Shadows" project has been adapted into several exhibitions and art installations around Ontario. Recently, she was chosen to participate in the 2023 RBC Emerging Artist Network program with the Power Plant.

"Inspired by the power of generational storytelling, I am exploring the landscapes my father visited during his travels to La Gran Sabana, Venezuela, in the 70s. I create my own painting interpretations of these places from his tales and reference images. The paintings appear blurred out to symbolize my unfamiliarity and a sense of discovery. Despite the unfamiliarity, this series of paintings reveals an incredible and perhaps unexpected connection to places in my home country I never knew."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the Bloor Gladstone branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: Artist: Sara Vargas; Title of Piece: La Gran Sabana; Medium: Mixed media on canvas; Size/dimensions: 24in x 32in

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Leafscapes/ Bouquets de Feuilles by Renee Sugar
description:
Throughout August, the works of Renee Sugar are on display at Yorkville branch in an exhibit titled "Leafscapes/ Bouquets de Feuilles". As a former watercolourist, Renee painted in exacting detail for over 35 years. During the pandemic, Renee was inspired during nature walks outdoors to explore a printmaking process which showcased the detailed structures, shapes and textures of leaves she collected, and called them 'Leafscapes' or 'Bouquets de Feuilles'.

"I am attracted to exploring and experimenting with a variety of media. This builds new skills, and is a replenishingway to keep my work fresh."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Fan Fine Art Exhibition by Fan Zhang
description:
Throughout August, the works of Fan Zhang and his students are on display at Woodside Square branch in an exhibit titled "Fan Fine Art Exhibition". Fan is a visual art artist and award winner of multiple international and domestic art shows.

Fan Fine Art Studio, a leading art studio in the Greater Toronto Area, is committed to nurturing students' artistic potential and guiding them on a journey of creativity and self-expression. Their comprehensive courses and innovative teaching methods enable students to develop unique drawing techniques and flourish alongside like-minded art enthusiasts.

Led by Fan Zhang, a celebrated artist and multiple award winner in both international and domestic art shows, Fan Fine Art Studio is renowned for its personalized guidance and support. Fan Zhang's dedication ensures that each student can cultivate their own artistic style.

At Fan Fine Art Studio, students of all ages, from pre-school children to adults, embark on a creative journey to master various drawing skills, including watercolor and acrylic painting.

Fan Fine Art Studio is excited to showcase the artwork of their talented teacher and students at the Woodside Square Library.

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the Woodside Square branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

title: Sunday Story time, Crafts and Games
description:
Enjoy fun activities, stories, songs, rhymes, crafts, games and a story time for the entire family.
Every Sunday in July and August at 3:30-4:30 pm

title: Tea & Entertainment
description:
Enjoy watching DVDs in the Library Auditorium from 2-4 p.m.
Tea & coffee and a small snack will be served after the presentation.
This is a free, drop-in program

July 5
Outback: The Dry Season (part 2)
It might be the dry season, but there's no rest in the Australian outback: There are turtle eggs to be laid, saltwater crocodiles to dodge and young birds on maiden flights. 60 minutes. Closed Captions.2017

July 12
Malaysias Last Tigers
The Malayan tiger is one of the most elusive animals in the Malaysian rainforest. Follow the researchers into the pristine rainforest of Taman Negara, Malaysia's oldest protected area as they attempt to find out how many tigers remain and to maintain and grow these numbers before they become extinct. 50 minutes. 2021


July 19
Planet California: Close Encounters (part 2)
From blue whales to kit foxes, spectacular images bring Californias wildlife into sharp focus. Natural forces reshape the land, yet some species persist, constantly adapting to a changing world. Still, in a space shared with 40 million people, is there room for all? Move over Hollywood. Our wildlife stars are ready for their close-up.2021. Closed Captions.53 minutes

July 26
Universe Revealed: The Milky Way
The Milky Way reminds us of our place in our own galaxy. But what shaped this giant spiral of stars and what will be its future? Travel back in time to unlock the turbulent story of our cosmic past and learn what forces continue to alter it. 2021. Closed Captions. 55 minutes

August 2
Frozen Planet 2: Frozen Worlds
Travel from the South Pole to the North Pole with David Attenborough to celebrate the precious wildlife in this frozen world and enjoy its wonders while there is still time, before the glaciers disappear.2022. Closed captions. 59 minutes

August 9
Frontier Sumatra
Frontier Sumatra tells the incredible story of the people, the animals and the land of Kampar Peninsula in Riau Province, a remote peatland rainforest the size of London. The film takes us into an impenetrable forest where scientists and rangers try to save this land and its wildlife from being decimated. 55 minutes. Closed captions

August 16
Royal Myths and Secrets: The Russian Revolution
The October Revolution of 1917 has gone down in history as the only Russian Revolution that really mattered. But Lucy Worsley reveals that the earlier revolution in February that year was downplayed in Bolshevik history books and films despite the fact that it was the truly spontaneous popular uprising that swept the Czar from power. She examines the frequent rewriting of Russian history through the decades. Closed Captions. 53 min. 2020

August 23
Pandas: Born to Be Wild
Unlock the mysteries of wild pandas whose counterparts in captivity are known for their gentle image. Journey through the steep Qinling Mountains to witness pandas startling courtship and aggressive behaviors.
Closed Captions. 53 minutes. 2020

August 30
World Greatest Engineering Icons: Palaces
From Buckingham Palace in the heart of London to the Hawa Mahal in India, discover how the rich and infamous have spent their time and money -- each attempting to bring luxury to the next level with magnificent chandeliers, great paintings, gilded walls , ornate furniture and massive gardens. 55 minutes. Closed Captions 2021

September 6
Secrets of the Royal Train
Climb aboard one of the most exclusive locomotive in the world for an inside look at its history that stretches from its lavish origin to modern times. Hear from those who look after the royal family keeping the schedules and looking after their every need. Closed captions. 46 minutes. 2019

September 14
Natures Great Race: Elephants
A thousand elephants, from magnificent bulls to vulnerable orphans, come together in a crucial annual gathering in northern Kenya, whilst facing deadly threats from both predators and poachers .Closed Captions.
54 minutes. 2017

September 20
Supernovas
Stars are not eternal; they are dying in unimaginably large explosions called supernovas. Second only to the Big Bang, these gigantic explosions scatter the elements from deep inside the stars. What can scientists learn about mans origins from these blasts? Closed Captions. 45 minutes. 2011

September27
Dynasties: Emperor Penguins
In Atka Bay, Antarctica, thousands of endangered Emperor penguins arrive to mate and give birth to their chicks in the coldest place on earth. Finding a partner and taking care of their eggs and chicks requires great cooperation until the babies reach adulthood. Closed captions. 52 minutes. 2019

title: Branch Art Exhibit: Catch and Release by Yannis Lobaina
description:
Throughout August, the works of Yannis Lobaina are on display at North York Central Library in an exhibit titled "Catch and Release by Yannis Lobaina". Yannis Lobaina is a Cuban artist, author, filmmaker, photographer and community arts facilitator based in Toronto. Yannis explores themes of immigration, diaspora, and motherhood through various narrative tools, and as a photographer, focuses on minimalist storytelling photography, landscapes, patterns, sacred geometry, and pareidolias in Mother Nature."

"I am an artist who creates minimalist photographic narratives called Catch and Release. Through my lens, I capture fleeting, frugal moments and the sacred geometry of Mother Nature, turning them into beautiful and timeless visual poetry. My photography explores patterns, pareidolia, spirals, textures, and the spiritual significance of these magical encounters with nature. Walking with my camera is a daily and conscious form of meditation for me. I have several photographic series around this theme, all focused on slowing down, observing, being patient, enjoying the present moment, and listening to Mother Nature. She is our home for healing and cure."

This exhibit is part of TPL's Art Exhibit Space program. Toronto Public Library provides space for local artists to exhibit their work at locations across the city. These exhibits aim to reflect the diverse cultural interests of the city and its neighbourhoods.

The exhibit can be viewed during Branch open hours. Please check the North York Central Library branch page before your visit.

Free. All are welcome.

Image credit: Artist: Yannis Lobaina; Title of Piece: Magical Portal (2023); Medium: Photography, Acrylic and Metal Print; Size/dimensions: 11" x 14" (27.5 x 35cm)

title: Abecedarium: The Art of the Alphabet
description:
Something wonderful happens when letters become art! From an early hornbook to creative interpretations of letters and language in modern times, the simple structure of the alphabet inspires works that are playful, engaging, and profound. This exhibit of abecedaria ("alphabet books") explores the intricacy of something "as easy as ABC" and shows the basis of our communication and learning are as meaningful as they are complex.


Free. All are welcome.

Located in the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books, on the 4th floor of the Lillian H. Smith Branch.

The exhibit can be viewed during the Osborne Collection's open hours.

Contact the Osborne Collection at 416-393-7753 or email osstaff@tpl.ca for more information.

description:

This workshop will introduce you to essential tech skills such as programming, data analysis, and digital marketing. You will discover the best resources for learning these skills, from online courses to coding boot camps, and see real-world applications in various industries. Whether you are looking to enhance your current skill set or pivot to a tech-focused career, this workshop will provide you with the knowledge and resources to succeed in the modern job market. Facilitated by Career Coach in Residence Kadine Cooper.

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener and Google Canada.

title: Computers for Beginners 1: Use the Mouse
description:
A class on how to use a mouse for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience.

In this first session you will:

- Observe and practice how to operate a mouse effectively
- Understand various mouse pointers and cursors
- Review basic keyboard functions
- Use the mouse for basic Windows functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a computer mouse at a basic level and will be able to go online for additional practice.

Pre-requisites: No computer experience required.

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Registration Required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at the library.

title: Wonder Workshop: Butterfly Challenge
description:
Have you ever wondered what a butterfly is, where they live and what impact butterflies have on an ecosystem? What about what would happen if these pollinators disappeared? Join us to learn all about butterflies and their habitats. Then use your imagination to design and build your own butterfly garden station for butterflies to live in your community. Plus, enter a prize draw for a chance to win an awesome book.

For kids ages 6 to 10 years.

Space is limited. Registration begins July 20, in branch or by calling 416-393-7703.

title: Fashioning the Beatles
description:
​Author Deirdre Kelly discusses her book "Fashioning the Beatles: The Looks that Shook The World" and examines the Beatles' enormous impact on fashion, then and now. Learn a new way of looking at the Beatles through a lens of fashion.

This program is part of our Beatlemania series:
Friday August 9, 3-5 PM How The Beatles Changed The World Film Screening- A fascinating story of the cultural, social, spiritual and musical revolution that was ignited by The Beatles, with revealing interviews and rarely-seen archival footage of the band.
Friday August 16, 3-4 PM Author Guest Lecture: John Robert Arnone's exhaustive research of 70 years of connections between Canada and The Beatles

Registration required. Please register in person at the Mount Pleasant Branch or by calling 416-393-7737.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Emancipation Month Film Screening: Joseph
description:
The International Day for the Remembrance of the Slave Trade and its Abolition is commemorated annually on August 23.

Join us on the International Day for the Remembrance of the Slave Trade and its Abolition | UNESCO for a free screening of Joseph, a film about a Jamaican doctor searching for an identity. Trained in Western medicine, the doctor must overcome family conflict and self-doubt to discover his African origins.

This event is in partnership with the Ghanaian Canadian Association of Ontario and the City of Toronto's Confronting Anti-Black Racism Unit. Please register through their Emancipation Month webpage.

Doors open at 5:30 pm

***

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:
  • Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
  • Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Toronto Reference Library WRAP Group will run every Saturday from July 13th to August 31st 2024 from 10 A.M. to 12 P.M. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library, by phone at (416) 393-7175, or visit gersteincentre.org. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Yours, Mine and Ours: Managing Copyright and Intellectual Property for Artists
description:

Artists will also learn the difference between copyright, trademarks and patents. Discover how to protect your creative work.

This program will be led by TPL's 2024 Arts Mentor in Residence, Kathryn Adams.

Drop in, no registration required.

Check out the Arts Mentor in Residence page for detailed program listings and how to sign up for free, one-on-one consultations.

description:
Drop-in for a friendly game of chess. Sets are provided. No registration is required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Japanese Fruit Sandwich Making with Chef Yumiko (**PROGRAM IS FULL**)
description:
Come join us for an interactive and delicious experience with Chef Yumiko Kobayashi. Chef Yumiko Kobayashi will provide a brief cultural history about "Furutsu Sandos", or Japanese fruit sandwiches, then lead a hands-on demonstration and workshop to make "Furutsu Sandos consisting of fresh fruit fillings, bread and whipping cream.

Registration is required. Please register at the front desk or by calling 416-394-5170.

This program is generously supported by a donation from Adrian and Ange Rocca.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email at accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail at 416-393-7099 to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Intermediate Arduino & Circuits: Transistors & Relays
description:
Did you try our beginner Arduino kits or class and enjoy the projects? Do you feel comfortable with the basics but want to do more with the Arduino? Come try your hand at a more advanced circuit, with a few different types of components and longer code.

This session will cover transistors and relays, and how to use them as switches to control other elements like household appliances.


** Please register only if you have already taken the beginner class, or if you are otherwise comfortable with a breadboard and basic computer programming. **


Ages 13+.

Registration is required. Registration begins August 10th at 12:30pm.

Note: Your spot will not be guaranteed after 5 minutes of the start of the program.


If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: **FULL** Excel Basics 3: Tables, Pivots and Formula
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Excel 2019 skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

In this third session you will:
- Sort and filter the data in tables
- Learn the basics of Pivot Tables
- Create and format charts
- Practice IF, VLOOKUP and IFERROR functions

Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using Pivot tables and formulas.

Pre-requisites: To attend this class you must have Excel Basics 1 and 2 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills are necessary.

Registration is now full. Please contact the Browsery Department at 416-395-5672, or visit the 1st floor reference desk, to be added to the waitlist.

title: Family Movie: Finding Dory
description:
A movie for the entire family! Join us to watch Finding Dory, and find out if Dory finds her long-lost family. Rated G.

Drop-in. No registration required.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Vector Design with Adobe Illustrator
description:
Learn some of the basics of Adobe Illustrator by creating graphics with some commonly used tools. The tutorial will cover many shape manipulation methods and colour selection.
This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of computer skills. Computers will be provided for this class.
Register in branch or through the link below.
For more information about this program please contact dihonline@tpl.ca
If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Photo Editing with Adobe Photoshop
description:
Learn how to alter and retouch images using Adobe Photoshop CC, an industry standard software for PC & Mac. In this hands-on class, you will learn to work with basic tools to resize, crop, modify colour, filter and add text to an image using our MacBook laptops.

This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of computer skills -- basically, if you can use a word processor or surf the web you can learn Photoshop.

** Registration will start 2 weeks before this class. Computers will be provided. **

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

Please register using the link below.
supportlinktext: Click here to register via Eventbrite

title: IPad For Beginners 3-part Series
description:
In this 3 part series on the IPad for absolute beginners, you will learn:
Session 1: IPad Basics - July 27th 2-3:30pm
- The physical features of the IPad
- Basic functions
Session 2: Using the Web - August 10th 2-3:30pm
- Connect to and use internet on device
- How to find and use websites
- About search engines and how to do a simple google search
- How to use google and google maps
Session 3: Using iOS 12 and IPad Apps - August 24th 2-3:30 pm
- Gain awareness about Apps and practice using them
- Use IPad Apps like the camera and photos

Prerequisite: Session 2 and 3 require a basic IPad understanding.
IPads provided. All sessions will occur in the Main Floor Program Room. To register call 416-393-7619 or visit us at the branch.

description:

Upon completion of this class students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 or equivalent experience. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

title: Digital Illustration for Beginners
description:
This week-long workshop series demonstrates the artistic process of creating a digital art piece, from rough sketches to a finished drawing. It aims to teach digital art in a way that is accessible and easy for those who are completely new to the medium by utilizing free and beginner-friendly drawing programs. The workshop is facilitated by Miranda, a Toronto-based illustrator and comic artist.

Registration begins July 29. Please call 416-395-5535 or visit the Browsery reference desk on the 1st floor to register.

title: Excel Basics 1: Create a Simple Spreadsheet
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for absolute beginners with no Excel experience.

In this first session you will:

- Learn the basic function and design of Excel files
- Practice basic data entry for text, numbers, and basic functions: Sum, AutoSum and Average
- Create and save your first workbook and worksheets

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Excel at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Basic mouse and keyboard skills are required.

This class will be conducted online using WebEx.
Details and practice files will be emailed to registered attendees.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Afternoon Movie
description:
2nd Floor - Program Room

Enjoy an afternoon movie at Albert Campbell Branch.


Mon. August 26, Film-Ghostbusters: "When three college professors lose their jobs, they decide to go into the freelance "paranormal investigation and elimination" business. When their first client discovers her refrigerator has become a portal into the spiritual dimension, our heroes come face to face with an ancient evil force with plans to raise hell in Manhattan. When ghosts go on a rampage, only these men can save the world. Soon every spook in the city is loose and our heroes face the supreme challenge. Who you gonna call? GHOSTBUSTERS!"

title: Creative Writing Workshop with Children's Author Sarabeth Holden
description:
Join children's author Sarabeth Holden for a reading of her books Benny the Bananasaurus Rex and Sea Snooze followed by an interactive creative writing workshop. This workshop is designed for children aged 3-8.

Sarabeth is a children's author based in Toronto, ON, and she's Anaana to two inspirational little boys. Sarabeth is Inuit from the community of Pangnirtung, Nunavut, she was born in Halifax and raised between New Brunswick and Nunavut.

REGISTRATION REQUIRED. Please call or visit the branch to register. For children ages 3-8 years.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Join us for a cool workshop where we will lean to make special paper that is good for the Earth! We will have lots of fun and get our hands busy making paper from old paper scraps. You will take how your very own unique paper and feel proud of helping our planet! We will also learn about how paper was made long ago and try out cool ways to make our paper extra special. Come join the fun!

This is a program for ages 6-12 years old.

Registration begins Friday, July 26. Register in person or by phone at 416-396-8979. Space is limited.

-Making and maintaining positive social connections and healthy relationships
-Stress management and the art of distressing
-Beliefs, values and attitudes, self-awareness and meditation
-Self-confidence and mindfulness

title: Festival Select: Man on Wire
description:
Join the Society and Recreation department of the North York Central Library in Rm. 101 for monthly screenings of fiction and non-fiction films that push the boundaries of the medium. This month's title is Man on Wire (2008) by James Marsh.

Summary: On August 7, 1974, a young Frenchman named Phillippe Petit stepped out on a wire illegally rigged between the World Trade Center's Twin Towers. After nearly an hour dancing on the wire, he was arrested, taken for psychological evaluation, and brought to jail before he was released. The documentary looks at the adventure through Petit's and his co-conspirators' testimony.

Optional registration here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/festival-select-man-on-wire-tickets-952880068937?aff=oddtdtcreator

title: **Word 3: Basic Resumes with Word--SESSION CANCELLED**
description:
Practice your Microsoft Word 2019 skills while creating a simple resume.
In this class you will:

- Format a simple resume
- Practice advanced formatting using Ruler Tools and Format Painter
- Use Grammar and Spell check tools
- Practice using Word's built-in resume templates
- Save documents in other formats such as PDF

Upon completion of this class students will be able to create an organized simple resume and access resume templates with additional style options.

**Please note, this session is not intended to review or critique the content of resumes.**

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 & 2 or equivalent skills. Keyboarding and mouse skills are required.

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations. Registration is required. Please register in-person or by calling the branch at (416) 394-5120. Program is limited to 10 participants.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request.

description:

It aims to teach digital art in a way that is accessible and easy for those who are completely new to the medium by utilizing free and beginner-friendly drawing programs. The workshop is facilitated by Miranda, a Toronto-based illustrator and comic artist.

Registration begins July 29. Please call 416-395-5535 or visit the Browsery reference desk on the 1st floor to register.

title: Google Docs Part 2
description:
Learn how Google Docs can be a useful free tool when you don't have access to Microsoft Word. In this follow-up class to Part 1 use more formatting tools such as bullets, numbered lists, text alignment, margins, page numbers, and Help. Use will also learn how to copy and paste text and images from the internet and explore templates for resumes.

Required: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills.

Register at Malvern Branch or call 416-396-8970. Space is limited.

***If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Malvern Library or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. description:
This four-part series will introduce participants to wellness practices that can be utilized in their everyday lives to enhance their state of well-being.

-Making and maintaining positive social connections and healthy relationships

-Beliefs, values and attitudes, self-awareness and meditation

Expect a healthy dose of participation and self-empowerment as she leads aspiring magicians of all ages on a journey to become "official magicians" during this fast-paced, comedy magic show for the entire family.

First 80 children and their caregivers, starting at 1:30 pm.

This is a ticketed event. Free tickets handed out at the Information Desk 30 minutes before the program. First come, first served. Space is limited."

description:

This course is mandatory in order to book the embroidery machine and will be held in the Fabrication Studio on the 2nd floor.

title: Computers for Beginners 4: Use the Internet
description:
An introductory class on the Internet for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this fourth session you will:

- Understand how to read a web site address
- Practice using web addresses
- Search for information using a search engine
- Explore a web site in detail to understand its key components

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use the internet at a beginner level and complete simple searches.

Registration is required. Please call York Woods at 416-395-5980 to register for this program.

Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 & 2 or basic mouse and keyboarding skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

description: Join us to create a stop motion project. Kids will get familiar with the process of creating a stop motion video, will get to know the basics of this technique and will challenge themselves to build up a video from scratch.

title: Choosing Hope: 1 Woman, 3 Cancers
description:
Munira Premji presents her first book, "Choosing Hope: One Woman. Three Cancers." as a focus for an inspirational talk about living through three advanced cancers within a 5-year period, and learning to thrive in the face of major challenges. The author will read passages from the book and provide insights on coping strategies when faced with adversity, followed by a Q&A.

DATE CHANGE FROM WED JULY 27 2-3PM TO TUES AUG 27 2-3PM
A captivating, true account of struggle and survivorship and an inspiring testimony to the human spirit. Dr. Norman Franke, Princess Margaret Cancer Centre

The story recounted here is an empowering tale of courage, optimism, survival and triumph. Dr. Rodger Tiedemann, Princess Margaret Cancer Centre

Registration required. Please register in person at the Mount Pleasant Branch or by calling 416-393-7737.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:

This program is suitable for children ages 7+.

description:
Exercise your brain this summer with Snap Circuits! Use simple wiring and electricity to make circuits that can turn on a light, spin a motor, activate a speaker, and more! Hands-on program. We will start with beginner exercises and move on to more advanced.

Space is limited. Please register starting Thursday, August 1 in-branch or by phoning 416-395-5460.

title: Wonder Workshop: Pollution Challenge
library: Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre
description:
Do you ever think about where your water bottles, plastic bags, and other plastic items go when you throw them out? Have you ever thought about what can be done to stop plastics from polluting our planet? In this workshop, you will explore the answers to these questions, and design and build your own creature or machine that will help keep our precious planet clean! Plus, enter a prize draw for a chance to win an awesome book.

For kids ages 8 to 12 years.

Space is limited. Registration begins Monday August 12, in branch or by calling 416-394-1040

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:

title: Wonder Workshop: Butterfly Challenge
description:
Have you ever wondered what a butterfly is, where they live and what impact butterflies have on an ecosystem? What about what would happen if these pollinators disappeared? Join us to learn all about butterflies and their habitats. Then use your imagination to design and build your own butterfly garden station for butterflies to live in your community. Plus, enter a prize draw for a chance to win an awesome book.

For kids ages 6 to 10 years.

Space is limited. Registration begins June 22, in branch or by calling 416-393-7657

title: Scientists in School: Science Snippet
description:
Enjoy a few snippets of science! Be a chemist and discover the difference between baking soda and powder. Create a fantastical creature while investigating dominant and recessive genes. Make a pompom launcher and explore physics. Discover aeronautics by building and testing a plane. A snippet is just the beginning!

For kids ages 4 to 12 years.

Space is limited. Registration begins Tuesday, August 13. Register in branch or by calling 416-396-8924.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessiblity Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Drop-in, all are welcome. Light refreshments will be provided. Call 416-393-7653 for more info.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's F.R.E.S.H initiative.

title: Adult Afternoon Movie: Petite Maman (2021)
description:
Join us every first and last Tuesday of each month for a free afternoon movie. Drop-in.

Following the death of her beloved grandmother, 8-year old Nelly (Josephine Sanz) accompanies her parents to her mother's childhood home to begin the difficult process of cleaning out its contents. As Nelly explores the house and nearby woods, she encounters a neighbor her own age (Gabrielle Sanz) building a treehouse. A tale of childhood grief, memory and connection.

14A

72 minutes

Subtitled in English

title: Dog Man Party - FULL
description:

title: Unexpected Treasures: Art, Archives and Artifacts Guided Exhibition Tour
description:
Take a trip through time in our eclectic new exhibition! Featuring items dating from the late 1500s to 2022. Explore original art, books, archival material, maps, artifacts and more! Dont miss your chance to see some remarkable items from Toronto Public Librarys Special Collections.

Join us for a free guided tour of the exhibition. Tours take place on Tuesdays at 3:00pm during the exhibition run. No registration required for the tour. Please meet at the entrance of the TD Gallery which is located on the first floor of the Toronto Reference Library. Learn more at tpl.ca/tdgallery.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:
  • Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
  • Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Lillian H. Smith WRAP Group will run every Tuesday from July 16, 2024 to September 3, 2024 from 3 PM. to 5 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Richview

Tues. April 30: Annual Migration of Clouds by Premee Mohamed
Tues. May 28: Kindred by Octavia Butler
Tues. June 25: Love Lives Here by Rowan Jette Knox

title: Community Writing Group
description:
Writers Collective of Canada is offering free community writing workshops!

Writers Collective of Canada (WCC) is a charitable organization that inspires exploratory writing in community to empower every voice, celebrate every story, and change the world. Our unique exploratory writing workshop method empowers the authentic voices of one and all, including traditionally underserved populations and underheard individuals nationwide.

No experience required. Beginners are welcome. Materials are provided.

This is a drop-in program. For more information please visit the branch or call 416-393-7663.

title: Board Games for Adults
description: Join us for the fun of playing classic & modern board games! Drop in with your friends or make some new ones while playing games like Chess, Rumikub, Cribbage, Scrabble, CodeNames, UpWords and more!

title: Vegetarian Sushi Making Workshop for young adults(18-24)
description: Toronto celebrity chef Sang Kim teaches the basics of sushi-making. Participants make sushi rolls using ingredients prepared by the Chef and eat their own creations. A brief history of sushi, its origins and eating etiquette will also be shared.​ Registration required. Please visit or call the branch at 416-393-7717. Please note this program is for young adults only 18-24 years old.

description:

Learn how to 3D print at the library using a Prusa MK3S+ printer. Discover the vast world of 3D design and see how designs come to life.

description: This Android device class is for absolute beginners who want to understand how their phones work. Learn how to connect to Wi-Fi, navigate your home screen, take a selfie, and more!

description:
Computers for Beginners is a series of 6 classes which have been designed to take a learner with no, or very few, skills from zero to a solid grounding in the absolute basics. Each class is set up to connect with the previous and next class in a series format. Registration is for all 6 classes, attendance to Part 1 and 2 is mandatory if you do not have mouse or keyboard knowledge.

Part 1: Use the Mouse, August 20
Part 2: Use the Keyboard, August 27
Part 3: Use the Internet, September 3
Part 4: Use Google Search and Maps, September 10
Part 5: Use Windows, September 17
Part 6: Gmail Basics, September 24

description:
In partnership with CultureLink, free weekly sessions to help you prepare for the Canadian Citizenship Test

* Learn about the test's contents and structure
* Get support and tips from CultureLink's Volunteer Mentors
* Practice with sample quizzes

These summer sessions run EVERY TUESDAY from July 16th to September 17th (6pm-8:30pm).

Please consider attending all the sessions because the instructor will cover different aspects of the book, Discover Canada: The Rights and Responsibilities of Citizenship, which will be provided for by the instructor.

NOTE: Tuesdays classes for Tuesdays August 6th and September 3rd are located in Room B1 on the lower level (instead of the Discussion Room).

For more information, call (416) 393-7085 OR contact Victor Gomes by email at vgomes@culturelink.ca or call Victor at (437) 288-3027.

CultureLink Settlement and Community Services is solely responsible for the protection of personal information collected through the program registration process.

description:

Copies of the book are available for pick-up at the Annette Street Branch. It is also available as en eBook or eAudiobook through Libby/Overdrive. New members are always welcome!

title: Tuesday Night Book Club
description:
If you love reading, please join us on Tuesday, August 27 at 6:30 p.m. to enjoy a snack and talk about our book of the month, Kitchen Confidential: adventures in the culinary underbelly, Anthony Bourdain's funny, shocking memoir about life in the culinary trade. You can get a copy at Maria A. Shchuka Library while supplies last. Inquire at the first floor circulation desk.
There are also digital copies available through Overdrive, which you can find on the Toronto Public Library's website. Ask library staff to show you how to borrow eBooks. Or, you can place a hold on the book yourself. All are welcome!

Upcoming book club meetings:

Tuesday, August 27: Kitchen confidential: adventures in the culinary underbelly by Anthony Bourdain.

Tuesday, September 24: Foster by Claire Keegan.

It is a hot summer in rural Ireland. A child is taken by her father to live with relatives on a farm, not knowing when or if she will be brought home again. In the Kinsellas' house, she finds an affection and warmth she has not known and slowly, in their care, begins to blossom. But there is something unspoken in this new household--where everything is so well tended to--and this summer must soon come to an end.

For more information, please call: 416-394-1000.

Toronto Public Library is committed is accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks notice is preferred. Phone (416) 393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

description:

description:
IMPORTANT: This month, two sessions are being offered on August 14 & 28 to accommodate smaller class sizes. Please sign up for ONE of the sessions as both classes will be run identically.

Find the joy in using a simple pencil and piece of paper to create a beautiful piece of art. Bring your tea or coffee, relax and socialize during a laid-back session of drawing for everyone from beginners to more advanced artists.

Debora Dunn will share simple techniques and demonstrate examples of symmetry, texture, line and form that artists of all levels will be able to follow to create intricate designs.

Bring your favourite pencil or share one of ours! Please register at Leaside branch or by calling 416-396-3835.

description:

It aims to teach digital art in a way that is accessible and easy for those who are completely new to the medium by utilizing free and beginner-friendly drawing programs. The workshop is facilitated by Miranda, a Toronto-based illustrator and comic artist.

description:

  • how to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website

  • how to manage your account


    • To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
  • a valid email address;

  • proof of Canadian status for all household members; and

  • your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment.

Enjoy music and special crafts as we say goodbye to summer. Perfect for kids and families!
Plus, Summer Reading Club book club members will have a chance to win prizes in our prize ballot, drawn at the end of the program. Dont miss out on entering your guess for the candy jarsballots will be drawn for the winner with the closest number.

description:
Suit up for a space flight and experience the life of an astronaut! Kids use teamwork to complete an important space mission and learn how Ground Control connects with astronauts across the vast distance of space. This program is a taste of living above the world! For children ages 6 to 12. Registration required by calling (416) 393-7657.


If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: The Meaning of Dreams with Ann Schnurr
description:
*Program date changed from August 20 to August 29*
*Drop ins are welcome*

What do dreams mean? Join Registered Psychotherapist, Ann Schnurr, in this interactive program on dream interpretation. She will explore how dreams have informed us through the ages, drawing on insights from the works of Psychoanalysts, Carl Jung and Sigmund Freud, and provide insight on how you can best interpret your own dreams.

Ann is a Registered Psychotherapist, holds a diploma from the Institute for Psychotherapy and Emotional Bodywork (IPEB, 1999), is a member in good standing with The College of Registered Psychotherapists of Ontario (CRPO) and The Canadian Association of Psychodynamic Therapists (CAPT). Ann works with clients challenged with anxiety, depression, anger issues, and chronic illness. Ann uses many modalities in her work with clients and especially enjoys dream interpretation.

Registration is currently available on Eventbrite.

For more information, contact
Toronto Reference Library - Business, Science and Technology
789 Yonge Street
P: 416-393-7149
E: trlbus@tpl.ca

TPL is committed to providing accessible and inclusive programming.
If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in our programs, please contact us two (2) weeks in advance.

title: Learn How to Use Your Credit Card for Your Benefit
description:
In this presentation, you will learn about when is the best time to use your credit card and how due dates work. Financial Planner, Tessa- Marie, will go over topics such as credit bureaus, line of credit and credit scores. At the end of the session you will be better equipped to understand your credit card statement and use your credit card for your benefit.

Tessa-Marie Shillingford was the Manager of Financial Services at one of the leading financial institution in Ontario. She has a designation as a Personal Financial Planner including Personal Financial Counselling issued by the institute of Canadian Bankers that has eminently qualified her to provide her exceptional insight into personal financial and credit management. Tessa-Marie worked with JVS Toronto from 2010-2014 where she facilitated their Financial Literacy program.


Registration is encouraged. Sign up here on Eventbrite. Drop-ins are welcome until capacity is reached. For more information, contact the 4th floor, Business Science and Technology desk at 416-395-5613 or email clbst@tpl.ca.

description:

-Stress management and the art of distressing
-Beliefs, values and attitudes, self-awareness and meditation
-Self-confidence and mindfulness

description:
Understanding the language of contracts and how they function in small arts businesses is vitally important for artists. This presentation demystifies contracts and other common arts business documents. Information will include the purpose they serve, what information belongs on each document and why.

This program will be led by TPL's 2024 Arts Mentor in Residence, Kathryn Adams.

Drop in, no registration required.

Check out the Arts Mentor in Residence page for detailed program listings and how to sign up for free, one-on-one consultations.

title: Coding with Python II
description:
Python is an open source programming language that is used for creating web applications, web content, mathematics and system scripting. In this follow up course you will learn about some more advanced coding concepts and how to incorporate them in real world examples. Key takeaways will include a working knowledge of functions and data structures.

This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of Python or have attended Coding with Python I.



Computers will be provided for this class. Registration is required on Eventbrite.

title: Coding with Python IV
description:
Python is an open source programming language that is used for creating web applications, web content, mathematics and system scripting. In this follow up course we will take our understanding of data structures to the next level as well as looking into the next stages of error handling (including making some custom error messages) and extending our knowledge of input/output to more than just the terminal.

This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of Python or have attended Python Basics I, II, and III.

** Registration will start 2 weeks before this class. Computers will be provided. **

title: Intro to Photography and Lightroom
description: In this workshop, we will discuss how to easily and effectively post process photos in Adobe Lightroom. We will also discuss the use of Manual mode on the camera, things such as exposure, aperture, ISO, zoom etc

title: Start or Grow Your Business with Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre
description:
Owning a business is a dream for many people. Every new business starts with an idea. This interactive presentation will give an overview of how to make it happen and the opportunity to ask questions related to your business.

An advisor from Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre (TSBEC) will present an overview of information related to the business planning process, evaluating a business idea, financing, marketing planning, business structures, regulatory requirements, and more.

Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre (TSBEC) is a City of Toronto service that provides a one-stop source to start and grow your small business.

Registration required. Registration opens July 20th, 2024. To register, please call 416-394-5240.

description:

About subsidized housing options like Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI)
How to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website
How to manage your account

To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
A valid email address;
Proof of Canadian status for all household members; and
Your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment.

To learn more and register for a session please visit the Access to Housing registration page.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:
  • Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
  • Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Toronto Reference Library WRAP Group will run every Saturday from July 13th to August 31st 2024 from 10 A.M. to 12 P.M. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library, by phone at (416) 393-7175, or visit gersteincentre.org. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Computers for Beginners 5: Use Google Search and Maps
description:
A class on using Google's filters, tools, and Maps for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this fourth session you will:

- Use Google search tools more effectively to find websites, images, and news sites
- Explore Google Maps to find addresses and get directions for transit and road travel.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use more advanced search engine features and use Google Maps at a basic level.

Registration is required. Please call York Woods at 416-395-5980 to register for this program.

Pre-requisites: Computers for Beginners 1, 2 & 3 or basic mouse, keyboarding and internet skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

title: After School Club: Snap Circuits
description:
Looking for something to do after school? Come out to our After School Club and learn new things, make stuff, meet other kids and have fun!

Tuesdays, September 3, 10, 17, 24, October 1 - Snap Circuits

Build exciting electronic projects with SNAP CIRCUITS! Have fun learning about circuitry and electricity. Turn on a light, spin a motor, activate a speaker and choose from over 300 different projects.

title: Coding with Python I
description:
Python is an open source programming language that is used for creating web applications, web content, mathematics and system scripting. In this online course you will learn how python code works and given time to practice. Prior coding knowledge is not necessary for this introductory class. Key takeaways will include a working knowledge of variables, loops, conditional arguments and much more.

This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of computer skills -- basically, if you can use a word processor or surf the web, you can learn Python!

Prior to the class, participants will need to download and install Python and VS Code onto their personal computers (installation guides provided after registration).

Registration is limited and specific instructions including information about software installation will be provided.

For more information about this program please contact dihonline@tpl.ca.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. title: CultureLink's Citizenship Education Circle - Newcomers Learn About Canada
description:
In partnership with CultureLink, free weekly sessions to help you prepare for the Canadian Citizenship Test

* Learn about the test's contents and structure
* Get support and tips from CultureLink's Volunteer Mentors
* Practice with sample quizzes

These summer sessions run EVERY TUESDAY from July 16th to September 17th (6pm-8:30pm).

Please consider attending all the sessions because the instructor will cover different aspects of the book, Discover Canada: The Rights and Responsibilities of Citizenship, which will be provided for by the instructor.

NOTE: Tuesdays classes for Tuesdays August 6th and September 3rd are located in Room B1 on the lower level (instead of the Discussion Room).

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Cercle de conversation bilingue/Bilingual Conversation Circle (Jane / Dundas)
description:
Le Programme Connexions Communautaires du Centre Francophone du Grand Toronto ainsi que la Bibliothque publique de Toronto vous invitent au prochain cercle de conversation bilingue qui aura lieu le mercredi 4 septembre de 11h 12h30 la succursale Jane/Dundas.

Les cercles de conversation bilingues constituent une bonne opportunit pour pratiquer votre anglais et/ou franais. C'est aussi un moment d'change et de rseautage entre participants.

Veuillez noter que le nombre de places est limit. Inscrivez-vous sur Eventbrite afin de confirmer votre participation.

Pour plus d'informations sur les cercles de conversation bilingues, veuillez nous contacter programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca ou en composant le 416-393-7650 pour la succursale City Hall.

La Bibliothque publique de Toronto s'est engage assurer l'accessibilit. Veuillez nous appeler ou nous envoyer un courriel si vous tes sourd(e) ou avez un handicap et souhaitez demander des mesures d'adaptation pour participer ce programme. Veuillez nous en informer le plus tt possible et nous ferons de notre mieux pour rpondre votre demande. Un pravis d'au moins trois semaines est prfrable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.



****



The Community Connections Program of the Centre Francophone du Grand Toronto and the Toronto Public Library invite you to join the bilingual conversation circle which will take place on Wednesday September 4 from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at the Jane/Dundas branch.

Come join us for the bilingual conversation circle! The bilingual conversation circle is a good opportunity for French-speakers to practice English and for English-speakers to improve their French. It is a great chance to meet new people and to explore networking opportunities.

The number of places is limited. Please register sur Eventbrite.

For more details about the bilingual conversation circles, please contact us at programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca or by calling City Hall library at 416-393-7650.

title: Computers for Beginners Series
description:
Computers for Beginners is a series of 6 classes which have been designed to take a learner with no, or very few, skills from zero to a solid grounding in the absolute basics. Each class is set up to connect with the previous and next class in a series format. Registration is for all 6 classes, attendance to Part 1 and 2 is mandatory if you do not have mouse or keyboard knowledge.

Part 1: Use the Mouse, September 4
Part 2: Use the Keyboard, September 11
Part 3: Use the Internet, September 18
Part 4: Use Google Search and Maps, September 25
Part 5: Use Windows, October 2
Part 6: Gmail Basics, October 9

Registration required, please visit the branch or call 416-396-8920.

title: **FULL** PowerPoint Basics 1: Create a Simple Presentation
description:
A introductory class on Microsoft PowerPoint 2019 for absolute beginners.

In this session you will:
- Create, save and run a PowerPoint Presentation
- Manipulate and re-order slides
- Format text and images and apply a design style

Upon completion of this class, students will be able to create and run a simple PowerPoint slideshow.

Prerequisites: Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

Registration is required. Registration is now full. Please contact the Browsery Department at 416-395-5672, or visit the 1st floor reference desk, to be added to the waitlist.

title: Excel Basics Part 1: Create a Simple Spreadsheet
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel 2019 for absolute beginners with little or no Excel experience.
In this first session you will:
- Learn the basic function and design of Excel files
- Practice basic data entry for text, numbers, and basic functions: Sum, AutoSum and Average
- Create and save your first workbook and worksheets
Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Excel at a basic level.
Pre-requisites: Basic mouse and keyboard skills are required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]
Please register by calling the User Education Department at 416-393-7209.
If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. description:

Whether you are a seasoned crochetier or picking up a set of knitting needles for the first time, everyone is welcome to share techniques, enjoy friendly conversation, and learn a new skill. Connect with fellow craftspeople as you work on your project. We will have some supplies available for beginners, but please feel free to bring your own. Drop-in; no registration required.

description:

* Basics of 3D Printing

*How to access and use 3D printer at the Digital Innovation Hub at Toronto Public Library

description:

In this class you will:
-Learn how to open, create, and save documents.
-Compose a letter.
-Practice Word's most popular formatting tools.
-Learn how to erase text and use the undo/ redo button.
-Practice changing settings for line spacing and text alignment.
