title: Makey Makey for Kids
description:
The Makey Makey is a circuit-building toy that lets you send electrical signals through a USB cable to a computer. By closing different circuits with any conductor, including foil, Play-Doh, or even your skin, you can send the computer a variety of signals, including mouse-clicks, space-bar and arrow keys. You can set up a variety of activities with the Makey Makey, including playing a piano keyboard or computer games.

This program intended for kids 8-12 years old.
* Please call or register in branch beginning August 21. *

description:

title: Casey McQuiston: The Pairing
description:
Casey McQuiston, New York Times bestselling author of Red, White and Royal Blue, joins us to discuss their wildly anticipated new romantic comedy about two bisexual exes who accidentally book the same European food and wine tour. Before the talk, get crafty and dream up your next vacation by creating a customized collage tote bag inspired by a summer of European travel as a part of a special pre-show event.

In The Pairing, we meet Theo and Kit, a pair of estranged exes who exited each other's lives after a brutal breakup on the transatlantic flight to their dream European food and wine tour.

In the years since, Theo has found confidence as a hustling bartender by night and aspiring sommelier by day. Kit, who never returned to America, now bakes at one of the finest restaurants in Paris. All that remains of their relationship is the unused voucher for the European tour that never happened. Four years later, it seems like a great idea to finally take the trip. Solo. Separately.

It's not until they board the tour bus that they discover they've both accidentally had the exact same idea, and now they're trapped with each other for three weeks of stunning views, luscious flavors, and the most romantic cities of France, Spain, and Italy. It's fine. There's nothing left between them. So much nothing that they challenge each other to a hookup competition to prove they're over each other.

But sometimes a taste of everything only makes you crave what you can't have.

Casey McQuiston speaks with journalist and author Rachel Giese about The Pairing, a magnetic 'exes-to-lovers' story steeped in the irresistible flavours of a European summer.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

About the DIY Travel Tote Bag Pre-Show: Need a new favourite tote to take on your next trip, pack for a beach day, or carry your current read? Starting at 6 pm, join Victoria Stacey of The Neighbourhood Market for a special pre-show event to create a customized collage tote bag. You will choose from a selection of travel-themed images to decorate your own tote inspired by a European summer. This workshop is suitable for all levels of experience and all materials are included. Get ready to make something special! (Space is limited. Ticket registration is required.)

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on August 1 at 9:00am ET.

About this event's guests:
Casey McQuiston
Rachel Giese

Read more:
The Pairing
Red, White and Royal Blue
Boys: What it Means to Become a Man

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Workshop: Understanding Depression & Anxiety Disorder
description:
Start thinking about mental health and well-being in later life! Join us to gain an understanding of mental health issues like depression, or anxiety disorders as they appear in late life. The presenter from Camh(Centre for Addiction and Mental Health) will answer your questions & assist you in understanding the factors that impact your mental health in later life. You will leave with new strategies to maintain your well-being.

title: Partners in (Fictional) Crime: Two Authors, One Book
description:
Hear first-hand about the fun and challenges of writing as part of a team from four talented authors in this Crime Writers of Canada panel discussion.

Moderater Jass Aujla will be joined by writing duos Alie & Hejsa Christensen and Michael & Zack Urlocker in a fascinating program aimed at writers and readers alike.

Jass Aujla is the Canadian South-Asian author of suspense-thriller, Next Of Twin. Jass' poetry has also appeared in thirteen bestselling anthology publications worldwide. She is the Crime Writers of Canada's Regional Board Director for Ontario (Southwest, North & GTA).

Alie and Hejsa Christensen are a mother-daughter writing duo based in Ontario. They discovered their affinity for working together when they were in-house writers for a film production company. Stealing John Hancock is their first novel.

Twin brothers Michael and Zack Urlocker write under the name M. Z. Urlocker. Inspired by true stories of individuals in tumultuous times, they write fiction about the intriguing era of the cold war.


Drop in, no registration required.


Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

description:

title: Moving Stories: art-based movement class for older adults
description:
Tiger princess dance projects, a non-profit contemporary dance company, brings you a free custom designed arts-based movement class for older adults. Join Artistic Director Yvonne Ng and her team of professional artists in a fun, healthy, and exciting arts program, Moving Stories.

These free classes offer an introduction into the enriching world of art and creativity through movement and music. These activities have proven to improve circulation, retain joint mobility, promote mental stimulation, improve posture and coordination, and build strength and balance.

- No previous movement experience required.
- Suggested Age: 60 +
- Go at your own pace, modifications encouraged
- Exercises can be modified for seated movement and/or standing

Please register in person or by calling 416-396-3835. By registering, you are signing up for all of the dates.

title: Careers with Ontario Public Service
description:
Are you interested in working with the Ontario Public Service? The Ontario Public Service (OPS) is one of the largest employers in the province, employing more than 60,000 people. They offer a wide range of meaningful and rewarding career opportunities in communities across Ontario (Careers: Ontario Public Service | ontario.ca). This session is an opportunity to hear directly from OPS regarding their organization, hiring practices and timelines, career opportunities, job application process, and career advancement within OPS.

Discussion moderated by Career Coach in Residence Tinu Olawuyi.

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener and Google Canada.

Questions about online programs? Email us at programproposals@tpl.ca

description:

Each week is a new opportunity to:

Meet new people and make new connections

title: Cyanotype & Lumen Printing Workshop
description:
This workshop will be a fun exploration of cameraless photographic practices using both Lumen and Cyanotype printing with botanicals and the sun. Students will learn the process of Cyanotype by sensitizing paper, exposure using flowers/plants and fixing their prints with water. Lumen printing using B&W darkroom photo paper will also be covered!

This program is part of the TAC's Artist in the Library Program in conjunction with Mount Dennis Library. It will be run by filmmaker Eva Kolcze and photographer Jessica Thalmann.

Event is FREE but please reserve a place as space is limited. Eventbrite registration begins August 13.

title: Redefining Canadian Cuisine with Chef Imrun Texeira
description:
Come join Chef Imrun Texeira who has worked in some of the world's best and most influential restaurants, including 3 Michelin Starred Noma in Copenhagen. Most recently Imrun received the 2023 Leader Award of Excellence from Restaurants Canada. He was also awarded the 2023 Alumni of Distinction Award for Apprentice of the Year by Algonquin College. Chef Texeira has been named as a recipient of the Top 30-Under-30 Award for hospitality leaders in Canada and as a rising talent in North America by The Art of Plating. Imrun has starred on the Food Network's Top Chef Canada Season 8 and Chopped Canada Season 3.

In his workshop Chef Imrun Texeira will address the question "What is Canadian Cuisine?", with inspiration from the book "Speaking in Cod Tongues." Chef Imrun will showcase dishes he has made that represent and support his mission to define modern Canadian cuisine.

The program will have samples of Ube cheesecake, with Passionfruit Popping Boba, and Dark Chocolate coated Puffed Quinoa.

Registration is required. Please register at the front desk or by calling 416-394-5170.

This program is generously supported by a donation from Adrian and Ange Rocca.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email at accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail at 416-393-7099 to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Haunted Heritage: Honouring Our History's Ghosts
description:
Forty-five years ago, The Searcher Group (TSG) - Canada's oldest, most reputable and accomplished paranormal research team - was founded. Join TSG Assistant Director and author Peter Roe for a fascinating look at how ghost presences within historic sites can be respectfully utilized to call attention to Ontario's vanishing heritage and help keep history alive. Skeptics, believers and the curious alike are all welcome to attend this judgment-free event.

This is an in-person program, drop-ins welcome. 35 seats are available, no registration required.

title: Understanding the Universe
description:
THIS WILL TAKE THE PLACE OF STEM SATURDAY ON SATURDAY SEPTEMBER 7, 2024.

Astronomer Margaret Ikape takes us on a journey through the universe starting with known and familiar things on the earth and then building up the scale to things in the solar system, the galaxy, the group of galaxies and then the observable universe.

Along with how astronomers study these objects and eras in space, she will also share her personal journey to become an astronomer and what she does in her research to increase the knowledge we have about the universe.

Registration is required. Please register in person at Bloor/Gladstone Branch or by phone at (416) 393-7674. *Registration starts August 12. Children of all ages are welcome. Children must be accompanied by a guardian.

title: Reel Injun
description:
From the National Film Board of Canada, we'll be screening Reel Injun (2009):

In this feature-length documentary, Cree filmmaker Neil Diamond takes an entertaining and insightful look at the portrayal of North American Indigenous people throughout a century of cinema. Featuring hundreds of clips from old classics as well as recent releases, the film traces the evolution of the Hollywood Indian. Diamond guides the audience on a journey across America to some of cinemas most iconic landscapes and conducts candid interviews with celebrities like Clint Eastwood, Robbie Robertson and Jim Jarmusch. The film is a loving look at cinema through the eyes of the people who appeared in its very first flickering images and have survived to tell their stories in their own way.

Drop-in.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Ruth Lor Malloy: Brightening My Corner
description:
Journalist, writer, and activist Ruth Lor Malloy will share her life story as a woman who explores the world, battles racial prejudice and collects old shoes.

Ruth was born into a Chinese restaurant family in Brockville, Ontario, in 1932. She was involved in the first racial discrimination trial in Canada 70 years ago and has dedicated her life to fighting racism. Her memoir, Brightening My Corner, recounts her journey of activism and helping others in Canada and around the world.

Books will be available for sale by the author after the talk.

title: Heather O'Neill: The Capital of Dreams
description:
Bestselling author Heather O'Neill discusses her new novel, a stunning dark fairytale of survival and betrayal.

The Capital of Dreams introduces us to Sofia Bottom, who lives in a small country that Europe has forgotten. But inside its borders, the old myths of trees that come alive and faeries who live among their roots have given way to an explosion of the arts and the consolations of philosophy. No one, from the clarinetists to the cabaret singers, is as revered in the arts as Sofia's brilliant mother, the writer Clara Bottom. How can 14 year old Sofia, with a tin ear and an enduring love of the old myths, ever hope to win her mother's love?

When the country's greatest enemy invades, and the Capital is under threat, at last Clara turns to her daughter. Sofia must smuggle her new manuscript to safety on the last train evacuating children from the city. But the train draws to a suspicious halt in the middle of a forest, and Sofia must run for her life, losing her mother's most prized possession. Now frightened and alone in a country at war, Sofia must find a way to reclaim what she has lost. On an epic journey through woods and razed towns, colliding with soldiers, survivors and other lost children, Sofia must make the choice between kindness and survival.

Heather O'Neill speaks with award-winning writer Emma Donoghue about The Capital of Dreams, a novel that once again reveals that she is a master of language.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Heather O'Neill
Emma Donoghue

Read more:
The Capital of Dreams
When We Lost Our Heads
Learned by Heart
Room

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. We'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library:

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. title: SafeTALK
description:
This 3-hour SafeTALK workshop equips participants to become more alert to the signs of suicidal thoughts and better able to connect individuals with the necessary support. The workshop emphasizes the importance of recognizing the signs, effectively communicating with someone considering suicide, and directing them to the appropriate help and resourced.

Open to ages 16 and up, this workshop is ideal for:
  • Parents and caregivers
  • Family and friends
  • Youth aged 16 or older
  • Natural helpers and advisors
  • Educators and ministers
  • Health practitioners
  • Justice and law enforcement professionals
  • Emergency workers
  • Community volunteers

Registration is required. To register, please call Lillian H. Smith Branch at 416-393-7746.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre.

title: Coding with Python II
description:
Python is an open source programming language that is used for creating web applications, web content, mathematics and system scripting. In this online course you will learn how python code works and given time to practice.

In this second online Python session we will leverage everything we learned about loops and blocks in part one to create our very own functions. We'll take a look at how to approach function design, how to allow users to enter data into functions through arguments, and how to get our functions to return results. We will also introduce some new data structures which, unlike variables, can hold more than one piece of data at a time.

Prior to the class, participants will need to download and install Python and VS Code onto their personal computers (installation guides provided after registration).

Registration is limited and specific instructions including information about software installation will be provided.

For more information about this program please contact dihonline@tpl.ca.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. title: In Jesus' Name: Shattering the Silence of St. Anne's Residential School
description:
Film Screening / Discussion

Join us for a screening of In Jesus' Name: Shattering the Silence of St. Anne's Residential School , followed by a Question & Answer with director Susan G. Enberg and St. Anne's Survivor, Evelyn Korkmaz. Residential School Survivor and peer advocacy worker Michael Cheena will open and close the event.

No registration required. This event is taking place on the ground floor of the building in Beeton Hall.

In Jesus' Name: Shattering the Silence of St. Anne's Residential School is a poignant all Indigenous English and Cree documentary, and it breaks long-held silences imposed upon children who were interned at the notoriously violent St. Annes Residential School in Fort Albany First Nation, Ontario. First Nations children from all over the western James Bay region suffered isolation from family and community as well as physical, sexual, spiritual and cultural abuse at the hands of the Catholic Oblates of Mary Immaculate and the Sisters of Charity. Some were abused by other students who had learned violent behaviours from their 'caregivers.'

***
Susan Enberg is a documentary producer, photographer, and editor living in Toronto. She is primarily concerned with shedding light on egregious human rights abuses. Most of Susan's work to date has been with Survivors of the notoriously violent St. Anne's Residential School that was located in Fort Albany First Nation.

Evelyn Korkmaz is an Indigenous Cree Survivor of St. Annes Residential School. Ms. Korkmaz advocates passionately for survivors of the Indian Residential School System and is committed to educating Canadians by sharing her personal experiences through public speaking engagements. Evelyn is a founding member of Ending Clergy Abuse and Advocates for Clergy Trauma Survivors in Canada has presented and testified before various committees at the United Nations. A member of the Nishnawbe Aski Nation Treaty #9 territory, Ms. Korkmaz occupies a pivotal role within the Nikanigawbowin Council.

Michael Cheena is First Nation with Cree ancestry from James Bay. He has held several leading roles in native communities in Ontario, including being a former President of Toronto Council Fire Native Cultural Centre Board of Directors. Michael received the Commemorative Medal for the 125th Anniversary of the Confederation of Canada in recognition of voluntary service. A survivor of two residential schools, Michael has shared his residential school experience with non-Indigenous Canadians. Michael is currently a Peer Advocacy Worker for IRSS at the Toronto Council Fire Native Cultural Centre.

***

Content Warning: This program features information about residential schools and personal accounts of residential school experiences. The National Indian Residential School Crisis Line (1-866-925-4419) is available 24/7 for Survivors and their families who are experiencing pain or distress as a result their experience in residential schools. Indigenous persons can access crisis intervention and immediate mental health counselling through the Hope for Wellness Helpline (1-855-242-3310).

***

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

title: True Crime Club
description: This club is for those who enjoy discussing true crimes from next door to around the world. We are a passionate group and always discuss cases in a respectful manner. Come and join us on the second Tuesday of the month for an intimate evening of True Crime.
otherinfo: June 11  Jack the Ripper was an unidentified serial killer active in the Whitechapel district of London, England, in 1888.

title: Wednesday Afternoon @ the Movies: Ordinary Angels
description:
Based on a remarkable true story, ORDINARY ANGELS centers on Sharon Steves, a fierce but struggling hairdresser in small-town Kentucky who discovers a renewed sense of purpose when she meets Ed Schmitt, a widower working hard to make ends meet for his two daughters. With his youngest daughter waiting for a liver transplant, Sharon sets her mind to helping the family and will move mountains to do it. What unfolds is the inspiring tale of faith, everyday miracles, and ordinary angels.

Drop-in. No registration required.

title: Astronomy in the Movies: Fiction vs. Reality
description:
***RESCHEDULED FROM EARLIER DATE***

Join the Dunlap Institute and learn about how astronomy is portrayed in the media. Whether its a first contact science fiction movie, or a historical adaptation of the space race, we are bombarded with content that are not necessarily accurate representations of what astronomy is. In this talk, we debunk some common movie tropes around astronomy representation and investigate what real life astronomy actually looks like.

DROP-IN, NO REGISTRATION REQUIRED
Program Room A, Second Floor

title: Culture and Technology Book Club: Tools for Conviviality
description:
The Culture and Technology Book club brings readers together once a month to discuss new and classic texts that raise important questions about the way technology transforms our cultural and political lives. The group will read on relevant topics related to social media, innovation, surveillance and infrastructure.

This month we read: Chapter 2 of Tools for Conviviality by Ivan Ilich (1973)

Ivan Illich, philosopher and social critic, identifies a crisis in the relationship between human and machine: it turns out that machines do not work and that people cannot be schooled for a life at the service of machines (p.19). This crisis is in part a result of the way that people relate to tools, and in this chapter he discusses a way that people can change their relationship to their tools in order to make their tools work for them



Registration is encouraged. Drop-ins welcome. Book your ticket through Eventbrite.

For more information, contact the 3rd floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-393-7149.

Comments, bonus reading suggestions, or want to sign up for The Culture and Technology mailing list? Send an email to naomidavies@tpl.ca. Reading chapters of some of the readings will be sent out to members ahead of time. Reach out to us if youd like a copy and havent received one.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in these programs. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Dionne Brand: Salvage
description:
Award winning author of 23 books of poetry, fiction and non-fiction, Dionne Brand, joins us to discuss her new novel, Salvage - her first work of non-fiction since the release of her groundbreaking A Map to the Door of No Return over twenty years ago.

In Salvage, Brand interrogates the colonial, racist tropes found in classic literature and her own experience of reading and deconstructing dominant cultural narratives as an act of defiant self-creation. Part memoir and part cultural criticism, Salvage challenges the role played by "the classics" in continuing to push damaging colonial rhetoric.

In conversation with author and professor of English literature, David Chariandy.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:

Dionne Brand

David Chariandy

Read More:

A Map to the Door of No Return
What We All Long For
Soucouyant
Brother

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

This event is also part of TPL's About Black History and Culture Series.

Presenting Sponsor of Heritage Programs: TD Bank Group, through the TD Ready Commitment.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Learn about subsidized housing in Toronto
description:
Housing Help Centre staff will be hosting free in-person workshops at Scarborough Civic Centre library.

Join a session to learn:
- about subsidized housing options like Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI)
- how to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website
-how to manage your account

To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
- a valid email address;
- proof of Canadian status for all household members; and
- your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment.

To learn more and register for a session, please visit the Access to Housing registration page.

description: Join us for a lively discussion at one (or both!) of our book club meetings at Eglinton Square. Re-read old favourites and discover some new ones. Come into the branch to pick up your copy of the book today. One book club meets once a month on Tuesday and the other on Thursday.

title: EarlyON: Baby and Me
description:
Join us for a FREE interactive program for you and your baby (birth-12 months) to promote bonding and early learning development through songs, play, shared parenting and caregiving discussions and more!

Come and have fun! Please speak to staff for specific programs and activities. For more information, please call 647-289-0676.

Every Thursday May, July, September, November, 2024.

Drop-in. No registration is required.

In partnership with East York East Toronto Family Resources Organization, EarlyON Centre.

If your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services at accessibleservices@tpl.ca or phone 416-393-7099. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: English Conversation Circle
description:
Are you learning English or new to Canada?

Practice your English conversation skills in a relaxing environment while making new friends and learning what the library has to offer!

Beginner and intermediate learners welcome. Please note that this is not a formal English class.

You must have a ticket to attend this program. Tickets are free and will be available in front of Room 101 on the first floor beginning at 1:30pm. Space is limited.

For more information visit the Language, Literature and Fine Arts Department or call (416) 395-5639.

title: **FULL** Excel Basics 2: Do More with your Data
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

In this second session you will:
- Practice data entry and formatting
- Manipulate rows and columns
- Create and copy simple formulas
- Convert data to a Table then sort and filter
- Create your first chart

Upon completion of this class, students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.

Prerequisites: Excel Basics Part 1 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.

Registration is required. Registration is now full. Please contact the Browsery Department at 416-395-5672, or visit the 1st floor reference desk, to be added to the waitlist.

title: Introduction to DaVinci Resolve
description:
In this 2 hour class, students will be introduced to the essentials of the industry standard video editing software, Davinci Resolve. Participants will learn the fundamental skills of video editing, and get hands-on practice. Some prior computer experience is necessary.

Registration is required. Registration opens on Thursday, August 29th, 2024 at 12:30pm

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Excel Basics III
description:
Excel Basics III will discuss filtering and sorting tables, basic PivotTable, creating and formatting charts, and mail merge. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

Register in person in the branch or by calling 416-394-1000.

If the above class date does not fit for your busy schedule, you may book an appointment with a librarian on one-on-one basis.

title: Nature TO: Trees Around the Branch Tour
description:
The Daniel G. Hill Library (formerly Jane Dundas) and its neighbourhood is home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to explore the natural world on a local neighbourhood walk. Learn how to recognize different species and fun facts about their cultural and ecological importance.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver.

Please note, the tour will start and end at the Daniel G. Hill Library (formerly Jane Dundas). The City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff will take participants outside and around the neighbourhood where there may be uneven, unpaved surfaces will guide attendees. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes).

Registration is required. Please call 416-394-1014 to register.

This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, you will be notified of an alternative date.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone (416) 393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Learn about subsidized housing in Toronto
description:
Housing Help Centre staff will be hosting free in-person workshops at Albion branch.

Join a session to learn:
- about subsidized housing options like Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI)
- how to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website
- how to manage your account

To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
- a valid email address;
- proof of Canadian status for all household members; and
- your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment.

To learn more and register for a session please visit the Access to Housing website and register for a session: [https://tinyurl.com/3d46z64w]

title: Knitting Circle
description:
Join other knitters and crocheters for an hour in a knitting circle! Exchange knitting and crochet tips and tricks. Bring your projects, troubleshoot patterns, or work on that piece you've been wanting to try. All skill levels welcome. Please bring your own supplies.

description:

title: Indigenous Food Sovereignty & Plant medicine
description:
Learn about the Albert Campbell library's Indigenous entryway garden with Chef Johl Whiteduck. Johl will connect us to our plant and seed ancestors. Join us in the garden and he shares insights on Indigenous Agroecology and Indigenous seed sovereignty with examples from garden plantings at the library.

Through Miinikaan Innovation and Design Johl has co-designed and created Indigenous teaching gardens even in the smallest of urban spaces. Proprietor of NishDish Marketeria and Catering since 2005, Johl brings his perspective on reclaiming and relearning Indigenous knowledge about the foods, seeds, and plant medicine.

Registration is encouraged. To register, please call 416-396-8900 or speak to staff at the library.

title: The Romance Book Club
description:
A monthly discussion on diverse and inclusive romance books. Suitable for 18+

Join us online for a lively discussion of The Long Game by Elena Armas. Copies are available in regular print and audiobook formats at branches, as well as eBook format through OverDrive.

About this month's book:

Adalyn Reyes knows exactly what she wants: to impress her rich father and boss enough to be granted a promotion to run the Miami Flames soccer club. Unfortunately, after an incident involving her beheading the team's mascot, Adalyn finds herself banished to North Carolina to head some charity work for the club in the form of managing a young girls' soccer team Everything goes from bad to worse when Adalyn discovers she's staying in a crumbling, infested shed next to a hot neighbor who hates her.

Former professional goalkeeper Cameron Caldani was simply looking for a quiet place to disappear for a while when he got suckered into coaching nine-year-old girls. One look at the uptight woman moving into the ramshackle shed next to his house while claiming she's his boss has him gunning to get her out of town.

This program requires registraion. Specific instructions on how to access Jitsi Meet will be sent to all registrants 30 mins before the book club meeting.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. description:
Owning a business is a dream for many people. Every new business starts with an idea. This interactive presentation will give an overview of how to make it happen and the opportunity to ask questions related to your business.

An advisor from Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre (TSBEC) will present an overview of information related to the business planning process, evaluating a business idea, financing, marketing planning, business structures, regulatory requirements, and more. Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre (TSBEC) is a City of Toronto service that provides a one-stop source to start and grow your small business.

Free tickets for this event will be available to book via Eventbrite beginning on September 5 at 6:30pm. https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/start-grow-your-business-with-toronto-small-business-enterprise-centre-tickets-951589378447

title: Indigenous Storytelling: Relationships, Resilience, Resurgence, Reconcili-action
description:
Join Indigenous activist, educator, storyteller, artist, and dancer, Jim Adams, as he shares how renewing our relationship with Four R's (Relationships, Resilience, Resurgence, Reconcili-action) can help bring balance to the course of humankind's path.

Drop-in. No registration required.

Jim is of mixed Indigenous and settler heritage and has a BFA, MFA, and M.Ed in Urban Indigenous Education. He seeks to make sense of the world through the use of story, music and movement. His greatest teachers and most profound understandings have come from relationships he has had with traditional Knowledge Keepers, Elders and his own children.

**

title: Treena Orchard: Sticky, Sexy, Sad
description:
Anthropologist Treena Orchard studies sexuality and a sex-positive feminism at Western University. Her debut book, Sticky, Sexy, Sad : Swipe Culture and the Darker Side of Dating Apps is part dating memoir and part anthropological study of the intersection of technology and modern love. In conversation with journalist Jen Kirsch.

After taking a much needed break from dating to pursue sobriety, Orchard decided to return to the dating pool by downloading a dating app. And instead of the fun, carefree and exciting experiences advertised by the app, she tumbled into a portal filled with ghosting, fleeting moments of sexual connection, and a steady flow of misogyny. Written with humour and vulnerability, Sticky, Sexy, Sad explores the social and human impacts of using dating apps

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:

Treena Orchard
Jen Kirsch

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Jack Rabinovitch Reading Room, located on the fourth floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library

We are committed to making our content accessible to as many Torontonians as possible. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively.

In this class you will:

- Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer

- Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists

description:
Tiger princess dance projects, a non-profit contemporary dance company, brings you a free custom designed arts-based movement class for older adults. Join Artistic Director Yvonne Ng and her team of professional artists in a fun, healthy, and exciting arts program, Moving Stories.

These free classes offer an introduction into the enriching world of art and creativity through movement and music. These activities have proven to improve circulation, retain joint mobility, promote mental stimulation, improve posture and coordination, and build strength and balance.

- No previous movement experience required.
- Suggested Age: 60 +
- Go at your own pace, modifications encouraged
- Exercises can be modified for seated movement and/or standing

Please register in person or by calling 416-396-3835. By registering, you are signing up for all of the dates.

description:
Le Programme Connexions Communautaires du Centre Francophone du Grand Toronto ainsi que la Bibliothque publique de Toronto vous invitent au prochain cercle de conversation bilingue qui aura lieu le 13 septembre de 18h 19h30 la Bibliothque de rfrence dans la Salle de discussion au 3e tage.

La Bibliothque publique de Toronto s'est engage assurer l'accessibilit. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

***

The Community Connections Program of the Centre Francophone du Grand Toronto and the Toronto Public Library invite you to join the bilingual conversation circle which will take place on September 13 from 6:00 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. at the Reference Library in Discussion Room on the 3rd floor.

Come join us for the bilingual conversation circle! The bilingual conversation circle is a good opportunity for French-speakers to practice English and for English-speakers to improve their French. It is a great chance to meet new people and to explore networking opportunities.

The number of places is limited. Please register on Eventbrite.

For more details about the bilingual conversation circles, please contact us at programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca or 416-393-7085.

title: Stuffy Sleepover Storytime
description:
Come in your pajamas, bring a stuffed animal, and join us for an evening storytime! Then, leave your stuffy overnight for a sleepover at the library. Pick up your stuffy on Saturday afternoon to learn all about their adventures the night before!

This is a registered program; space is limited. Register in branch or by calling 416-3963854.

If you or your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Open Mic Night
description:
Calling all musicians, poets, and storytellers to join us for an evening of sharing connection, and creativity. Acoustic guitars, ukuleles, and microphones, and amp will be available. All skill levels are welcome to attend.

This is a drop in program, no registration required.

title: Rachel Kushner: Creation Lake
description:
Author Rachel Kushner, Booker Prize finalist, two time National Book Award finalist, and called "one of the most gifted authors of her generation" (The New York Times Book Review), joins us to discuss her new novel, Creation Lake, about a seductive and cunning American woman who infiltrates an anarchist collective in France. Recently longlisted for the 2024 Booker Prize!

Written in short, vaulting sections, Rachel Kushner's rendition of "noir" is taut and dazzling. Creation Lake is Kushner's finest achievement yet as a novelist, a work of high art, high comedy, and unforgettable pleasure.

In conversation with author Sheila Heti.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Rachel Kushner
Sheila Heti

Read more:
Creation Lake
The Mayor of Leipzig
The Hard Crowd
Pure Colour
How Should A Person Be?

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: NatureTO: Trees Around The Branch Tour
description:
The Jones Library branch and its neighbourhood is home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to explore the natural world on a local neighbourhood walk. Learn how to recognize different species and fun facts about their cultural and ecological importance.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver.

Please note, the tour will start and end at the Jones Branch. The City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff outside and around the neighbourhood where there may be uneven, unpaved surfaces will guide attendees. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date.

Registration is required please contact the branch.

description:

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Excel at a basic level.

title: Why It Is Healthy To Talk About Death
description: Led by death doula, Dave Clark, this is a relaxed and welcoming lecture and discussion workshop to help enhance death literacy and reduce peoples fear of death by examining how death has been a natural part of living since the beginning of time. The presentation will be supported by reviewing the extensive range of services currently available to help people experience a good death.

description:
Create a more sophisticated PowerPoint 2019 presentation with more advanced features.

In this session you will:
- Insert and format tables, simple charts, and SmartArt graphics
- Insert a screenshot or video
- Add Speaker notes and Print presentations

Upon completion of this class, students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 or equivalent experience. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

Registration is required. Registration is now full. Please contact the Browsery Department at 416-395-5672, or visit the 1st floor reference desk, to be added to the waitlist.

title: Paint a Ghost 3D Printing Part 2
description:
In this hands-on workshop, staff members will guide participant to painting a 3D Printed Ghost, and demonstrate the various 3D printing post processes.

Topics include :*Support and brim removal, sanding and clean up, suggestion on paints, adhesives, and treatments, preparation, basic techniques, best practices, and finishes for painting 3D printed objects.

Registration is required on eventbrite. All materials will be provided.

title: Didier Leclair, Le jazz et l'criture
description:
Mlomane et crivain renomm vivant Toronto, Didier Leclair (de son vrai nom Kabagema) va nous parler de sa passion pour l'criture lie celle de jazz. Dans son dernier roman Le prince africain, le traducteur et le nazi, publi aux ditions David, le jazz et la musique dcorent le roman d'espionnage.

Comment mler l'amour de la musique avec celui des mots ? Est-ce que le jazz, au fond, n'est pas en quelque sortes la mme chose que le processus d'criture ?

Didier Leclair, nom de plume de l'auteur Didier Kabagema, est n Montral. Il a vcu dans plusieurs pays en Afrique avant de s'tablir Toronto. Rcipiendaire du Prix Trillium en 2000 pour Toronto, je t'aime, finaliste au Prix littraire du Gouverneur gnral en 2004 pour Ce pays qui est le mien et laurat du Prix Christine Dimitriu Van Saanen en 2016 pour son roman Pour l'amour de Dimitri, il partage son temps entre la littrature et sa passion pour le jazz.

En conversation avec Lamara Papitashvili, crivaine.

Cet vnement sera enregistr et va tre disponible en rediffusion via le mme lien.

****

Si vous vous considrez comme une personne handicape ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer ce programme, veuillez-nous en informer le plus tt possible. Composez le 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca Veuillez communiquer avec nous au moins trois semaines l'avance.

title: SafeTALK
description:
This 3-hour SafeTALK workshop equips participants to become more alert to the signs of suicidal thoughts and better able to connect individuals with the necessary support. The workshop emphasizes the importance of recognizing the signs, effectively communicating with someone considering suicide, and directing them to the appropriate help and resourced.

Open to ages 16 and up, this workshop is ideal for:

- Parents and caregivers
- Family and friends
- Youth aged 16 or older
- Natural helpers and advisors
- Educators and ministers
- Health practitioners
- Justice and law enforcement professionals
- Emergency workers
- Community volunteers

Registration is required. To register, please call Fort York Branch at 416-393-6240.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:

Dr. Jules Arita Koostachin's deeply personal documentary, WaaPaKe (Tomorrow), moves beyond intergenerational trauma, with an invitation to unravel the tangled threads of silence and unite in collective freedom and power.

Drop in. No registration required.

title: Place au cinma avec Cinfranco : Chien blanc d'Anas Barbeau-Lavalette.
description:
Chien Blanc est un film dramatique canadien, ralis par Anas Barbeau-Lavalette et sorti en 2022. Adapt du roman autobiographique de Romain Gary Chien Blanc , le film met en vedette Denis Mnochet dans le rle de Gary et Kacey Rohl dans le rle de son pouse Jean Seberg, et se concentre sur leur adoption d'un chien abandonn dont ils apprennent avec horreur qu'il avait t dress pour attaquer des Noirs vue, les amenant l'envoyer chez Keys, un dresseur de chiens noirs, pour son recyclage.

Il s'agit de la deuxime adaptation cinmatographique du livre de Romain Gary, aprs celle du ralisateur amricain Samuel Fuller en 1982.

Le film a t prsent en novembre 2022 en tant que film d'ouverture du Festival de films Cinemania.

Avec Denis Mnochet et Kacey Rohl.

En version originale avec des sous-titres en anglais.
Dure : 96 min.

Entre libre.

La projection de film va se drouler le lundi 16 septembre 18h la bibliothque de rfrence dans Beeton Hall et sera suivi d'une discussion anime par Marcelle Lean, Directrice gnrale et artistique de Cinfranco.


****

Si vous vous considrez comme une personne handicape ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer ce programme, veuillez nous en informer le plus tt possible. Composez le 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca Veuillez communiquer avec nous au moins trois semaines l'avance.

****

Pour toutes questions concernant ce programme, veuillez nous envoyer un courriel programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca

title: How to Increase Self-Esteem and Kick Imposter Syndrome
description:
This workshop aims to boost youth confidence as it relates to career development by addressing self-esteem concerns and imposter syndrome. Through a mix of educational content, interactive activities, and practical exercises, participants will gain strategies to build self-confidence and overcome mental barriers, empowering them to navigate their professional journeys with greater assurance.

Facilitated by Career Coach in Residence Shenelle Payne Cuffy with guest speaker Fatima Noorali.

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener and Google Canada.

Questions about online programs? Email us at programproposals@tpl.ca

description:

title: How to Become a Volunteer
description:
In collaboration with the Toronto Public Library, discover how to safely get involved as a volunteer. Learn where to search for opportunities and how to find the best match for your needs and goals - including volunteering virtually from home, or in person with a group or organization.

Youll also discover thousands of free online resources through the Toronto Public Library to help you learn more about the city, make community connections, and access other helpful support services. This session is great for youth, newcomers and seniors and anyone who wants to make a positive impact on our city, or improve or learn new skills.

Drop-in, no registration.

To receive an email reminder for the program, sign up at Volunteer Toronto.

title: Beverly McLachlin: Proof
description:
Former Chief Justice of Canada and #1 bestselling author Beverley McLachlin joins us to discuss her newest thriller novel, Proof, featuring the razor sharp defense attorney Jilly Truitt as she defends a high profile mother accused of kidnapping her own child.

In conversation with author Elizabeth Renzetti.

Q & A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Beverley McLachlin
Elizabeth Renzetti

Read more:
Proof
Full Disclosure
Bury The Lead

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library:

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. description:

Drop-in. No registration required.

This program will be held downstairs in the Childrens Department.

title: Ancestry Library Club
description:
For beginners. Learn basic searches to find records of your ancestors using the popular genealogy database Ancestry Library Edition. For those with little or no experience with family history.

In the first session you will:
-learn the basics of compiling a family tree
-use sample searches to explore Ancestry records for birth, marriage, death and the census
-experiment with wildcards to improve your searches

Prerequisites: Basic mouse and keyboarding skills required.

In subsequent sessions you will use what you learned to explore your own genealogy with staff available for support.

This is an in-person program. Registration begins August 20th. Please register in person or by calling the Brentwood branch at (416) 394-5240.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description: Join us for a classic or new release movie on selected Tuesday afternoons.  Drop in.  No registration required.  For more information please call the Cliffcrest Library:  416-396-8916

title: Word Basics 2: Format a Flyer
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively.

In this class you will:

- Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer
- Format text, margins, indents, headers and footers
- Format text as columns
- Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists
- Review your document with Spelling and Grammar check and Thesaurus

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use even more Word tools to design their documents.

Pre-requisite: Word Basics 1 or equivalent skills. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

Registration is required for each session. Please register at the branch or by calling 416-393-7700. Space is limited.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: **FULL** Word Basics 2: Format a Flyer
description:
Build on your basic Microsoft Word 2019 skills and learn to use Word more effectively.

In this class you will:
- Practice new Word skills while you design a flyer
- Format text, margins, indents, headers and footers
- Format text as columns
- Create bulleted, numbered and sorted lists
- Review your document with Spelling and Grammar check and Thesaurus

Upon completion of this class, students will be able to use even more Word tools to design their documents.

Prerequisite: Word Basics 1 or equivalent skills. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

Registration is required. Registration is now full. Please contact the Browsery Department at 416-395-5672, or visit the 1st floor reference desk, to be added to the waitlist.

title: Introduction to Adobe Premiere
description:
Adobe Premiere is an industry-leading piece of video editing software. With this powerful tool, you can edit virtually any type of media create professional productions for film, TV and the web. Premiere is a time-line based video editing application and can also integrate with the rest of the Adobe suite such as After Effects, Photoshop and more. In this introductory Premiere class you will learn basic video editing techniques such as adding clips, transitions and titles. Add audio to your project, along with cutting and splicing on your project's timeline. Located in the 2nd floor eLearning Lab.

Please note your spot is guaranteed only for the first five minutes of the class. Before using Illustrator, please be expected to log into your existing Adobe account, or through your Apple ID, Facebook or Gmail account, respectively.

Registration is required for this class. Free e-tickets will be available on September 3rd at 12:30pm.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Eventbrite sends some participants requests for additional information after events take place. TPL does not receive any of the feedback provided to Eventbrite. You can change your email preferences at any time in your Eventbrite Account settings if you do not wish to receive these surveys.

title: Job Search Tools
description:
In this session you will:

-Discuss how to get your job search organized
-Explore websites which advertise jobs
-Investigate jobs advertised directly by companies
-Learn about government sites and services
-Learn about TPLs Online Tools: Career Cruising and Scotts Business Directories
-Review learning and upskilling services such as LinkedIn Learning

Registration Required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at the library.

title: Use the Keyboard
description:
A class on basic keyboard functionss for absolute beginners with little or no computer experience.

In this second session you will:

- Familiarize yourself through practice with the most essential keyboard functions ( alphabet, number and symbol keys)
-Practice proper keyboarding posture
-Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a keyboard at a beginner level and know how to go online for additional practice.

Space is limited, phone 416-396-3975 to register.

title: Navigating  Post-Secondary Pathways for Newcomers
description:
Want to apply to Ontario public colleges as a mature student? Join this presentation to learn about Ontario public college system, credentials, application procedures, how to meet admissions requirements as a mature student, English proficiency requirements and credential evaluation, options to earn grade 12 credits, and academic prep study programs/employment focused programs for newcomers.

Please register in person or call Barbara Frum Branch at 416-395-5440.

title: Introduction to Adobe Photoshop
description:
Learn how to alter and retouch images using Adobe Photoshop CC, an industry standard software for PC & Mac. In this class you will learn to work with basic tools to resize, crop, modify colour, filter and add text to an image.

PLEASE NOTE: After registering create a free adobe account at https://www.adobe.com/ca/

You will need this account to sign into Adobe Photoshop during the class.

title: Straws and Connectors
description:
Straws and Connectors are ideal in helping children develop Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) skills. It allows children to enhance hand-eye coordination, motor skills, logic, and problem-solving skills all while playing. Build a fort, rocket, boat, tower, tunnel, or bridge!

For children ages 8-12. Space is limited. Registration begins Aug 20th. Register in branch or by calling 416-395-5460.

title: Computers for Beginners Series
description:
Computers for Beginners is a series of 6 classes which have been designed to take a learner with no, or very few, skills from zero to a solid grounding in the absolute basics. Each class is set up to connect with the previous and next class in a series format. Registration is for all 6 classes, attendance to Part 1 and 2 is mandatory if you do not have mouse or keyboard knowledge.

Part 1: Use the Mouse, August 20
Part 2: Use the Keyboard, August 27
Part 3: Use the Internet, September 3
Part 4: Use Google Search and Maps, September 10
Part 5: Use Windows, September 17
Part 6: Gmail Basics, September 24

Registration required, please visit the branch or call 416-396-8850 to register.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Godzilla x Kong
description:
Relegated to Hollow Earth, Kong feels lonely and continues to search for his family, but instead finds a fearsome enemy imprisoned and on the verge of breaking out to conquer the humans. Alongside his human family -- Jia, Ilene, Trapper, and Bernie -- he ventures above ground to recruit help from Godzilla and other Titans, but making allies from old enemies is never easy!

Drop In.

For more information call 416-393-7746

description:

Computers will be provided. No prior design skills necessary.

Registration will open 2 weeks prior to the date of the program. To register, please click the link below.

title: Yes, You Can Win Scholarships: Busting Common Myths to Help Students and Parent
description: ​Scholarships are accessible to more students than what is commonly believed. And here is the most important thing: scholarships can be a game changer for a student's career, their financial well-being, and their or their family's bank account. Scholarships, grants, and bursaries are available for high school, college, and university students, and you don't need perfect grades! This presentation will help empower attendees with information to find and win money for postsecondary education.

title: Coding with Python III
description:
Python is an open source programming language that is used for creating web applications, web content, mathematics and system scripting. In this follow up course we will really start to stretch our legs in Python, designing and implementing some simple Object Oriented Programming data structures. Key takeaways will include a working knowledge of Python classes and objects.

This class is for beginners but assumes you have a basic understanding of Python or have attended Python Basics I and II.

Prior to the class, participants will need to download and install Python and VS Code onto their personal computers (installation guides provided after registration).

Registration is limited and specific instructions including information about software installation will be provided.

For more information about this program please contact dihonline@tpl.ca.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

description:

title: CultureLink's Citizenship Education Circle - Newcomers Learn About Canada
description:
In partnership with CultureLink, free weekly sessions to help you prepare for the Canadian Citizenship Test

* Learn about the test's contents and structure
* Get support and tips from CultureLink's Volunteer Mentors
* Practice with sample quizzes

These summer sessions run EVERY TUESDAY from July 16th to September 17th (6pm-8:30pm).

Please consider attending all the sessions because the instructor will cover different aspects of the book, Discover Canada: The Rights and Responsibilities of Citizenship, which will be provided for by the instructor.

NOTE: Tuesdays classes for Tuesdays August 6th and September 3rd are located in Room B1 on the lower level (instead of the Discussion Room).

For more information, call (416) 393-7085 OR contact Victor Gomes by email at vgomes@culturelink.ca or call Victor at (437) 288-3027.

CultureLink Settlement and Community Services is solely responsible for the protection of personal information collected through the program registration process.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Introduction to Writing in the Romance Genre
description:
Romance is a billion-dollar industry, and the romance genre outsells all other genres - by far. With subgenres like historical romance, fantasy romance, contemporary romance and paranormal romance, there is so much room for diversity of stories and voices. In this workshop Farah will define the romance genre, discuss tropes, themes and genre requirements, and finally give you some tools to help craft a page turning, swoony romance novel. This workshop would be of value to beginner to intermediate romance writers, or writers of other genres who want to include a romance subplot into their story. Q&A follows.

Join writer Farah Heron, Toronto Public Library's Fall 2024 Writer in Residence, as she engages you in this fascinating and informative talk on romance fiction at North York Central Library.

This event is part of TPL's Writer in Residence program. The residency is designed to encourage exchanges between the author and the community and the Writer in Residence will be delivering workshops and evaluating manuscripts of aspiring writers who submit their work.

To register, please call 416-395-5639.

Accessibility
Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Evening Book Club
description:

August Book Club Title - A Man Called Ove by Fredrik Backman

description:

Use Ruler tools such as Indent
Use the Format Painter
Use Spelling and Grammar check
Learn how to save your resume as a PDF
Use templates to start building your own resume

Space is limited. To register, please visit or call Riverdale Library at
416-393-7720.

title: How poetry saved me and others: from Software Engineer to Poet Laureate
description:
Mississauga's first Poet Laureate (2015-17), Anna Yin (Seven Nights with the Chinese Zodiac), shares how poetry found her and opened her to a broader world. She discusses how she has used poetry and translations as mirrors and windows to help cross-cultural exchanges. She also shows how she applies her computer skills from her background in I.T. with photos and films for her workshops to grow the international audience in poetry and humanity.

Anna won the 2005 Ted Plantos Memorial Award, two MARTYs, two USA scholarships and grants from OAC and CCA. Her poems/translations have appeared at Queens Quarterly, ARC Poetry, New York Times, China Daily, CBC Radio, Literary Review of Canada etc. Her 10th book will be published by Frontenac Press in 2025.

This program is generously funded with support of the Canada Council through the Writer's Union of Canada

Register in person or by phone at 416-396-8890.

Small Meeting Room, 2nd floor

The Community Connections Program of the Centre Francophone du Grand Toronto and the Toronto Public Library invite you to join the bilingual conversation circle which will take place on Wednesday September 18 from 4 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. at the City Hall library.

Come join us for the bilingual conversation circle! The bilingual conversation circle is a good opportunity for French-speakers to practice English and for English-speakers to improve their French. It is a great chance to meet new people and to explore networking opportunities.

The number of places is limited. Please register sur Eventbrite.
You can book a spot for this circle from August 19.

For more details about the bilingual conversation circles, please contact us at programmesenfrancais@tpl.ca or by calling City Hall library at 416-393-7650.

title: Learn about subsidized housing in Toronto
description:
Housing Help Centre staff will be hosting free in-person workshops at Scarborough Civic Centre library.

Join a session to learn:
- about subsidized housing options like Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI)
- how to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website
- how to manage your account

To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
- a valid email address;
- proof of Canadian status for all household members; and
- your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment.

title: Catherine Hernandez: Behind You
description:
Award-winning author Catherine Hernandez discusses her new novel about a city gripped by terror, a young girl facing danger closer to home, and chilling memories that last a lifetime.

Behind You is inspired by a horrifying chapter in Canadian history and follows fictional characters terrorized by a fictional perpetrator.

Alma is a Filipina woman who works as a film editor for a cheesy True Crime series featuring the most notorious killers of the 20th century, called Infamous. On the surface she seems to live a good life with her wife Nira and teenage son, Mateo. But there is so much left unsaid.

It's not until Infamous' last episode features the Scarborough Stalker that she remembers coming of age while the serial rapist and killer was attacking women and girls in Scarborough in the late 80s and early 90s.

What unfolds are two storylines: In the past, young Alma watches an entire city become consumed with a manhunt for an elusive, terrifying suspect, while she herself is in jeopardy from closer corners. In the present, adult Alma must come to terms with her own ideas of consent to stop her son's dangerous behaviour towards his girlfriend.

Catherine Hernandez speaks with writer and cultural critic Stacy Lee Kong about Behind You, a moving story of one girl's resilience into adulthood and a chilling portrayal of the insidiousness of rape culture.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Catherine Hernandez
Stacy Lee Kong

Read more:
Behind You
Scarborough

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

It is also part of our Asian Heritage series, generously supported by TD Bank Group, through the TD Ready Commitment.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Willowdale Community Legal Services - Public Legal Education Workshop
description:
Join us every third Thursday of the month for free legal
assistance! During each session, they provide an overview of
specific areas of law such as clinic provided services, tenant
rights, social assistance, disability benefits, welfare, old age
security benefits, children benefits, etc.

Learn about sponsoring a spouse, partner,
dependent children, parents or grandparents. We
will cover who can apply, how to apply, forms to
fill out, fees and processing times.

Drop-In. No registration required.
