title: September Movie - Romancing the Stone
description:
Enjoy a night at the movies! Join us for a free movie on the big screen in our accessible theatre. Start time is 6:00 pm. Drop in. All are welcome!

Romancing the Stone
1984 - 106 min - AA - Comedy; Adventure

When Joan Wilder, a writer of best-selling Gothic romances, journeys to Columbia in a desperate attempt to rescue her sister from kidnappers, she finds herself in the midst of a "real life" adventure far more exciting than any of her published fantasies!

Starring Kathleen Turner, Michael Douglas and Danny DiVito.

If you live with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Computers for Beginners: Use Email-Gmail
description:
The Computers for Beginners Series are introductory classes on how to use the mouse, keyboard, web, Google Search and Maps, and Windows 10. They are geared towards absolute beginners with little to no computer experience. Each class will build on skills learned in previous classes to help you become more comfortable using the laptop computer.

Registration required. Please call (416) 393-7692 to register.

title: The Billionaire Murders: The Mysterious Deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman
description:
Toronto Star investigative journalist Kevin Donovan chronicles the unsettling story of the infamous Barry and Honey Sherman murder case which occurred in Toronto in 2017 from the beginning, drawing on interviews with family members, friends, and colleagues. Donovan sheds new light on the Shermans' lives and the disturbing double murder while discussing his best-selling book, The billionaire murders : the mysterious deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman.

Registration required.
To register, please visit in-person or by calling the branch at 416-393-7706.

description:
Rekindle your enjoyment of creating art by painting in a relaxed atmosphere. The Acrylic Painting workshop is intended to provide a reintroduction to art with acrylic paint and sometimes other mediums. Participants will get a hands-on step-by-step approach and instruction on a particular painting or free-flow art in a relaxing, creative environment
Age 16+

title: Keep Calm & Carry Yarn Crafting Circle
description:
Come craft with us! TRL is hosting a once a month crafting circle where you can create and chat. Whether its crochet, knitting, embroidery or sewing; connect with fellow craftspeople as you work on your project. All skill levels are welcome.

*Note* We do supply yarn and crochet hooks/knitting needles for those that need them during the program.

title: Yes, You Can Win Scholarships!
description:
Yes, You Can Win Scholarships: Busting Common Myths to Help Students and Parents Pay for Postsecondary Education

Scholarships are accessible to more students than what is commonly believed. Here is the most important thing: scholarships can be a game changer for a students career, their financial well-being, and their or their familys bank account. Scholarships, grants, and bursaries are available for high school, college, and university students, and you dont need perfect grades!

Christopher Grafos, founder of BridgesEDU Scholarships will share a presentation which will help empower attendees with information to find and win money for postsecondary education.

No registration required.

title: Excel Basics 2: Do More with Your Data
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.


In this second session you will:

- Practice data entry and formatting

- Manipulate rows and columns

- Create and copy simple formulas

- Convert data to a Table then sort and filter

- Create your first chart


Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.


Pre-requisites: Excel Basics Part 1 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]

Registration Required. To register, please call 416-396-8890 or speak to staff at the library.

title: National Film Board of Canada Screening of "WaaPaKe (Tomorrow)"
library: Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre
description:
We will recognize National Truth and Reconciliation Day early by kicking off our NFB Documentary Screening Series with "WaaPaKe (Tomorrow)."
For generations, the suffering of residential school Survivors has radiated outward, impacting Indigenous families and communities. Dr. Jules Arita Koostachin's deeply personal documentary "WaaPaKe (Tomorrow)" moves beyond intergenerational trauma, with an invitation to unravel the tangled threads of silence and unite in collective freedom and power.

Drop in. No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: All You Ever Wanted to Know About Black Holes
description:
So you've heard of the mysterious black hole, but what is it exactly??

Dr. Ilana MacDonald, of the Dunlap Institute for Astronomy and Astrophysics, is here to give us a crash course on black holes! Come and learn more about what black holes are, how they form and where you can find them with us.

Registration is required. Please call 416-393-7666 or visit the branch to register.

No raw fish is used. Ingredients are free of gluten, nuts and dairy.

description:
Join us to discuss Lucy Maud Montgomery's classic novels at the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books. In celebration of her 150th birthday, the book club will be reading novels from across Montgomery's career. We welcome new readers and avid Montgomery fans alike! Dates and books are listed below.

Thursday September 19 - Anne of Green Gables
Thursday October 17 - Emily of New Moon
Thursday November 21 - The Blue Castle

No registration is required and everyone is welcome.

Book club meetings will take place in the Osborne Collection on the fourth floor of Lillian H. Smith Branch.

If you need help getting a copy of the book or have any questions, please contact us at osstaff@tpl.ca or 416-393-7753.

description:

In this workshop we will look at Mango and Gale Courses. Mango is a language-learning resource. Gale Courses offer instructor-led online courses on a wide variety of topics.

title: Book Discussion: There Is No Blue
description:
Join us to discuss the latest book by Canadian author, Martha Baillie. Discussion will be led by library staff, and we will be joined by the author, who will read a passage and answer questions.

Martha Baillie's richly layered response to her mother's passing, her father's life, and her sister's suicide is an exploration of how the body, the rooms we inhabit, and our languages offer the psyche a home, if only for a time.

Regular print copies will be available for pickup at the branch beginning Wed Sep 21. "There Is No Blue" is also available as Audiobook, eBook, and eAudiobook.

Drop-in, no registration. Call 416-393-7653 for more info.

title: Excel Basic 1
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for absolute beginners with no Excel experience.

In this first session you will:

- Learn the basic function and design of Excel files
- Practice basic data entry for text, numbers, and basic functions: Sum, AutoSum and Average
- Create and save your first workbook and worksheets

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Excel at a basic level.

title: Moving Stories: art-based movement class for older adults
description:
Tiger princess dance projects, a non-profit contemporary dance company, brings you a free custom designed arts-based movement class for older adults. Join Artistic Director Yvonne Ng and her team of professional artists in a fun, healthy, and exciting arts program, Moving Stories.

These free classes offer an introduction into the enriching world of art and creativity through movement and music. These activities have proven to improve circulation, retain joint mobility, promote mental stimulation, improve posture and coordination, and build strength and balance.

- No previous movement experience required.
- Suggested Age: 60 +
- Go at your own pace, modifications encouraged
- Exercises can be modified for seated movement and/or standing

Please register in person or by calling 416-396-3835. By registering, you are signing up for all of the dates.

title: Aging Well in Toronto Program Series: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
description:
The program is designed to provide older adults and seniors, residing in Toronto, with the information they require to age well. In partnership with Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community, this monthly program series is will run from July - December 2024.

Participants will engage in workshops providing information and tools related to the following topics:

Session 2: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
Tuesday August 13th, 10:30am - 11:30am. Room 1

In this workshop, participants will learn how to protect their assets from frauds and scams targeted towards seniors. With a guest speaker from the Toronto Police Services Frauds and Scams Unit, seniors will learn how to identify scams and how to protect themselves from becoming a victim. In addition, our guest speaker will provide participants with next steps should they become a victim of fraudulent activity.

Upcoming Program Dates (Room 1):

Session 3: Elder Abuse - Friday, September 20, 2024 - Room 101
Session 4: Mental Health and Cognition - Friday, October 25, 2024
Session 5: Physical Health and Exercise - Tuesday, November 19, 2024
Session 6: Aging in Place and Other Options - Tuesday, December 17, 2024

Registration is encouraged via Eventbrite. Drop-ins are welcome. For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

title: Financial Literacy Session: Fraud Protection
description:
Understand fraud and how to protect yourself from becoming a victim.

Learning Objectives:
- What fraud is and how it works
- Identify the signs of fraud and how to act on suspicions
- Learn about top three scams
- Why vulnerable people are targeted
- What to do if you are a victim of fraud

Drop-In. No registration required.

title: Learn about subsidized housing in Toronto
description:
Housing Help Centre staff will be hosting free in-person workshops at the Bloor/Gladstone Branch

Join a session to learn:
- about subsidized housing options like Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI)
- how to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website
- how to manage your account

To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
- a valid email address;
- proof of Canadian status for all household members; and
- your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment

To learn more and register for a session please visit the Access to Housing page: https://tinyurl.com/3d46z64w

Dates and Times for Sessions are:
Sept 12, 1pm - 3pm
Sept 19,1pm - 3pm, 4pm - 6pm
Sept. 20,1pm - 3pm, 4pm - 6pm
Sept. 21, 11am - 1pm

title: Kombucha Brewing Workshop
description:
Kombucha is an amazing and naturally fizzy elixir, made with tea and loaded with bioavailable probiotics (the good kind of bacteria) and B-vitamins. It's also simple to brew on your own, not to mention cost-effective.

Learn about the origins of Kombucha and how to brew different flavours at home in this hands-on workshop that also shares the benefits of fermentation and value of probiotics.


Limited Space. Registration Required.
Please register in person or call Barbara Frum Branch at 416-395-5440.

description:

description:

This class is for beginners but assumes you have mouse navigation and keyboarding skills.

The recommended age for participation is 13+. Computers will be provided.

- Review basic keyboard functions
- Use the mouse for basic Windows functions
Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a computer mouse at a basic level and will be able to go online for additional practice.

description:
An online class on Microsoft Word for beginners with some experience with Word. Practice your Word skills while creating a simple resume.

In this class you will:

- Practice advanced formatting using Ruler Tools and Format Painter
- Use Grammar and Spell check tools
- Practice using Words built-in resume templates
- Save documents in other formats such as PDF
- Upon completion of this class students will be able to create an organized simple resume and access resume templates with additional style options.

Pre-requisites:
- A basic working knowledge of Word is required.
- Keyboarding and mouse skills are required.

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

description:
Looking for something to do after school? Come out to
our After School Club and learn new things, make stuff, meet other kids, have a light snack, and have fun! Registration for September After School Club begins Tuesday, September 3rd. To register, please visit the branch or call 416-393-7717.Registration is required per program.

Snacks are handed out at 3:45; program begins at 4:00pm

Snacks are offered during the After School Club for participants. Food may contain or have come into contact with common allergens. Ingredient lists will be available. Snacks are generously supported, in part, by donors.

*This club runs weekly on Fridays from 4-5pm starting on September 20th to December 13th. On September 20th we will be exploring SNAP circuits. For ages 6-12.*Please note that the After School Club does not occur on PA days.

September 20th: SNAP circuits: Build exciting electronic projects with SNAP CIRCUITS! Have fun learning about circuitry and electricity. Turn on a light, spin a motor, activate a speaker and choose from over 300 different projects.
October 4th: DASH robots, Learn to code with robots! Complete challenges, get creative and explore programming with Dash.
October 18th: Painting Fall Landscapes. Celebrate Fall and paint or draw a lovely Landscape.
October 25th: SPHERO robots, Children will be introduced to block coding and be guided to complete various activities with Sphero BOLT robots
Nov 1st: Sugar Skulls, children will decorate, and design their own sugar skulls with various material to celebrate the Day of the Dead
More programs TBA soon.

title: De Gauguin  Matisse  Tahiti et en Ocanie ; horizons lointains
description:
A plusieurs semaines de bateau de l'Europe, l'Ocanie fascine les artistes, et ce depuis les expditions et les rcits (1771) de Bougainville, auparavant pass par le Canada, et le clbre roman de Bernardin de Saint-Pierre, Paul et Virginie (1788), dont l'action se passe l'le de La Runion. Lass par la vie parisienne dans laquelle il ne trouve dcidment pas sa place, en qute d'un hypothtique Paradis terrestre, Gauguin y effectue deux voyages, en 1891, puis dfinitivement en 1895. Adoptant le mode de vie des Maoris, il transpose leurs croyances en des tableaux lgiaques, o se mlent lgendes tahitiennes et symboles chrtiens. Marchant sur ses pas, Matisse se rend en 1930 Tahiti o il rencontre le cinaste expressionniste allemand Murnau. bloui par la splendeur des paysages, Matisse en revient mtamorphos ; les impressions colores qu'il en rapporte seront la source de ses ultimes chefs-d'oeuvre.

La confrence est propose par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art et fait partie d'un premier cycle intitul Les artistes voyageurs ; nouveaux horizons, nouvelle inspiration !

En collaboration avec Alliance Franaise de Toronto.

Crdit photo : Margot Richard.


****

title: Write Better Faster with Maaja Wentz
description:
Participants will use discussion and reflection to diagnose their areas of challenge and opportunity to write more efficiently. Maaja will demonstrate the advantages of writing in the zone, as well as the many impediments created by modern life that block this kind of creative flow state.

This is a responsive workshop in which the challenges expressed by the participants will determine the proportion of time spent learning techniques of journaling, writing in the zone, training for and hitting word count goals, using community and shared challenges to inspire and motivate, and managing ideas to reduce distraction for maximum creative potential.


Presenter Bio: Maaja Wentz is an award-winning writer of chilling mysteries and quirky speculative fiction. The Wattpad serial, Feeding Frenzy: Curse of the Necromancer, won a Wattpad award and became Maajas first novel. The Sequel, Double Dead Magic, is a cold case murder mystery featuring witchy power struggles and a dragon shifter detective.

Maajas unusual murder story, Inside of a Dog, appeared in Ellery Queen Mystery Magazine.

Maaja holds a B. A. in French and English literature, an M.A. in Comparative literature, and a B. ed. She teaches French and works as an elementary school librarian in Toronto, Canada.
www.maajawentz.com


To register, call York Woods Library at (416) 395-5980

title: Indigenous Storytelling: Relationships, Resilience, Resurgence, Reconcili-action
description:
Join Indigenous activist, educator, storyteller, artist, and dancer, Jim Adams, as he shares how renewing our relationship with Four R's (Relationships, Resilience, Resurgence, Reconcili-action) can help bring balance to the course of humankind's path.

Drop-in. No registration required.

Jim is of mixed Indigenous and settler heritage and has a BFA, MFA, and M.Ed in Urban Indigenous Education. He seeks to make sense of the world through the use of story, music and movement. His greatest teachers and most profound understandings have come from relationships he has had with traditional Knowledge Keepers, Elders and his own children.

title: Excel Basics 2: Do More with your Data
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.

In this second session you will:

- Practice data entry and formatting
- Manipulate rows and columns
- Create and copy simple formulas
- Convert data to a Table then sort and filter
- Create your first chart

Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.

Pre-requisites: Excel Basics Part 1 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills are required.

This class will be conducted online using Webex.
Details and practice files will be emailed to registered attendees.

title: A Fascinating Tour of the Universe with Tom Vassas
description:
Are you interested in space and time travel? Join us with Astronomer, Tom Vassos, as he utilizes cutting-edge astrophysics to explore the fascinating world of time machines and the intersection of imaginative Hollywood movies with the reality of time travel.

Tom Vassos has devoted thousands of hours researching his lifelong passions astronomy and space exploration. He is an astronomer, university instructor, founder of Cosmologists Without Borders, member of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada and author of several books in The Inspiring Universe Collection series. Mr. Vassos is a science communicator who is frequently invited as a guest expert on radio and television and he is the Astronomer-in-Residence for Holland America and Royal Caribbean cruise lines.


Tickets will be available on Thursday, September 1, 2024 at 9:00 am.

For more information, contact
Toronto Reference Library - Business, Science and Technology
789 Yonge Street
P: 416-393-7149
E: trlbus@tpl.ca

title: katherena vermette: real ones
description:
Award-winning author katherena vermette discusses her new novel, a heartrending story of two Michif sisters who must face their past trauma when their mother is called out for false claims to Indigenous identity.

In real ones, we meet June and her sister, lyn. Lyn has her pottery artwork, her precocious kid and the uncertain terrain of her midlife to keep her mind, heart and hands busy. June, a Mtis Studies professor, yearns to uproot from Vancouver and move. With her loving partner, June decides to buy a house in the last place on earth she imagined she'd end up: back home in Winnipeg with her family.

But then into lyn and June's busy lives a bomb drops: their estranged and very white mother, Renee, is called out as a "pretendian." Under the name (get this) Raven Bearclaw, Renee had topped the charts in the Canadian art world for winning awards and recognition for her Indigenous-style work.

The news is quickly picked up by the media and sparks an enraged online backlash. As the sisters are pulled into the painful tangle of lies their mother has told and the hurt she has caused, searing memories from their unresolved childhood trauma, which still manages to spill into their well curated adult worlds, come rippling to the surface.

katherena vermette speaks with Elamin Abdelmahmoud, host of CBC Radio's COMMOTION, about real ones, an energetic, probing and ultimately hopeful story that pays homage to the long-fought, hard-won battles of Michif (Mtis) people to regain ownership of their identity and the right to say who is and isn't Mtis.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
katherena vermette
Elamin Abdelmahmoud

Read more:
real ones
The Strangers
Son of Elsewhere

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

It is also part of our Indigenous Celebrations series, generously supported by TD Bank Group, through the TD Ready Commitment.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. We'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

description:

Create 3D models using sketches, extrusions, and other geometric operations.
Design parts, assemblies, and complex structures.

Prepare your designs for additive manufacturing or subtractive processes.

description:
Python is an open source programming language that is used for creating web applications, web content, mathematics and system scripting. title: Author Talk:Carol Williams-Wong |Letters To My Grandchildren
description:
Join Carol Williams-Wong, as she discusses her personal history in Letters to My Grandchildren: Memoirs of a Dragon Lady.

Born to Hakka Chinese immigrants in Jamaica, Carol Wong discusses her early life in the West Indies, and her journey in becoming a Hakka Chinese Dragon Lady in Toronto. While the letters serve to record her family history, they also highlight life in Jamaica from 1941-1977 and the changing socio-political events from that era.

Q&A to follow Author Talk.

Books will be available for sale and signing.

Drop-In. No Registration Required.

Please call (416) 393-7697 or speak with staff at the desk for more information.

title: Unpacking Truths in  Truth and Reconciliation
description:
In this month of learning about historical and contemporary relations between Indigenous Nations and the nation state of Canada, there are many painful truths that need to be unpacked. How can we learn together to unpack and make these relationships more relevant - as individuals and as a society? How can we change how we listen and learn to move forward together with Peace, Friendship and Mutual Respect?

Join Dr. Ruth Green as she storytells about Treaty relations and responsibilities to the Lands and the people that have been caretakers of the territory known as Tkaronto since time immemorial.

Drop-in program. No registration required.

***

Dr. Ruth Green is an Associate Professor in the School of Social Work at York University. Ruth uses She/her pronouns and identifies as an urban Indigequeer woman. She is an activist turned accidental academic. Ruth is a citizen of the Haudenosaunee Confederacy, from the Kanien'keha:ka Nation and is a member of the Turtle Clan. She also acknowledges her paternal Celtic heritage. Ruth is currently the Special Advisor to the Dean of Liberal Arts and Professional Studies on Indigenous Issues. She has a PhD from OISE in Adult Education and Community Development, an MSW and a BSW from X University, now known as Toronto Metropolitan University.

***

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Tuesday Night Book Club
description:
If you love reading, please join us on Tuesday, August 27 at 6:30 p.m. to enjoy a snack and talk about our book of the month, Kitchen Confidential: adventures in the culinary underbelly, Anthony Bourdain's funny, shocking memoir about life in the culinary trade. You can get a copy at Maria A. Shchuka Library while supplies last. Inquire at the first floor circulation desk.
There are also digital copies available through Overdrive, which you can find on the Toronto Public Library's website. Ask library staff to show you how to borrow eBooks. Or, you can place a hold on the book yourself. All are welcome!

Upcoming book club meetings:

Tuesday, August 27: Kitchen confidential: adventures in the culinary underbelly by Anthony Bourdain.

Tuesday, September 24: Foster by Claire Keegan.

It is a hot summer in rural Ireland. A child is taken by her father to live with relatives on a farm, not knowing when or if she will be brought home again. In the Kinsellas' house, she finds an affection and warmth she has not known and slowly, in their care, begins to blossom. But there is something unspoken in this new household--where everything is so well tended to--and this summer must soon come to an end.

For more information, please call: 416-394-1000.

description:
Edible History of Toronto Description:
Toronto is a global culinary capital, home to iconic food brands and restaurants, from Caf Diplomatico to Mr. Christies Cookies, but how did Toronto earn its reputation as a foodie haven? Join culinary historian Dr. Laura Carlson on a mouth-watering journey through Torontos food history. Bring your appetite and your stretchy pants for a virtual taste of past and present Toronto. Registration is required. To register, please call North York Central Library, Society and Recreation Department at 416-395-5660. title: Excel Basics Part 2:  Do More With Your Data
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for beginners with little or no Excel experience. Build on your basic Microsoft Excel skills and learn to use Excel data effectively.
In this second session you will:
- Practice data entry and formatting
- Manipulate rows and columns
- Create and copy simple formulas
- Convert data to a Table then sort and filter
- Create your first chart
Upon completion of this class students will be able to get more from their data using tables, filters and charts.
Pre-requisites: Excel Basics Part 1 or equivalent knowledge. Basic mouse and keyboard skills required.
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]
Please register by calling the User Education Department at 416-393-7209.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Connect with fellow craftspeople as you work on your project. We will have some supplies available for beginners, but please feel free to bring your own. Drop-in; no registration required.

description: This Book Club meets on the fourth Wednesday of the month. This month's title is "Far Cry" by Alissa York. Register with staff.

title: Armchair Travel Tanzania: Trek the Snows of Kilimanjaro & Beyond
description:
After a successful summit of Kilimanjaro (elevation 5895 metres/19,341) - the roof of Africa - in more snow than the tallest freestanding mountain has received in 20 years, Lola travels to the Serengeti by airplane, which she gets to fly. After a fabulous 4-day safari, we fly to the exotic Spice Island of Zanzibar, a former Omani sultanate.

Lola Reid Allin is a Commercial Airline Transport Pilot, flight instructor, SCUBA Dive Master, and an award-winning author and photographer whose work has appeared in many notable publications (in print & online) including National Post, Globe & Mail, and National Geographic.

Drop in. No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: PowerPoint Basics
description:
Pre-requisites: Some computer experience is required; beginner mouse and keyboard skills required.

In this class you will:
-Create a PowerPoint presentation
-Choose a design
-Use a slide layout and edits
-Insert image
-Delete and reorder slides
-Incorporate transitions and run a slideshow
-Open, close, and save a PowerPoint presentation

Space is limited. To register, please visit or call Riverdale Library at 416-393-7720.

title: PowerPoint 2
description:
Create a more sophisticated PowerPoint 2019 presentation with more advanced features.

In this session you will:

- Insert and format tables, simple charts, and SmartArt graphics
- Insert a screenshot or video
- Add Speaker notes and Print presentations

Upon completion of this class students will be able to enhance their PowerPoint presentations with audiovisual elements and speaker notes.

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 or equivalent experience. Basic keyboarding and mouse skills required.

To register call 416-393-7746

title: Career Pivoting and Upskilling
description:
In today's rapidly changing job market, the ability to pivot and upskill is more important than ever. This workshop will guide you through the process of identifying your transferable skills, exploring new career paths, and acquiring the necessary skills to make a successful transition. Learn how to stay competitive by continuously learning and adapting to new opportunities and discover practical steps to achieve your career goals.

Facilitated by Career Coach in Residence Kadine Cooper.


The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener and Google Canada.

title: Author visit with Mark Creedon
description:
Join us as we host local author Mark Creedon in a short reading and discussion of his book, Caught Between Two Devils.
Based on the real-life experiences of Antanas Paskevicius, his wife Jadwyga, and his sister Maria. In April of 1944, their lives were forever altered when they were sent to a work camp in northeast Germany where they struggled for ten months. Despite the risk of betrayal, torture, and death, they managed to stage a daring escape from the work camp, stealing a Wehrmacht truck in February 1945 and, along with other prisoners, fleeing the camp and heading for Bavaria.

Registration required. Please call 416-394-5270 to register or visit the Eatonville Branch.

title: Why It's Healthy to Talk About Death
description:
​Led by death doula, Dave Clark, this is a relaxed and welcoming lecture and discussion workshop to help enhance death literacy and reduce peoples fear of death by examining how death has been a natural part of living since the beginning of time. The presentation will be supported by reviewing the extensive range of services currently available to help people experience a good death.
Register on Eventbrite or by calling 416-395-5613

Questions about this event? Please call 416-395-5613.

title: Chimney Swifts in High Park
description:
The High Park Branch is a special place not only for bookworms but also for a unique and threatened urban bird species, the Chimney Swift.

Learn about these incredible little aerial acrobats, the challenges facing them, and the importance of the High Park Branch's chimney for their conservation. The presentation will also include tips on how and where to spot Chimney Swifts and what you can do to make Toronto a friendlier city for swifts.

Presented by Birds Canada as part of the Our Fragile Planet program series.

Registration is not required.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone (416) 393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Tropes and Vibes to Story and Plot
description:
Romance novels are often described like dark enemies to lovers or cozy second chance at love, but these are descriptions of the tropes and vibes of a book, not the story or plot. But how do you go from tropes or vague ideas to a workable plot? In this workshop, Farah will cover the terms tropes, story concept, and plot, and discuss brainstorming methods to take you from vague ideas to a plot outline. This workshop is geared towards romance writers but would be of value to all writers who want to go from story idea to plot. Q&A follows.

Join writer Farah Heron, Toronto Public Library's Fall 2024 Writer in Residence, as she engages you in this fascinating and informative talk on romance fiction at North York Central Library.

This event is part of TPL's Writer in Residence program. The residency is designed to encourage exchanges between the author and the community and the Writer in Residence will be delivering workshops and evaluating manuscripts of aspiring writers who submit their work.

To register, please call 416-395-5639.

title: Memory and Aging: What's Normal, What's Not, and What You Can Do About It
description:
Dr. Nicole Anderson of Baycrest Health Sciences discusses how memory changes as we age, what is considered "normal" and when to be concerned. Learn how health and lifestyle factors can affect memory, and about strategies that can be used to improve it.

Registration is required. Please call the branch at 416-395-5710.

title: Marissa Stapley: The Lightning Bottles
description:
Bestselling author Marissa Stapley joins us to discuss hew new novel, The Lightning Bottles, a spellbinding story of rock 'n' roll and star crossed love -- about grunge era musician Jane Pyre's journey to find out what really happened to her husband and partner in music, who abruptly disappeared years earlier.

In conversation with Elamin Abdelmahmoud.

Q & A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Marissa Stapley
Elamin Abdelmahmoud

Read more:
The Lightning Bottles
Lucky

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Librarys new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

Topics discussed include Themes; Settings; What's behind the story?; Aging; Male friendship; 1920's Paris; and more.

A Q&A follows a short reading from the novel.

title: SP Book Club
description:
Discuss diverse and inclusive titles from a variety of genres on the fourth Thursday of every month!

This month we will be discussing Crying in H Mart by Michelle Zauner.
A powerful memoir from the author about growing up Korean-American, losing her mother, and forging her own identity. A story full of family, food, grief, and endurance, told with humor and heart. We follow Michelle as she navigates the various aspects of her identity, how she feels distant from her Korean side, and how she later reclaims the gifts of taste, language, and history her mother had given her.

Pick up a physical copy at the branch before the meeting, or find copies through our website in various formats. Registration is required and begins August 22, 2024.

Please call 416-393-7666 or visit the branch to register.

title: Engaging your Local School Trustee: What you need to know
library: Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre
description:
School Boards are an important elected part of our municipal level government. Many of us may not think about this role until we are casting our ballots for our local city council and Mayor every four years.

This September, join us for "Engaging your Local School Trustee: What you need to know to engage with public education at the Toronto District School Board", an interactive conversation to build your awareness around the Toronto District School Board and the massive undertaking that sustains public education. This discussion-based session will test your knowledge through table talk discussions, myth-busting facts and through sharing lived experiences. Ask staff for a print or digital Information Kit for resources to read, watch & listen about the School Board Trustee system in Ontario.

Kaydeen is a community organizer and facilitator working in Eglinton-Lawrence for many years. As a former school Trustee candidate and current ward 8 representative at the Parent Involvement Advisory Committee (PIAC), a TDSB statutory advisory committee, Kaydeen is committed to equitable access to education for all.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Sept 26 - "The Librarianist" by Patrick deWitt
Oct 31 - "The Memory Police" by Yōko Ogawa
Nov 28 - The Lighthouse Keepers Daughter by Hazel Gaynor
Jan 30 - "Horse" by Geraldine Brooks

This is a drop-in program. Please speak to staff at the reference desk on the first floor or call 416-395-5672 for more information.

title: Haroon Siddiqui: My Name is not Harry
description:
Veteran Toronto Star editor Haroon Siddiqui, brown and Muslim, has spent a life on the media front lines, covering conflicts both global and local, and tracked rising xenophobia. In his recently released memoir, My Name is not Harry, Siddiqui traces his journey from India to Canada; And his extraordinary career that took him from warzones to the corridors of power in Canada.

Upon arriving in Canada in the late 1960s, Siddiqui did what many newly arrived immigrants would not dare do - he refused to change who he was. It was this unabashed self-confidence and sense of dignity that made him a champion of multiculturalism and a pioneer of cross-cultural journalism. And as the world started to become increasingly Anti-Muslim after 9/11, Siddiqui was one of the first Canadian journalists to interrogate the real motivations behind "the war on terror".

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:

Haroon Siddiqui
Denise Balkissoon

Read:

My Name is Not Harry

***

This event is part of our signature On Civil Society series, where we host local and international authors, activists and academics in conversation about the most critical topics of our time. Generously supported in part by Chris M. Reid.

This event is also part of our new programming series, Islamic History and Culture. Many key events associated with this series in our inaugural year were created in collaboration with the Aga Khan Museum.

By providing a platform for learning, discussion, and celebration, we hope to foster a greater understanding and appreciation of the Islamic communities' invaluable contributions to our shared history and identity.

Join us in celebrating the diversity that strengthens our community and makes our city a more vibrant and inclusive place for all.

The Aga Khan Museum is a presenting and collaborative partner on Islamic History and Culture.


***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Jack Rabinovitch Reading Room, located on the fourth floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

description:
Tiger princess dance projects, a non-profit contemporary dance company, brings you a free custom designed arts-based movement class for older adults. Join Artistic Director Yvonne Ng and her team of professional artists in a fun, healthy, and exciting arts program, Moving Stories.

These free classes offer an introduction into the enriching world of art and creativity through movement and music. These activities have proven to improve circulation, retain joint mobility, promote mental stimulation, improve posture and coordination, and build strength and balance.

- No previous movement experience required.
- Suggested Age: 60 +
- Go at your own pace, modifications encouraged
- Exercises can be modified for seated movement and/or standing

Please register in person or by calling 416-396-3835. By registering, you are signing up for all of the dates.

title: NatureTO: Our Urban Forest
description:
Toronto has one of the largest urban forests in the world. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff for an in-library presentation on this amazing natural habitat that reaches all corners of Toronto.

Well talk about what makes the urban forest so special and share tools to explore and understand it better. Bring questions and curiosities and leave with embolden confidence and understanding of your City and the natural world that surrounds you!

Registration is not required.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. -Wednesday, September 11: Baby Food

-Friday, September 27: Reading Labels for Preschoolers

title: Too Much Noise: PA Day Puppet Show
description:
Old Peter can't stand all the sounds his home makes. The floor
squeaks, the bed creaks theres too much noise! A wise man gives Old
Peter some unusual advice and tells him to bring a donkey into his
house. Will that fix the problem?

After the puppet show, stay to make your own stick puppets so you can
re-tell the story at home.

This performance is best for ages 3-8. No registration is required.

title: The Power of Mentorship: How to Find and Utilize a Mentor
description:
Mentorship has a profound impact on personal development and future employability. This workshop will help youth participants learn about the role and benefits of mentorship, explore strategies for finding a mentor, and discover how to build a productive and meaningful mentorship experience. Whether you are looking to enhance your skills, gain insights into your desired field, or simply find guidance as you navigate your future, join this workshop to empower your future self.

Facilitated by Career Coach in Residence Shenelle Payne Cuffy.

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener and Google Canada.

Questions about online programs? Email us at programproposals@tpl.ca

Accessibility

title: Learn about subsidized housing in Toronto
description:
Housing Help Centre staff will be hosting free in-person workshops at Scarborough Civic Centre library.

Join a session to learn:
- about subsidized housing options like Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI)
- how to apply or register an existing application through the MyAccesstoHousingTO website
-how to manage your account

To apply for subsidized or RGI housing, you will need to bring:
- a valid email address;
- proof of Canadian status for all household members; and
- your 2022 or 2023 Notice of Assessment.

To learn more and register for a session, please visit the Access to Housing registration page.

title: P.A Day Movie: Kung Fu Panda 4
description:
Join us for a P.A Day family friendly movie.

After Po is tapped to become the Spiritual Leader of the Valley of Peace, he needs to find and train a new Dragon Warrior, while a wicked sorceress plans to re-summon all the master villains whom Po has vanquished to the spirit realm. 1hr 34m (Rated PG)

Children must be accompanied by a guardian.

title: COSTI- Access Housing Information Sessions
description: COSTI's housing experts will work with individuals to access and secure affordable market rent housing or subsidized housing. If you have any questions or are interested in these information sessions please come to Woodview Park on Fridays August 23 or September 13 or September 27 between 1 pm and 3 pm.  No registration is required, just drop in. For more information

title: PA Day: Solar Workshop with Relay Education
description:
Plug in the Sun is an interactive, curriculum-linked workshop focused on building the understanding of renewable energy and solar power. Participants will learn about solar photovoltaic and solar thermal systems, and how solar panels have been used in a variety of innovations. Using interactive experiments, participants will discover how angles, light colour and certain elements can affect the energy output of solar panels.

This program is intended for children aged 9-12 years.

Please register in branch or by calling (416) 393-7663.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: LinkedIn Profiles for Networking and Job Hunting
description:

title: Author Talks & Lectures: Nora Gold
description:
Join author Nora Gold for an afternoon discussion on their latest work and writing fiction, non-fiction, identity, language and culture. Nora Gold will discuss her paired novels, 'In Sickness and In Health / Yom Kippur in a Gym' as well as her work as an editor of such collections as '18 Jewish Stories.'

Please register in person or call Barbara Frum Branch at 416-395-5440.

title: Aging Well in Toronto
description:
Aging Well in Toronto is a 6-week program designed to provide older adults and seniors, residing in Toronto, with the information they require to age well. Participants will engage in workshops providing information and tools related to the following topics:

Friday, Sept 6 : Financial Freedom in Retirement
Friday, Sept 13: Frauds and Scams Against Seniors
Friday, Sept 20: Elder Abuse
Friday, Sept 27 : Mental Health and Cognition
Friday, Oct 4: Physical Health and Exercise
Friday, Oct11: Aging in Place and Other Options

Presented by Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community.

Drop in

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Come Meet Terry Fallis
description: Terry Fallis examines and explains the roots of his latest novel, A New Season, and the personal connections the author has to the story. The presentation is supported by visual and audio elements, and the author will be open to questions from participants.

title: Audio Editing with Audacity
description:
You will learn how to enhance an existing sound file and learn how to cut and splice one or more audio clips. You will also learn how to add different effects to your sound files.

description:

Drop-in. No registration required.

title: The Deorhord: An Old English Bestiary
description:
Dr. Hana Videen, an expert in Old English literature, will discuss her new book with Princeton University Press, The Deorhord: An Old English Bestiary (2024).
Dr. Videen will explain how the English language has evolved since the 7th century; even though many of the animals we encounter in everyday life have remained the same for millennia, the words we use to describe them have not, starting with the Old English word for 'animal' itself, 'deor.'
Please register at the front desk or by calling the branch at 416-395-5710.

description:

- Familiarize yourself through practice with the most essential keyboard functions (alphabet, number and symbol keys)
- Practice proper keyboarding posture
Upon completion of this class students will be able to use a keyboard at a beginner level and know how to go online for additional practice.
Pre-requisites: Computer for Beginners 1 or basic mouse skills
Format: Hands-on with demonstrations
[90 min]
Please register by calling the User Education Department at 416-393-7209.

title: PA Day Family Movie - Moana
description:
Come watch the first Moana movie before the sequel comes out!

"An adventurous teenager sails out on a daring mission to save her people. During her journey, Moana meets the once-mighty demigod Maui, who guides her in her quest to become a master way-finder. Together they sail across the open ocean on an action-packed voyage, encountering enormous monsters and impossible odds. Along the way, Moana fulfills the ancient quest of her ancestors and discovers the one thing she always sought: her own identity."

description:

Chef Sang will also share a brief history of sushi, its origins and eating etiquette. No raw fish is used. Ingredients are completely vegetarian and free of gluten, nuts and diary.

This is a ticketed event for teens. Space is limited to 15 participants. Free tickets will be handed out in the Youth Hub 30 minutes before the program begins on a first come, first served basis. If you have any questions, please contact the branch at 416-396-3975.

title: Culture Days Celebration - The Griot's Journey
description:
Celebrate life, its cycles and season, and African culture with interactive call-and-response songs and storytelling, dance and rhythmic hand drumming.

Presented by Babarinde Williams, an award-winning ethnomusicologist, multi-instrumentalist, master drummer, Griot storyteller and motivational speaker.

Through this program, audience will gain an appreciation of ancient African storytelling styles, the importance of community, and wisdom and virtues from African stories.

Please visit or call the branch to register. Drop-in is accepted dependent on space availability on the day of presentation.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:
Roa Lee will play the Gayageum, a traditional Korean instrument live at Parkdale Library. The performance will include classical, jazz, waltz and pop music performed with the 25-stringed Gayageum, as well as traditional Korean music played on the 12-stringed version.

Drop in program. No registration required.

title: About Brightening My Corner: A Memoir of Dreams Fulfilled
description:
Join us for an author talk and slide show about the adventure, love and family story of a Chinese-Canadian who recently published her memoir, Brightening My Corner: A Memoir of Dreams Fulfilled (2023, Barclay Press). Ruth Lor Malloy traveled mainly in Asia as a travel writer and volunteer, and she is the author of a dozen guidebooks on China - 1970s to 2008. She was focused on fighting racial discrimination and in 2023, York University awarded her an honorary Doctor of Laws degree for her 'tireless efforts to combat discrimination and promote equality in Canada and beyond.'

A presentation of the Society and Recreation department of the North York Central Library. No registration required.

title: Elevating Dialogue: A Writer's Workshop with Rachel McMillan
description:
Dialogue is often the strongest link to character and voice and without it, the rest of the Jenga game of a book's story can fall apart.

This workshop will inspire writers to think about using dialogue to propel action forward and even replace descriptives and plot points for a wholly immersive experience. Rachel will provide tips and tricks for writing and self-editing dialogue as well as using dialect to pack a punch for your readers and immerse them in the book's world.

The group will read samples of dialogue from a wide variety of bestselling books, and participants will work with the presenter to notice what works and what doesn't, keeping their own work in mind and determining an in-class list of brainstormed best practices.

Participants are invited to bring a sample of their own work for critique, if they feel comfortable sharing with the group.

To register for this program, please call the branch at 416-393-7717.


Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Weaving Futures
description:
Dance, Paint, Weave.
"Weaving Futures" is a 6-week workshop series led by local artist Blessyl Buan. We will journey themes of decolonization, cultural preservation and "Kapwa" (community). Engage with weaving, paint, Baybayin (ancient writing) and dance. Your creations are yours to keep and will be showcased in an exhibition and opening reception at the Morningside Branch in November.

For ages 13 and up. Register on Eventbrite - https://www.eventbrite.com/e/weaving-futures-tickets-944389032017?aff=oddtdtcreator or phone the branch at 416-396-8881

title: Travel Talk: Southern Japan
description:
Southern Japan is a great place to travel in the spring time because of its warm weather, beautiful coastline scenery, interesting historical architecture, and very good food of all kinds. Experienced travel talk presenter Chris Myers will show you photos and provide stories from his trip with his wife in April 2024. It includes their visits to Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Takayama, Kanazawa, Hiroshima, and the island of Miyajima.

This program is for adults. Drop in. No registration is required. Room 101.

title: True Crime Club
description:
Dive into the world of true crime with fellow enthusiasts as we explore real-life mysteries, investigations, and infamous cases. Investigate the case on your own using books, podcasts, or documentaries and then join us at the end of the month as we share findings, theories and insights in a respectful and engaging discussion. Whether you're a seasoned sleuth or a curious newcomer, our club offers a safe space to unravel the mysteries of the criminal mind.

For September, we will be investigating "The Highway of Tears" by Jessica McDiarmid, a poignant account of the Indigenous women and girls who have vanished or been murdered along British Columbia's notorious Highway 16. This powerful book sheds light on the heartbreaking stories behind the statistics, revealing a national crisis of violence and systemic neglect. Limited copies of the book and discussion guides are available at the 5th floor desk. Reading is encourage but not required. Everyone is welcome.

Sign up for an email reminder here: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/true-crime-club-tickets-856439923867?aff=oddtdtcreator

Prerequisites: PowerPoint Basics Part 1 and 2 or equivalent experience. Keyboarding and mouse skills required.

In this class you will:

- Use Grammar and Spell check tools
- Practice using Words built-in resume templates
- Save documents in other formats such as PDF

Upon completion of this class, students will be able to create an organized simple resume and access resume templates with additional style options.

Prerequisite: Word Basics 1 & 2 or equivalent skills. Keyboarding and mouse skills are required.

title: SR Festival Select-Colonization Road
description:
Join the Society and Recreation department of the North York Central Library in Rm. 101 for monthly screenings of fiction and non-fiction films that push the boundaries of the medium. This month's title is Colonization Road (2016) by Michelle St. John.

Synopsis: In towns throughout Ontario, there are startling reminders of the colonization of Indigenous territories and the displacement of First Nations people. Anishinaabe comedian and activist Ryan McMahon takes us to his hometown of Fort Frances and down its main drag, which is called Colonization Road. Similar streets have similar names in towns and cities across the province, direct reminders of the Public Lands Act of 1853 and its severe impact on First Nations, their treaties and their land in the name of "Canadian settlement." On his journey through Ontario, McMahon explores the history of these roads, meets with settlers in solidarity and raises significant questions about "reconciliation" and what it means to "decolonize."

Optional registration here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sr-festival-select-colonization-road-tickets-986022589107?aff=oddtdtcreator

description:
This workshop is presented by Andrew Kcomt, Knowledge Translation & Research Manager at Hope & Me: the Mood Disorders Association of Ontario.

The workshop will cover:

What is mindfulness?
Window of tolerance
Mindfulness and the brain
Mindfulness break
Managing stress and emotions
Practical resources

Free. No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:

title: Adult Afternoon Movie: Wicked Little Letters (2023)
description:
Join us every first and last Tuesday of each month for a free afternoon movie. Drop-in.

A 1920s English seaside town bears witness when people in Littlehampton--including conservative local Edith (Olivia Colman)--begin to receive letters full of hilarious profanities, rowdy Irish migrant Rose (Jessie Buckley) is charged with the crime. Suspecting that something is amiss, the town's women investigate.

R

100 minutes

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Japanese Fruit Sandwich Making with Chef Yumiko
description:
Chef Yumiko Kobayashi will provide a brief cultural history about "Furutsu Sandos", or Japanese fruit sandwiches, then lead a hands-on demonstration and workshop to make "Furutsu Sandos consisting of fresh fruit fillings, bread and whipping cream.

Spots are limited. Registration begins September 17. To register call 416-394-5330.

title: Book Club 4 Kids & Parents
description:
Share the love of reading! Kids and parents will read a pre-selected book together, and then join us on the 1st Tuesday of each month at the library to chat about the book. The book for September's meeting is The World of Pooh by A.A. Milne, a children's classic that entertains all ages. Registration is required by calling the branch at 416-394-5088. Copies of the selected book of the month are available for pickup at the front desk. Please speak with staff.

If your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services at accessibleservices@tpl.ca or phone 416-393-7099. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Building Intimacy and Strengthening Relationships in Your Writing
description:
The backbone of any romance novel is the romantic relationship. Romance novelists are skilled at showing characters fall in love with each other while the reader falls in love with the characters. In this workshop, Farah will cover techniques to show increasing emotional intimacy by focusing on both the mind and the body. Themes, character growth, and emotions will be discussed, as well as physical expressions of intimacy. This workshop would be of value to romance writers, or writers of other genres who want to improve the romantic relationships in their stories. Q&A follows.

Join writer Farah Heron, Toronto Public Library's Fall 2024 Writer in Residence, as she engages you in this fascinating and informative talk on romance fiction at North York Central Library.

This event is part of TPL's Writer in Residence program. The residency is designed to encourage exchanges between the author and the community and the Writer in Residence will be delivering workshops and evaluating manuscripts of aspiring writers who submit their work.

To register, please call 416-395-5639.

Accessibility
Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Tuesday Night Tech Support Drop-in
description:
Have questions about your tablet, phone, laptop, email or an app? Need help with ebooks or other online library services?

No registration required. This is a drop-in event, come to the library to get one-on-one tech support! Space may be limited depending on attendance.

*Longer questions may be referred to a 1 hour Book a Librarian appointment at a later date.*

*No technology repairs at this event.*

title: Seniors and Caregivers Information Fair
description:
Come chat with representatives of agencies in your community and find out how they can make your life better, at the Maria A. Shchuka Library Seniors and Caregiver Information Fair! Here are some of the things you can learn about: health services, community safety, how to protect yourself from scams, Wheel Trans, fire safety in the home, tips for managing your finances, volunteer opportunities, library services, and settlement services. A representative of Service Canada will be available to answer your questions about the Canadian Dental Care Plan, Canada Pension Plan and Old Age Security. Enjoy a refreshment and make some new friends! Please join us!

No registration required. Free, drop-in program.

For more information, please call 416-394-1000.

title: Wheeling through Toronto: A History of the Bicycle and Its Riders
description:
Cities around the world, including Toronto, are embracing the bicycle as a response to the climate crisis. This is not the first time the bicycle has come to our rescue, proving itself a loyal friend during times of crisis, including the world wars and the COVID pandemic.

In "Wheeling through Toronto, A History of the Bicycle and Its Riders", author Albert Koehl takes the audience on a 130-year ride through the rich history of the bicycle in Toronto. By understanding how we got here, we can begin mapping a way forward, one in which the potential of cycling is maximized.

Registration is required. Please call the branch at 416-395-5710.

title: An Edible History of Toronto
description:
Toronto is a global culinary capital, home to iconic food brands and restaurants, from Caf Diplomatico to Mr. Christies Cookies. But how did Toronto earn its reputation as a foodie haven? Join culinary historian Dr. Laura Carlson on a mouth-watering journey through Torontos food history. Bring your appetite and your stretchy pants for a virtual taste of past and present Toronto.

title: Resting Witch Face: In Conversation with Bianca Marais
description:
Meet Bianca Marais: novelist and author of The Witches of Moonshyne Manor. We will spend the evening getting to know more about this feminist fantasy, which uses magic and humour to battle misogyny and ageism.
In this novel, five octogenarian witches have only days to save their home from demolition. To do so, they make a deal with a powerful evil, which fractures their sisterhood and leads to a fiery confrontation with their enemies. Marais witches are women who grow into their power as they age, celebrating the value of sisterhood. Come delve into feminism, identity and power dynamics through the intrigue and drama of secrets, lies and sex!

Registration is required. Please call 416-393-7666 or visit the branch to register.

title: Fan Brothers: Unboxing Creativity
description:
Join the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books for our 17th Annual Sybille Pantazzi Memorial Lecture: Unboxing Creativity by the Fan Brothers .

The Fan Brothers - Terry, Eric, and Devin Fan are brothers, writers and artists who have been dreaming up stories and characters together since they were young. "Barnaby Unboxed!" is the follow-up to "The Barnabus Project", winner of the Governor General's Literary Award and the TD Canadian Children's Literature Award, among many other honors, and published in almost twenty languages. Terry and Eric are author-illustrators of "The Night Gardener", "Ocean Meets Sky", "It Fell from the Sky", and "Lizzy and the Cloud". Devin is a youth worker who has a passion for nature, poetry and kung fu. All three brothers live by the edge of a lake in Ontario, Canada, and daydream about stories during long walks by the water.

In October's lecture the Fan Brothers will discuss their creative process, from initial inspiration, to working on the final book. Their latest book, "Barnaby Unboxed!", is Terry and Eric's fifth book as both writers and artists, and Devin's second book. Over the course of making those books, a pattern emerged as to how they approach the creative process. Every writer and artist faces the same challenge when confronted with the blank page. Where do stories and ideas come from? As three brothers, working collectively, that challenge comes with its own unique set of hurdles, and also benefits. Sometimes, it turns out, three heads are better than one.

Fan Brothers (photo credit Michelle Quance)

Books will be available for sale by Little Island Comics at the event.

This free event will be held on the lower level of the Lillian H. Smith Branch in the Auditorium.

Doors will open at 6:00 pm and the event will start at 6:30 pm. No registration is required. Everyone is welcome.

Questions about the program? Please email us at osstaff@tpl.ca.

description:

title: After School Club: DASH robots
description:
Looking for something to do after school? Come out to
our After School Club and learn new things, make stuff, meet other kids, have a light snack, and have fun! Registration for September After School Club begins Tuesday, September 3rd. To register, please visit the branch or call 416-393-7717.

Snacks are handed out at 3:45; program begins at 4:00.Snacks are offered during the After School Club for participants. Food may contain or have come into contact with common allergens. Ingredient lists will be available. Snacks are generously supported, in part, by donors.

*This club runs weekly on Fridays from 4-5pm starting on September 20th to December 13th. On October 4th we will be exploring DASH robots. Learn to code with DASH! Complete challenges, get creative and explore programming with DASH. For ages 6-12. Registration required per program. Please call the branch at 416-393-7717 or visit. *Please note that the After School Club does not occur on PA days.

September 20th: SNAP circuits: Build exciting electronic projects with SNAP CIRCUITS! Have fun learning about circuitry and electricity. Turn on a light, spin a motor, activate a speaker and choose from over 300 different projects.
October 4th: DASH robots, Learn to code with robots! Complete challenges, get creative and explore programming with Dash.
October 18th: Painting Fall Landscapes. Celebrate Fall and paint or draw a lovely Landscape.
October 25th: SPHERO robots, Children will be introduced to block coding and be guided to complete various activities with Sphero BOLT robots
Nov 1st: Sugar Skulls, children will decorate, and design their own sugar skulls with various material to celebrate Day of the Dead
More programs TBA soon.


If your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services at accessibleservices@tpl.ca or phone 416-393-7099. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: SafeTALK
description:
This 3-hour SafeTALK workshop equips participants to become more alert to the signs of suicidal thoughts and better able to connect individuals with the necessary support. The workshop emphasizes the importance of recognizing the signs, effectively communicating with someone considering suicide, and directing them to the appropriate help and resourced.

Open to ages 16 and up, this workshop is ideal for:

- Parents and caregivers
- Family and friends
- Youth aged 16 or older
- Natural helpers and advisors
- Educators and ministers
- Health practitioners
- Justice and law enforcement professionals
- Emergency workers
- Community volunteers

Registration is required. To register, please call Sanderson Branch at 416-393-7653.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: L'exil : une question d'identits.
description:
ceux qui ont tout perdu, c'est une entre intime dans la vie d'tres qui ont reu l'ordre d'vacuer leur appartement dans l'heure, et de n'emporter qu'un seul sac. Nous sommes plongs dans une ambiance ternelle des exils provoqus par la guerre.

Avril Bnard s'interroge sur des questions essentielles : quoi tient-on le plus ? des objets ? des symboles ? Qu'est-ce qu'on ne peut pas abandonner ? Que veut-on transmettre ? Comment tout quitter ? Comment rsumer toute une vie dans un bagage ?

Nous rencontrons ces gens, nous rencontrons leurs passs, leurs identits, nous les rencontrons intimement.

Autant de sujets qui traversent ce texte saisissant par son intensit motionnelle et sa force d'vocation.

Ce premier roman ceux qui ont tout perdu a t publi en 2023 aux ditions des Instants, et reoit depuis un beau rayonnement littraire.

Lors de cette rencontre, Avril Bnard s'entretient avec Lamara Papitashvili, crivaine.

***

Cet vnement sera enregistr et va tre disponible en rediffusion via le mme lien.

****

Si vous vous considrez comme une personne handicape ou sourde et que vous avez besoin d'une mesure d'adaptation pour participer ce programme, veuillez-nous en informer le plus tt possible. title: Elizabeth Renzetti: What She Said
description:
Elizabeth Renzetti, a passionate advocate for gender equity and one of Canada's most respected journalists, joins us to discuss her new book, What She Said.

Renzetti draws upon her own life story and her years as an award winning journalist at the Globe and Mail, where her columns followed the trajectory of women's rights. Forcefully argued, accessible, and witty, What She Said explores a range of issues: the increasingly hostile world of threats that deter young women from seeking a role in public life; the use of non disclosure agreements to silence victims of sexual harassment and assault; the inadequacy of access to health care and reproductive justice, especially as experienced by Indigenous and racialized women; the ways in which future technologies must be made more inclusive; the disparity in pay, wealth, and savings, and how women are not yet socialized to be the best financial managers they can be; the imbalanced burden of care, from emotional labour to child care. What She Said is a rallying cry for a more just future.

In conversation with journalist Scaachi Khoul.

Q & A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Elizabeth Renzetti
Scaachi Koul

Read more:
What She Said
Shrewed
One Day We'll All Be Dead and None of This Will Matter

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library:

title: Ancestry Library Club
description:
For beginners. Learn basic searches to find records of your ancestors using the popular genealogy database Ancestry Library Edition. For those with little or no experience with family history.

In the first session you will:
-learn the basics of compiling a family tree
-use sample searches to explore Ancestry records for birth, marriage, death and the census
-experiment with wildcards to improve your searches

Prerequisites: Basic mouse and keyboarding skills required.

In subsequent sessions you will use what you learned to explore your own genealogy with staff available for support.

This is an in-person program. Registration begins August 20th. Please register in person or by calling the Brentwood branch at (416) 394-5240.

title: Art Journaling
description:
Art journaling is a visual-based diary where you can creatively express your ideas, thoughts, feelings, and memories through any type of art form you enjoy and can place on a page. There are endless possibilities for artistic experimentation: from collage to blackout poetry, to drawing and painting. Your journal will reflect your unique individuality. Supplies will be provided, but feel free to bring any papers and clippings you feel drawn to include. This will be a two-part program, with session one focusing on creating pages, and session two focusing on assembling your journal.

Registration required. Please call the branch to book your spot.
