title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Teen Cupcake Decoration with Chef Yumiko
description:
​Pastry Chef Yumiko Kobayashi leads this hands-on one-hour cupcak workshop where participants will each mix, pipe and decorate two cupcakes. Participants will learn primary techniques like piping with cream cheese and buttercream frosting and decorating. All ingredients to be provided and prepped by the chef. Allergen alert: Dairy and gluten.

Spots are limited. Registration begins September 24. To register call 416-394-5330.

title: Panel Discussion - New Stories and New Faces:Modern Changes in the Romance Genre
description:
The romance genre is ever changing, and the bodice rippers of the past aren't what's on shelves today. New trends in romance include the explosion of Romantasy (a blend of romance and fantasy), the inclusion of speculative elements into contemporary stories, and stories set outside major US cities. Also non-white, non-Eurocentric world views are finally entering the mainstream. In this panel discussion, Farah will speak to 3 debut authors Alina Khawaja, Kate Robb and Kay Costales about breaking into a changing genre with stories that would not have been possible before. 30 minute Q&A follows.

Join writer Farah Heron, Toronto Public Library's Fall 2024 Writer in Residence, as she engages you in this fascinating and informative talk on romance fiction at North York Central Library.

This event is part of TPL's Writer in Residence program. The residency is designed to encourage exchanges between the author and the community and the Writer in Residence will be delivering workshops and evaluating manuscripts of aspiring writers who submit their work.

To register, please call 416-395-5639.

Accessibility
Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: True Crime Club
description: This club is for those who enjoy discussing true crimes from next door to around the world. Each month we review a case and then we decide which cases we want to look into next month We investigate the cases on our own using a variety of true crime databases, podcasts, books etc. We then meet to discuss the theories and ideas around the crime with one another. We are a passionate group and always discuss cases in a respectful manner. Come and join us on the second Tuesday of the month for an intimate evening of True Crime.
otherinfo: June 11  Jack the Ripper was an unidentified serial killer active in the Whitechapel district of London, England, in 1888.

title: Python Essentials 1 Learning Circle
description:
Take a free online course in a welcoming space! This learning circle meets in-person every Wednesday at Eglinton Square Library (Toronto, Canada) from 10:30-12:00 pm, October 9 to November 13, 2024.

Participants will learn basic coding in Python computer programming, as well as general computer programming techniques and concepts.

Participants learn together in a lightly facilitated peer-supported environment. Participants are expected to attend all learning circle sessions and complete approximately 10 hours of independent course work per week.

Learners who complete the course will be able to:
- earn a digital badge
- download a certificate of completion
- receive a 20% discount for the PCEP certification exam

Questions about this program? Please contact networkingacademy@tpl.ca

Why should you learn Python?
Python is a versatile programming language used by startups and enterprises such as Google, Facebook, Dropbox and IBM. This is also the language of choices for developers who work in data science, machine learning, artificial intelligence, networking and IoTs (Internet of Things). This course will help participants learn basic coding in Python, as well as general computer programming techniques and concepts.

Python Essentials 1 curriculum aligns with Python Institute's PCEP (Certified Entry-Level Python Programmer) certification.

Accessibility

title: Excel Basics 1: Create a Simple Spreadsheet
description:
Prerequisites: Some computer experience is required; beginner mouse and keyboard skills are required.

In this class you will:
-Learn the parts of the workbook including columns, rows, cells, and the ribbon
-Learn how to create, name, save, and edit Excel worksheets
-Learn to enter data into cells
-Practice the functions, AutoSum, Sum, and Average
-Practice basic formatting features of Excel including Bold, Font Size, Align Right, and Decimal Places

Space is limited. To register, please visit or call Riverdale Library at 416-393-7720.

Please register with the YMCA Newcomer Information Centre to attend the program. Space is limited and will be given on a first-come, first-served basis. For more information, please call 416-917-6717 or email Doris.Garcia@ymcagta.org.

In partnership with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, YMCA Newcomer Information Centre & Toronto Public Library.

title: Python Essentials 1 and 2 Learning Circle
description:
Take a free online course in a welcoming space! This learning circle meets online via WebEx every Thursday morning, October 10 - December 19, 10-11:30 AM (11 sessions).

This learning circle will include beginner level concepts (Python 1) followed by intermediate level concepts (Python 2). Participants will learn basic and intermediate coding in Python computer programming.

Participants learn together in a lightly facilitated peer-supported environment. Participants are expected to attend all learning circle sessions and complete approximately 10 hours of independent course work per week.

Learners who complete the course will be able to:
- earn a digital badge
- download a certificate of completion
- receive a 20% discount for the PCEP certification exam
- receive a 50% discount for the PCAP certification exam

Questions about this program? Please contact networkingacademy@tpl.ca

Why should you learn Python?
Python is a versatile programming language used by startups and enterprises such as Google, Facebook, Dropbox and IBM. This is also the language of choices for developers who work in data science, machine learning, artificial intelligence, networking and IoTs (Internet of Things).

- Python Essentials 1 curriculum aligns with Python Institute's PCEP (Certified Entry-Level Python Programmer) certification.
- Python Essentials 2 curriculum aligns with Python Institute's PCAP (Certified Associate-Level Python Programmer) certification

Accessibility

title: Financial Literacy Session: Planning for Retirement
description:
How to effectively plan for the kind of retirement you desire.

Learning Objectives:
- Understand that government payments are not enough to fund retirement
- How to become proactive and start retirement planning early
- The benefits of:
- Using government tax deferral/saving opportunities
- Participating in company pension plans
- Non-registered investments

title: The Romance Book Club
description:
A monthly discussion on diverse and inclusive romance books. Suitable for 18+

Join us online for a lively discussion of The Dead Romantics by Ashley Poston. Copies are available in regular print at branches, or in eBook and eAudiobook format through Overdrive.

About this month's book:

Florence Day is a ghostwriter for a prolific romance author, but she no longer believes in love. Her hot, new editor won't extend her deadline so her career is as good as dead too. When she receives a call she never wanted, she must return home to bury her beloved father.
She ran far away from her hometown a decade ago. While she misses her family, she can't bring herself to stay her father is gone, but nothing has changed. Then she finds a ghost standing in the door, handsome and confused as to why he's there.

This program requires registraion. Specific instructions on how to access Jitsi Meet will be sent to all registrants 30 mins before the book club meeting.

2023
Director: Zack Russell
Running time: 75 minutes

description:

This introductory class will give participants an understanding of the layout, tools and workflow used in Da Vinci Resolve. Basic video editing techniques will be taught such as using transitions and titles, adding audio, cutting and splicing, and mastering the timeline.

Computers will be provided for this class

title: Start or Grow Your Business with Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre
description:
Owning a business is a dream for many people. Every new business starts with an idea. This interactive presentation will give an overview of how to make it happen and the opportunity to ask questions related to your business.

An advisor from Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre (TSBEC) will present an overview of information related to the business planning process, evaluating a business idea, financing, marketing planning, business structures, regulatory requirements, and more.

Toronto Small Business Enterprise Centre (TSBEC) is a City of Toronto service that provides a one-stop source to start and grow your small business.

Drop-in. Registration is not required.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. title: Culture and Technology Book Club
description:
Friday, August 16, 2024
7:00pm - 8:00pm

The Culture and Technology Book club brings readers together once a month to discuss new and classic texts that raise important questions about the way technology transforms our cultural and political lives.

This Month we read: Household Technology and the Social Construction of Housework (1984) by Bose, Bareano and Malloy
[accessible here while on TPL wifi]

Has technology made our home lives easier? In an attempt to answer this complex question, Bose, Bareano, and Malloy argue against the myth of the labour-saving appliance and instead present a more complex picture of how domestic tasks have shaped and been shaped by technologies, and in particular how this dynamic has impacted women.

Registration is encouraged. Drop-ins welcome. Book your ticket through Eventbrite.

For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

Comments, bonus reading suggestions, or want to sign up for The Culture and Technology mailing list? Send an email to naomidavies@tpl.ca. Reading chapters of some of the readings will be sent out to members ahead of time. Reach out to us if youd like a copy and havent received one.

description:

Join us for a talk by Dr. Athar Kamal (PhD Sustainable Energy; Data Modelling and Analysis Specialist) as he breaks down climate change and provides ideas for sustainability as we face the effects of climate change on the world.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Bettany Hughes: The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World
description:
Award winning historian, author and broadcaster Bettany Hughes, joins us to discuss her new book, The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World: An Extraordinary New Journey Through History's Greatest Treasures.

For generations, the Seven Wonders of the World have captured the imagination and stand as testaments to humanity's ambition and creativity. In The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, Hughes travels to each site, uncovering the latest archeological discoveries to bring these glorious monuments to breathtaking life.

In conversation with Nahlah Ayed (CBC Ideas).

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this events guests:

Bettany Hughes
Nahlah Ayed

Read more:

Venus and Aphrodite: A Biography of Desire
Istanbul: A Tale of Three Cities

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library

We are committed to making our content accessible to as many Torontonians as possible. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: The A(i), B, C's of Artificial Intelligence
description:
We are living in the Industrial Revolution 4.0 - possibly the most disruptive revolution ever. The impact of AI is ongoing and impacting our society and controlling our everyday lives more and more, making it important for people to stay informed about AI. This fast moving, multi-media and live performance session outlines the four pillars of "must knows" to make a person AI literate.

Digital Inclusion Week takes place October 7 - October 13, 2024. It is a week to raise awareness in the area of digital literacy, technology training, and thought-provoking events.

Drop-in.

title: NatureTO: Trees Around the Branch Tour
description:
The High Park Library and its neighbourhood is home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to explore the natural world on a local neighbourhood walk. Learn how to recognize different species and fun facts about their cultural and ecological importance.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver.

Please note, the tour will start and end at the High Park Library. The City of Toronto Urban Forestry tour is outside and around the neighbourhood where there may be uneven, unpaved surfaces. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). This program takes place rain or shine.

Registration is required. Please register in branch or by calling 416-393-7671 beginning August 21.


Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone (416) 393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Zehra Allibhai: Bismillah, Let's Eat!
description:
Beloved Toronto-based hijabi fitness influencer and coach Zehra Allibhai shares her first cookbook, welcoming everyone to her table and offering a new way to think about family food.

Muslims from all around the world start each meal by saying "Bismillah," which is like a short practice of gratitude. In Bismillah, Let's Eat!, health and wellness expert Zehra Allibhai invites us into her kitchen to explore cooking that is flavourful, accessible, wholesome and - above all - meant to be shared with joy.

From her healthy spin on traditional dishes such as shakshuka and chaat to sumac chicken and lamb karahi, her renowned hearty salads, and treats such as the perfect one-bowl chocolate cake, Zehra makes being in the kitchen fun, easy - and incredibly delicious!

Zehra Allibhai speaks about Bismillah, Let's Eat! and her own cooking evolution- starting in the kitchen with her Indian Kenyan family, and expanding through culinary adventures with her husband, as a mother, and as a fitness influencer.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Zehra Allibhai

Read more:
Bismillah, Let's Eat!: Fresh and Vibrant Recipes from my Family to Yours

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

It is also a part of our new programming series, Islamic History and Culture. Many key events associated with this series in our inaugural year were created in collaboration with the Aga Khan Museum.

By providing a platform for learning, discussion, and celebration, we hope to foster a greater understanding and appreciation of Muslim communities' invaluable contributions to our shared history and identity.

Join us in celebrating the diversity that strengthens our community and makes our city a more vibrant and inclusive place for all.

The Aga Khan Museum is a presenting and collaborative partner on Islamic History and Culture.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

title: Business Law 101: Starting and Growing a Business
description:
Learn the fundamentals of starting and growing a business in Ontario. Whether a sole proprietor, partnership, or corporation, we will explain the key legal concepts all business owners should know. In this presentation, we will cover the different types of business structures, important legal rules for running a business, and tips to protect your business as it grows. The presentation will be led by Samuel Michaels, a corporate lawyer who has built his own law firm and works with hundreds of businesses across Canada.

Samuel Michaels is a Toronto-based lawyer working in corporate and employment law. Samuel runs his own law firm, SM Legal, and works with small businesses, established companies, and individuals. Samuel graduated from Osgoode Hall Law School and is a veteran of Torontos legal-tech and entrepreneur communities. An advocate for legal education, Samuel also works with several access-to-justice initiatives throughout the GTA.

Registration is encouraged. Sign up here on Eventbrite. Drop-ins welcome until room capacity is reached. For more information, contact the North York Central Library, Business, Science and Technology Department (4th floor) at 416-395-5613.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Soft Skills and Workplace Expectations
description:
Prepare to enter the workforce with the crucial soft skills and mindset employers value most. In todays competitive job market, strong interpersonal skills, professionalism, and a solid work ethic are essential for success in any professional environment.

This session empowers youth job seekers to enhance their understanding of these key skills, refine their ability to articulate their skills effectively, and provide strategies for continuous improvement. Through educational content and practical tips, participants will gain insights into workplace expectations and build confidence in their ability to develop these skills over time.

Facilitated by Career Coach in Residence Shenelle Payne Cuffy with guest speaker Niroma De Zoysa.

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener and Google Canada.

title: After School Club: Painting a Fall landscape
description:
Looking for something to do after school? Come out to
our After School Club and learn new things, make stuff, meet other kids, have a light snack, and have fun! Registration for September After School Club begins on Tuesday, September 3rd. To register, please visit the branch or call 416-393-7717.Registration required per program. For ages 6-12.*Please note that the After School Club does not occur on PA days.

Snacks are handed out at 3:45; program begins at 4:00.

Snacks are offered during the After School Club for participants. Food may contain or have come into contact with common allergens. Ingredient lists will be available. Snacks are generously supported, in part, by donors.

This club runs weekly on Fridays from 4-5pm starting on September 20th to December 13th. On October 18th we will be painting a lovely Fall painting.

September 20th: SNAP circuits: Build exciting electronic projects with SNAP CIRCUITS! Have fun learning about circuitry and electricity. Turn on a light, spin a motor, activate a speaker and choose from over 300 different projects.
October 4th: DASH robots, Learn to code with robots! Complete challenges, get creative and explore programming with Dash.
October 18th: Painting Fall Landscapes. Celebrate Fall and paint or draw a lovely Landscape.
October 25th: SPHERO robots, Children will be introduced to block coding and be guided to complete various activities with Sphero BOLT robots
Nov 1st: Sugar Skulls, children will decorate, and design their own sugar skulls with various material to celebrate Day of the Dead
More programs TBA soon.


If your child lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services at accessibleservices@tpl.ca or phone 416-393-7099. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Weaving Futures
description:
Dance, Paint, Weave.
"Weaving Futures" is a 6-week workshop series led by local artist Blessyl Buan. We will journey themes of decolonization, cultural preservation and "Kapwa" (community). Engage with weaving, paint, Baybayin (ancient writing) and dance. Your creations are yours to keep and will be showcased in an exhibition and opening reception at the Morningside Branch in November.

For ages 13 and up. Register on Eventbrite - https://www.eventbrite.com/e/weaving-futures-tickets-944389032017?aff=oddtdtcreator or phone the branch at 416-396-8881

title: Picasso et la Mditerrane
description:
Au moment mme o le Cubisme est son apoge Paris, Picasso est invit par Jean Cocteau rejoindre en 1917 Serge de Diaghilev en Italie, pour prparer la nouvelle saison des Ballets Russes. Aprs un sjour Rome, Picasso se rend Naples et dcouvre les sites antiques de Pompi et d'Herculanum ; abandonnant peu peu la dconstruction gomtrique du rel, il rintroduit le model et le dgrad de ton, s'inspire de Raphal et d'Ingres, et renoue avec les sujets favoris des peintres classiques . Ces nouvelles sources d'inspiration sont l'occasion, pour Picasso comme pour son contemporain Andr Derain, d'un renouvellement fcond de leurs esthtiques. Aux austres natures mortes cubistes succdent maintenant des compositions arcadiennes o les hommes et les femmes s'panouissent dans la nature.

La confrence est propose par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art et fait partie d'un premier cycle intitul Les artistes voyageurs ; nouveaux horizons, nouvelle inspiration !

En collaboration avec Alliance Franaise de Toronto.

Crdit photo : Margot Richard.

title: Everyday Art: An Evaluation of Our Visual Literacy
description:
Grow your understanding and appreciation of art. This program aims to analyze and breakdown primary visual elements to open the eyes of non-artist individuals to visual arts. Participants learn about the attributes of primary visual elements, like dot, line, shape, and color. Visual Relations between those visual elements and Material Properties are other subjects of discussion. Throughout this program, participants may self-consciously enhance their visual literacy.

Participants are required to attend all three sessions on October 21, 23, and 24 at 2-3pm.

Registration will open 2 weeks prior to program.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:
Join us every third Monday of the month for a film screening and post discussion. In a film club, participants watch a film together and then share their reactions, emotions and thoughts. Participants will gain a deeper understanding of the film through shared experiences. Film selection includes a mix of classics, new releases and award-winning films.

title: City of the Dead: The History of Toronto's Early Cemeteries
description:
Join Virginia Van Vliet, native Cabbagetown resident, and discover the eerie history of Toronto's first cemeteries, their impact on our local communities, and some of their famous - and infamous - residents. The presentation concludes with information about how to explore these cemeteries for yourself.

Q&A period to follow the presentation.

Register in branch or by calling 416-396-3975. Held in Meeting Room.

title: Parent/Child Book Club
description:
Share the love of reading! Kids and parents will read a book together, then join us once a month at the library to chat about the book. Was it a great read? Or a total stinker? All opinions and thoughts are welcome and appreciated. For ages 9 to 12.

This is an in-person program. Space is limited to a maximum of 10 child/parent pairs. Please register in-person or by calling 416 395-5710.

title: Nalo Hopkinson: Blackheart Man
description:
Grand Master Award-winning author Nalo Hopkinson joins us to discuss her new entrancing fantasy, Blackheart Man.

The magical island of Chynchin is facing conquerers from abroad and something sinister from within. Pickens (children) are disappearing and an ancient invading army, long frozen into piche (tar) statues by island witches is stirring to life - led by the fearsome demon known as the Blackheart Man. The line between myth and history blends in this delightfully sly tale.

In conversation with Rinaldo Walcott.

Q & A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Nalo Hopkinson
Rinaldo Walcott

Read more:
Blackheart Man
Brown Girl in the Ring

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

description:
As the leaves change and nature puts on its most magnificent display, there's no better time to explore your artistic talents. Immerse yourself in the breathtaking beauty of autumn and create a stunning floral masterpiece inspired by the vibrant hues of the season. Bring autumn's rich colours and textures to life on paper as cards with the help of watercolour inks.

Leave this workshop with a completed floral piece of artwork - a stunning reminder of your artistic journey and the beauty of autumn.

title: LSP: Nobody's Perfect - Parenting Program for Newcomer Families
description:
Are you a newcomer eager to connect with other parents and learn positive ways to navigate the joys and challenges of raising children in a new environment?

Join our Parenting series of workshops which offer a supportive space where you can meet other parents , share your questions and ideas, and work together to discover effective parenting strategies. Whether you are seeking advice or simply want to connect with a community that understands you journey, our workshops will empower you with the tools and confidence to thrive as a parent in your new home. Come and be part of a welcoming group where you experiences are valued and you family's growth is nurtured!

Register now! For more information, please contact - Nina at nali@culturelink.ca or 416-931-6536

In partnership with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, CultureLink Settlement & Community Services & Toronto Public Library.

title: Memory and Aging: What's Normal, What's Not, and What You Can Do About It
description:
Dr. Nicole Anderson of Baycrest Health Sciences discusses how memory changes as we age, what is considered "normal" and when to be concerned. Learn how health and lifestyle factors can affect memory, and about strategies that can be used to improve it.

Free. No registration required.

description:

The Career Coaches in Residence program is generously supported by lead donors Azrieli Foundation and RBC Future Launch and supporting donors Linda Dagg and Kenneth Wiener and Google Canada.

title: Making Sense of Managing Your Money a Cash Chat with Ardelle Harrison
description:
These days, with so many options available, how can a person make sense of managing their money? Where can people find sound advice so they can reach their financial goals, especially if they are on their own? Regardless of your age, life stage, or financial situation it's important to be informed and learn how to make the best decision for yourself regardless of what the media and your friends may be promoting.​

Join the discussion with consumer Ardelle Harrison, co-author of the book Bank on Yourself: Why Every Woman Should Plan Financially to be Single, Even If She's Not.

To register call 416-393-7746

Participants will also get a chance to learn some simple, yet astonishing magic tricks using everyday objects.

Registration required. Please register in person at Bloor/Gladstone Branch or by phone at (416) 393-7674. *Registration starts October 1st.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Writing Romantic Comedy
description:
Romantic comedies have always been popular in movie theaters, but lately they seem to be everywhere in bookstores, too. In this workshop, Farah will delve deeply into what differentiates a rom com from a traditional romance and discuss necessary elements to a great romantic comedy. With tips on developing high-concept storylines, writing biting and witty banter, and finally layering in laugh-out-loud scenes. Most importantly, Farah will show you how to maintain the emotional romance arc that will keep your readers swooning between the belly laughs. Q&A follows.

Join writer Farah Heron, Toronto Public Library's Fall 2024 Writer in Residence, as she engages you in this fascinating and informative talk on romance fiction at North York Central Library.

This event is part of TPL's Writer in Residence program. The residency is designed to encourage exchanges between the author and the community and the Writer in Residence will be delivering workshops and evaluating manuscripts of aspiring writers who submit their work.

To register, please call 416-395-5639.

description:

description: The Novel Knitters Club also crochets and looms!  Bring your own needles and yarn, share ideas, skills or knit socially. All levels are welcome. Limited instruction available for beginners. Drop in only. No registration required.

title: Everyday Art: An Evaluation of Our Visual Literacy
description:
Grow your understanding and appreciation of art. This program aims to analyze and breakdown primary visual elements to open the eyes of non-artist individuals to visual arts. Participants learn about the attributes of primary visual elements, like dot, line, shape, and color. Visual Relations between those visual elements and Material Properties are other subjects of discussion. Throughout this program, participants may self-consciously enhance their visual literacy.

Participants are required to attend all three sessions on October 21, 23, and 24 at 2-3pm.

Registration will open 2 weeks prior to program.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Excel Basics 3: PivotTables and Conditional Formatting
description:
Prerequisites: Some computer experience is required; beginner mouse and keyboard skills are required.

In this class you will:
-Use Conditional Formatting to visualize data using rules, icon sets, and data bars
-Explore the power of PivotTables for data summary and analysis
-Apply best practices
-Customize settings
-Apply formatting
-Create a Slicer
-Create a Pivot Chart

Space is limited. To register, please visit or call Riverdale Library at 416-393-7720.

title: Excel Basics 1
description:
An introductory class on Microsoft Excel for absolute beginners with no Excel experience.

In this first session you will:

- Learn the basic function and design of Excel files
- Practice basic data entry for text, numbers, and basic functions: Sum, AutoSum and Average
- Create and save your first workbook and worksheets

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use Excel at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Basic mouse and keyboard skills are required.

To register call 416-393-7746

description:

title: SP Book Club
description:
Discuss diverse and inclusive titles from a variety of genres on the fourth Thursday of every month!

This month we will be discussing The Woman in Cabin 10 by Ruth Ware.
Journalist Lo Blacklock has been given the assignment of a lifetime: a week on a luxury cruise with only a handful of cabins. The Aurora begins her voyage in the picturesque North Sea and Los stay is beyond pleasant. But as the week wears on, the skies turn gray, and Lo witnesses a woman being thrown overboard. However, all the passengers are accounted for and ship continues onward, despite Los attempts to convey that something (or someone) has gone terribly wrong.

Pick up a physical copy at the branch before the meeting, or find copies through our website in various formats. Registration is required and begins September 26, 2024.

Please call 416-393-7666 or visit the branch to register.

title: Sloppy Craft: Monoprinting and Mark Making workshop
description:
During this workshop, artist & printmaker Olivia Mae Sinclair will demonstrate how to use a Gelli printing plate to create fun and dynamic prints. Participants are encouraged to be a little "sloppy" and very creative!

Monoprinting, a technique that offers a high reward for minimal effort, is almost instantly and incredibly satisfying. Participants may create two or more unique prints using ink and paint, allowing them to improve their technique and express themselves through art.

No registration. FOR TEENS.

title: October Movie - The Last Black Man in San Francisco - NEW DATE!
description:
Enjoy a night at the movies! Join us for a free movie on the big screen in our accessible theatre. Start time is 6:00 pm. Drop in. All are welcome!

The Last Black Man in San Francisco
2019 - 121 min - 14A - Drama

Jimmie Fails dreams of reclaiming the Victorian home his grandfather built in the heart of San Francisco. Joined on his quest by his best friend Mont, Jimmie searches for belonging in a rapidly changing city that seems to have left them behind. As he struggles to reconnect with his family and reconstruct the community he longs for, his hopes blind him to the reality of his situation.

Starring Jimmie Fails, Jonathan Majors and Rob Morgan.

If you live with a disability, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: National Film Board of Canada Screening: "npawistamsowin: We Will Stand Up"
library: Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre
description:
Join us as we continuing our NFB Documentary Screening Series with our second film, "npawistamsowin: We Will Stand Up."

Sensitively directed by Tasha Hubbard, "npawistamsowin: We Will Stand Up" follows the family of the late Colten Boushie, a young Cree man fatally shot in a Saskatchewan farmyard, as they demand justice from Canada's legal system.

Drop in. No registration required.

title: Why It's Healthy to Talk about Death
description:
Why don't we talk about death? There are so many benefits!

Led by death doula Dave Clark, this is a relaxed and welcoming discussion and workshop to help enhance death literacy and reduce people's fear of death by examining how death has been a natural part of living since the beginning of time.

Learn about the benefits of Advance Care Planning, services available for end-of-life care, overview of funeral options, services available for grief support, and much more.

Space is limited. Register in branch or by calling 416-396-3975. Held in Meeting Room.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Ted Chiang: Soulful Science Fiction
description:
Ted Chiang joins us to discuss his beloved stories, collected in Exhalation and Stories of Your Life and Others.

Perhaps the world's most celebrated living science fiction author, his fantastical and elegant stories explore how our inner worlds and our societies would react to unexpected rifts in the fabric of science. How would it feel to receive a hormone injection that drastically improved your cognitive function? What if learning an alien language changed the way you perceived time? And if humanity were to create artificial life, what obligations would we owe it? Ted Chiang wrestles with the oldest questions on earth - What is the nature of the universe? What does it mean to be human? - and ones that no one else has even imagined. And, each in its own way, the stories prove that complex and thoughtful science fiction can rise to new heights of beauty, meaning, and compassion.

In conversation with author Kelly Robson.

Q & A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Ted Chiang
Kelly Robson

Read more:
Stories of Your Life and Others
Exhalation
High Times in the Low Parliament

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Aging Well in Toronto Program Series: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
description:
The program is designed to provide older adults and seniors, residing in Toronto, with the information they require to age well. In partnership with Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community, this monthly program series is will run from July - December 2024.

Participants will engage in workshops providing information and tools related to the following topics:

Session 2: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
Tuesday August 13th, 10:30am - 11:30am. Room 1

In this workshop, participants will learn how to protect their assets from frauds and scams targeted towards seniors. With a guest speaker from the Toronto Police Services Frauds and Scams Unit, seniors will learn how to identify scams and how to protect themselves from becoming a victim. In addition, our guest speaker will provide participants with next steps should they become a victim of fraudulent activity.

Upcoming Program Dates (Room 1):

Session 3: Elder Abuse - Friday, September 20, 2024 - Room 101
Session 4: Mental Health and Cognition - Friday, October 25, 2024
Session 5: Physical Health and Exercise - Tuesday, November 19, 2024
Session 6: Aging in Place and Other Options - Tuesday, December 17, 2024

Registration is encouraged via Eventbrite. Drop-ins are welcome. For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Excel Basics 3: Pivot Tables and Conditional Formatting
description:
PivotTables and Conditional Formatting are powerful Excel tools to help you visualize and analyze your data.

In this class you will:
Use Conditional Formatting to visualize data using Rules, Icon Set, Data Bars.
Explore the power of PivotTables for data summary and analysis with custom settings, formatting and filters.
Upon completion of this class students will have a foundation upon which to independently build their skills with these effective tools.

Pre-requisites: Previous Excel experience is strongly recommended. Excel Basics 1 and 2 or equivalent knowledge. Mouse and keyboard skills required.

title: Travel Talk: Western Cape, South Africa
description:
Situated on the southernmost region of African contient, Western Cape is well known for its coastlines, floral areas and diverse topography. Experienced travel talk speaker David Crichton presents his recent trip to Western Cape, South Africa. The presentation includes his visits to the Victoria & Albert Waterfront in Cape Town, a drive along the Cape Peninsular to Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. It also includes a tour to a winery near Stellenbosch, the wine district of South Africa and a stay In a Retirement Village in Somerset West.

This program is for adults. Drop in. No registration is required. Room 101.

title: Building Career & Job Search Resilience
description:
Job hunting is not for the faint-hearted. All those unanswered applications, networking meetings and interviews can take a toll on us. In this workshop for younger adults, learn about resilience and how to persevere despite disappointments.

Resilience is an essential skill for career development - whether you're just starting out or are seeking to grow in your established profession. The session will include a Q&A period at the end.

title: True Crime Club
description:
Dive into the world of true crime with fellow enthusiasts as we explore real-life mysteries, investigations, and infamous cases. Investigate the case on your own using books, podcasts, or documentaries and then join us at the end of the month as we share findings, theories and insights in a respectful and engaging discussion. Whether you're a seasoned sleuth or a curious newcomer, our club offers a safe space to unravel the mysteries of the criminal mind.

For September, we will be investigating "The Highway of Tears" by Jessica McDiarmid, a poignant account of the Indigenous women and girls who have vanished or been murdered along British Columbia's notorious Highway 16. This powerful book sheds light on the heartbreaking stories behind the statistics, revealing a national crisis of violence and systemic neglect. Limited copies of the book and discussion guides are available at the 5th floor desk. Reading is encourage but not required. Everyone is welcome.

Sign up for an email reminder here: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/true-crime-club-tickets-856439923867?aff=oddtdtcreator

title: Place au cinma avec Cinfranco : Testament de Denys Arcand
description:
Se posant en moraliste sceptique , Denys Arcand explore dans son dernier film des sujets de socit assez controverss allant de la rectitude politique aux questions identitaires. Le film raconte l'histoire de Jean-Michel, un archiviste pr-retrait qui cherche ses repres face aux nombreux changements qui traversent la socit qubcoise. Il est d'abord exaspr par un groupe de manifestants qui arrive pour exiger que l'tablissement retire une installation artistique juge insultante pour les Premires Nations mais au final il trouve un nouvel amour et une nouvelle joie de vivre dans cette exprience.

Le film a t slectionn pour le Festival du film francophone d'Angoulme 2023 et pour le Festival de cinma de la ville de Qubec.

Avec Rmy Girard et Sophie Lorain.

En version originale avec des sous-titres anglais.

Dure : 115 min.

Entre libre.

La projection de film va se drouler le lundi 28 octobre 18h la bibliothque de rfrence dans Beeton Hall et sera suivi d'une discussion en franais anime par Mme Marcelle Lean, Directrice gnrale et artistique de Cinfranco.


****

title: Ghost Phenomena
description:
Canada's oldest, most reputable and accomplished paranormal research team celebrates its 45th Anniversary in 2024!

Assistant Director Peter Roe is sharing The Searcher Group's true-life discoveries from the field of ghost investigation. This popular presentation includes tools-of-the-trade, original theory on life-after-life phenomena, rarely-seen exclusive field photos and clarifies popular misconceptions about ghosts (and how to properly investigate them).

Bring your own inquiries and experiences to a Q&A following the hour-long talk!

An informative and entertaining Pre-Show video will be presented 30 minutes before the presentation for early attendees.

5:30-6 pm Pre-Show
6-7:30 pm Presentation and Q&A

Space is limited. Register in branch or by calling 416-396-3975. Held in Meeting Room.

title: The Quest for Alien Life -  Are We Alone?
description:
Where are all the aliens? Why haven't we met them yet? What do they look like? Are UFOs really evidence of visiting aliens? When and where might we discover alien life in the future? Living in the golden age of astronomy and space exploration, we could uncover the answers in our lifetimes. Immerse yourself in possible images of aliens, informed by our knowledge of science and evolution.

Tom Vassos is an astronomer, university instructor, founder of Cosmologists Without Borders, member of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada and author of several books in "The Inspiring Universe Collection" series. Mr. Vassos is a science communicator who is frequently invited as a guest expert on radio and television. He is the Astronomer-in-Residence for Royal Caribbean and Holland America cruise lines, leading eclipse expeditions worldwide.

Drop-in.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: LSP: Nobody's Perfect - Parenting Program for Newcomer Families
description:
Are you a newcomer eager to connect with other parents and learn positive ways to navigate the joys and challenges of raising children in a new environment?

Join our Parenting series of workshops which offer a supportive space where you can meet other parents , share your questions and ideas, and work together to discover effective parenting strategies. Whether you are seeking advice or simply want to connect with a community that understands you journey, our workshops will empower you with the tools and confidence to thrive as a parent in your new home. title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Path to Publication: How to Get Your Romance Novel Published
description:
The publishing landscape has changed significantly in the last 15 years, and this shift is evident in the romance genre more than in other genres. In this workshop, Farah will cover the possible paths to getting your romance novel published; outlining the steps to getting traditionally published by querying agents or submitting to publishers directly, and the steps involved with indie (self) publishing. This workshop would be of value to anyone looking to get their stories published in any genre, however the focus will be on romance publishing. Q&A follows.

Join writer Farah Heron, Toronto Public Library's Fall 2024 Writer in Residence, as she engages you in this fascinating and informative talk on romance fiction at North York Central Library.

This event is part of TPL's Writer in Residence program. The residency is designed to encourage exchanges between the author and the community and the Writer in Residence will be delivering workshops and evaluating manuscripts of aspiring writers who submit their work.

To register, please call 416-395-5639.

title: Jeanne Beker: Stories from a Life Well Worn
description:
Fashion and style icon Jeanne Beker discusses her new memoir and walks us through a wardrobe of memory, one article of clothing at a time.

Jeanne Beker's name is synonymous with style and grace in fashion, recognized by many as the beloved host of Fashion Television. Now, in Heart on My Sleeve, Jeanne reveals who she is in an all-new way.

This is not just a memoir but a wardrobe of memory. Jeanne walks us through her recollections of specific pieces of clothing and jewelry, precious items that have made an indelible impact on her. She invites readers to think more deeply about how what we wear - whether it's a thrift-store find or high-end couture - acts as a touchstone to our most treasured recollections, reminding us of who we once were or of loved ones we hold dear.

With Jeanne as our style guide, we get up-close and personal with a star-studded cast, including Paul McCartney, Madonna, Karl Lagerfeld, Kate Moss, Oscar de la Renta, Beyonc, and Keith Richards. But equally important, Jeanne introduces us to the family members and loved ones who form her closest entourage - including her wise Yiddish mother and her industrious father, both Holocaust survivors; her childhood neighbor Mrs. Jaskolka, a style maven ahead of her time; her two trailblazing daughters; and her many warm and exuberant friends who have seen her through the best and worst of times.

Jeanne Beker speaks with Melissa Grelo, co-host of CTV's The Social, about Heart on My Sleeve, a bold, colourful, and authentic memoir that proves that a life lived with style and substance is always in fashion.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Jeanne Beker
Melissa Grelo

Read more:
Heart on My Sleeve: Stories from a Life Well Worn
Finding Myself in Fashion

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. We'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

description:

Participants will delve into songwriting fundamentals, rhyme schemes, song structures, and recording techniques. The program will culminate in the preparation and release of an original song. Participants will explore the artistic and legal elements of song creation.

For ages 12 and up.

Spaces are limited. Register in person or by calling 416-394-1066.

description:
A thought-provoking and enlightening presentation emphasizing how ghost presences within historic sites can be respectfully utilized to call attention to Ontario's vanishing heritage and those who have gone before us.

description:

September 25: Moccasin Square Gardens by Richard van Camp
October 30: We Have Always Lived in the Castle by Shirley Jackson
November 27: Remembrance by Alistair MacLeod
December 18: Holiday's on Ice
Registration is required. New members are always welcome! Please register at Parliament Street branch or by calling 416-393-7663. Each month's title will be available at the front desk upon request.

title: Toronto Early Cemeteries
description:
Retired librarian Virginia Van Vliet has been leading historic

history of these and other early cemeteries, and the interesting
lives of some of the people buried there.

Presented in partnership with the North Toronto Historical Society

title: Creative Writing Workshop Group
description:
Looking to improve your English Writing skills? We're gathering a group of amateur writers to read and workshop one another's short stories! Each month, members will hand out their stories (Max word count: 800) and then we will meet to discuss what we liked and what requires more work within each member's piece. Meets on the last Wednesday of the month.

Registration required. Call 416-396-8850 to register.

description:

title: Rumaan Alam: Entitlement
description:
Bestselling author Rumaan Alam joins us to discuss his new novel, Entitlement, a riveting tale for our guilded age about the unsettling and seductive distortions of money. When Brooke finds a job assisting an octogenarian billionaire in his quest to give away a vast fortune, proximity to wealth turns out to be nothing less than transformative. What is money, really, but a kind of belief?

Q & A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Rumaan Alam

Read more:
Entitlement
Leave the World Behind
That Kind of Mother
Rich and Pretty


***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. As with all Appel Salon events, we'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Haunted Heritage: Honoring Our History's Ghosts
library: Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre
description:
Forty-five years ago, The Searcher Group (TSG) - Canada's oldest, most reputable and accomplished paranormal research team - was founded. It is in the spirit of commemorating this anniversary that TSG arrives at Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre to present its popular talk with a focus on heritage and historic sites - many of which continue to vanish in the name of 'progress'.

Join TSG Assistant Director and author Peter Roe (Haunted Town Halls) for a fascinating and intriguing perspective, as he mixes chills and humour, linking our disappearing past with revelations discovered in the process of professional ghost investigation; discover how those who have gone before us can help keep history alive!

Skeptics, believers, experiencers and the curious alike are all welcome to attend. This is a judgment-free event. Bring your own inquiries and experiences to a Q&A following the hour-long talk!

An informative and entertaining Pre-Show will be presented 30 minutes before the presentation for early attendees.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Personal Essay Workshop for Post-Secondary Students
description:
Are you applying to post-secondary education and are required to submit a personal essay? Or maybe you're already in a program and seeking funding beyond OSAP? This workshop provides the writing supports needed to craft a compelling personal statement. Participants will learn how to tell their story in a way that resonates with the reader while respecting their personal boundaries.

Presenter Kathryn Barclay will guide youths through the process, helping them hone their written communication skills to potentially access scholarship and bursary opportunities, and gain entry to the programs of their choice.

Participants are required to attend all 4 sessions on November 4, 11, 18, and 25 at 4-5pm.

Registration will open in September.

description:
Are you a newcomer eager to connect with other parents and learn positive ways to navigate the joys and challenges of raising children in a new environment?

Join our Parenting series of workshops which offer a supportive space where you can meet other parents , share your questions and ideas, and work together to discover effective parenting strategies. Whether you are seeking advice or simply want to connect with a community that understands you journey, our workshops will empower you with the tools and confidence to thrive as a parent in your new home. Come and be part of a welcoming group where you experiences are valued and you family's growth is nurtured!

Register now! For more information, please contact - Nina at nali@culturelink.ca or 416-931-6536

In partnership with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, CultureLink Settlement & Community Services & Toronto Public Library.

title: Newsgirls: Gutsy Pioneers in Canada's Newsrooms
description:
Former Toronto Star reporter, Donna Jean Mackinnon documents the lives of 10 leading female reporters who established their careers between 1930 and 1960--the Golden Age of Newspapers. MacKinnon's fascinating, often amusing presentation includes a slew of vintage photos and intimate anecdotes.Trailblazers in their fields, these adventurous 'newshens,' as they were once called, covered every beat from art openings, fashion, crime, politics, and the major social issues of the day​.

Free. No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Week 2: Tuesday, October 29, 2:00 3:00 p.m.

title: NatureTO: Trees Around the Branch Tour
description:
The S. Walter Stewart Library and its neighbourhood is home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to explore the natural world on a local neighbourhood walk. Learn how to recognize different species and fun facts about their cultural and ecological importance.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver.

Please note, the tour will start and end at the S. Walter Stewart Library. The City of Toronto Urban Forestry tour is outside and around the neighbourhood where there may be uneven, unpaved surfaces. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). This program takes place rain or shine.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone (416) 393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

Registration is required. Register in branch or by calling 416-396-3975.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Tuesday Night Tech Support Drop-in
description:
Have questions about your tablet, phone, laptop, email or an app? Need help with ebooks or other online library services?

We know keeping up with new technology can be difficult! Our staff are here to teach you technology tools and concepts in a friendly and casual setting. Please bring your personal device and any questions you may have.

No registration required. This is a drop-in event, come to the library to get one-on-one tech support! Space may be limited depending on attendance.

*Longer questions may be referred to a 1 hour Book a Librarian appointment at a later date.*

*No technology repairs at this event.*

title: Leonard Cohen: The Man Who Saw Angels Fall
description:
Christophe Lebold joins us to discuss his new biography of Leonard Cohen. In Leonard Cohen: The Man Who Saw Angels Fall, we see how six decades of radiant pessimism and a few thousand nights in hotel rooms transformed a young Jewish poet who longed to be a saint into an existentialist troubadour in love with women and a gravelly-voiced crooner who taught a thousand ways of dissolving love.

In conversation with David Bezmozgis.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Christophe Lebold
David Bezmozgis

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

This event is also part of our new Jewish Heritage programming series, presented in partnership with the Miles Nadal JCC.

By providing a platform for learning, discussion, and celebration, we hope to foster a greater understanding and appreciation of the Jewish community's invaluable contributions to our shared history and identity.
Join us in celebrating the diversity that strengthens our community and makes our city a more vibrant and inclusive place for all.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the Jack Rabinovitch Reading Room, located on the fourth floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 15 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

description:
An introductory class on the Internet for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this session you will:

- Understand how to read a web site address
- Practice using web addresses
- Search for information using a search engine
- Explore a web site in detail to understand its key components

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use the internet at a beginner level and complete simple searches.

Pre-requisites: Basic mouse and keyboarding skills

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

Register in person or call 416-393-7723

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Haunted Heritage: Honoring Our History's Ghosts
description:
Join TSG Assistant Director and author Peter Roe (Haunted Town Halls) for a fascinating and intriguing perspective, as he mixes chills and humour, linking our disappearing past with revelations discovered in the process of professional ghost investigation; discover how those who have gone before us can help keep history alive!

Skeptics, believers, experiencers and the curious alike are all welcome to attend. This is a judgment-free event.

An informative and entertaining Pre-Show will be presented at 5:30pm for early attendees.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Are you are looking to get together with a group of like-minded friends? Come join our Friday Socials at Spadina! Every Friday, we will offer a series of activities that will focus on social interaction and fun.

Each week is a new opportunity to:

Meet new people and make new connections
Play cards, board games, bingo, craft (bring your own projects), colour, puzzles and so much more!
Learn a new skill while having fun
Benefit from social interaction

All supplies are provided. No need to bring anything other than a smile and a good attitude. All are welcome!
