title: Personal Essay Workshop for Post-Secondary Students
description:
Are you applying to post-secondary education and are required to submit a personal essay? Or maybe you're already in a program and seeking funding beyond OSAP? This workshop provides the writing supports needed to craft a compelling personal statement. Participants will learn how to tell their story in a way that resonates with the reader while respecting their personal boundaries.

Presenter Kathryn Barclay will guide youths through the process, helping them hone their written communication skills to potentially access scholarship and bursary opportunities, and gain entry to the programs of their choice.

Participants are required to attend all 4 sessions on November 4, 11, 18, and 25 at 4-5pm.

Registration will open in September.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

All skill levels and small crafts are welcome. Instruction is not provided.

title: Canada's Ongoing Contribution to Diabetes Research
description:
Canada's Ongoing Contribution to Diabetes Research:
From Insulin to Islet Transplants

Since Sir Frederick Banting's discovery of insulin at the University of Toronto in 1921, Canadian scientists have remained on the front lines of the development of new treatments for diabetes and the quest for the cure.

Author and science communicator Krista Lamb shares stories from her award-winning book about the remarkable Canadian scientists from across the country who are building on Banting's legacy and are having an impact on the international stage. She also offers insights and inspiration for future scientists or those who hold science as an interest.

Space is limited. Register in branch or by calling 416-396-3975. Held in Meeting Room.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Natalie Haynes: Goddesses in Greek Myth
description:
New York Times bestselling author, comedian, and BBC broadcaster Natalie Haynes shares her new book about the world of ancient Greek myth, offering a refreshing take on the legends and stories we thought we knew.

Divine Might: Goddesses in Greek Myth is a female-centered look at Olympus and the Furies, focusing on the goddesses whose prowess, passions, jealousies, and desires rival those of their male kin, including: Athene, the goddess of war and provider of wise counsel who sprang fully formed from her father's brow; Aphrodite, the epitome of love who also harbors a fearsome vengeful side; and Hera, Zeus's long-suffering wife, whose jealousy born of his repeated dalliances leads her to wreak elaborate and often painful revenge on those she believes have wronged her.

Natalie Haynes speaks with Jessica Allen, correspondent for CTV's The Social, about Divine Might, a scintillating look at the goddesses at the heart of Greek mythology.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Natalie Haynes
Jessica Allen

Read more:
Divine Might: Goddesses in Greek Myth
Pandora's Jar: Women in Greek Myths

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends. We'll have a bar with a selection of beer and wine, as well as snacks, available to purchase (only debit and credit cards accepted).

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

***

title: Ancestry Library Club
description:
For beginners. Learn basic searches to find records of your ancestors using the popular genealogy database Ancestry Library Edition. For those with little or no experience with family history.

In the first session you will:
-learn the basics of compiling a family tree
-use sample searches to explore Ancestry records for birth, marriage, death and the census
-experiment with wildcards to improve your searches

Prerequisites: Basic mouse and keyboarding skills required.

In subsequent sessions you will use what you learned to explore your own genealogy with staff available for support.

This is an in-person program. Registration begins August 20th. Please register in person or by calling the Brentwood branch at (416) 394-5240.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: True Crime Club
description: This club is for those who enjoy discussing true crimes from next door to around the world. Each month we review a case and then we decide which cases we want to look into next month We investigate the cases on our own using a variety of true crime databases, podcasts, books etc. We then meet to discuss the theories and ideas around the crime with one another. We are a passionate group and always discuss cases in a respectful manner. Come and join us on the second Tuesday of the month for an intimate evening of True Crime.
otherinfo: June 11  Jack the Ripper was an unidentified serial killer active in the Whitechapel district of London, England, in 1888.

title: The Romance Book Club
description:
A monthly discussion on diverse and inclusive romance books. Suitable for 18+

Join us online for a lively discussion of Canadian Boyfriend by Jenny Holiday. Copies are available in regular print at branches and eBook and eAudiobook format through OverDrive.

About this month's book:

Once upon a time teenage Aurora Evans met a hockey player at the Mall of America. He was from Canada and soon, he was the perfect fake boyfriend. He became her get-out-of-jail-free card for all kinds of sticky situations. He was just what she needed to cover her social awkwardness and he never had to know. It wasn't like she was ever going to see him again.

Years later, Aurora is teaching kids' dance classes and battling panic and eating disorders--souvenirs from her failed ballet career--when pro hockey player Mike Martin walks in with his daughter. Mike's honesty about his struggles with widowhood helps Aurora confront some of her own demons, and the two forge an unlikely friendship. There's just one problem: Mike is the boy she spent years pretending was her "Canadian boyfriend." The longer she keeps her secret, the more she knows it will shatter the trust between them. But to have the life she wants, she needs to tackle the most important thing of all: believing in herself.

This program requires registraion. Specific instructions on how to access Jitsi Meet will be sent to all registrants 30 mins before the book club meeting.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: L.M. Montgomery's Anne of Green Gables through the Years: Texts, Covers, Readers
description:
Join the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books for our 36th Annual Helen E. Stubbs Memorial Lecture: L.M. Montgomery's Anne of Green Gables through the Years: Texts, Covers, Readers by Benjamin Lefebvre .

Benjamin Lefebvre (he/him) lives in Kitchener and directs the web resource L.M. Montgomery Online. His books include an edition of L.M. Montgomery's rediscovered final book, "The Blythes Are Quoted" (Penguin Canada), and the award-winning three-volume critical anthology "The L.M. Montgomery Reader" (University of Toronto Press). Current projects include editing volumes of Montgomery's shorter works for University of Toronto Press, most recently "Twice upon a Time: Selected Stories, 1898 - 1939". In 2022, he published his first novel, "In the Key of Dale" (Arsenal Pulp Press).

In this lecture, Lefebvre will discuss how the text of L.M. Montgomery's first and most famous book, "Anne of Green Gables", has largely stayed the same since it was published in 1908. But everything else-from cover designs to the technologies people use to read and discuss books-has changed immeasurably since then. In this lecture, novelist and scholar Benjamin Lefebvre shares some of the discoveries he has made throughout his many years as a Montgomery scholar and offers new insights about this perennially popular book, how it fits within Montgomery's lifetime body of work, and how it continues to be reprinted today.

Benjamin Lefebvre (photo credit Kassandra Fritz)

This free event will be held on the lower level of the Lillian H. Smith Branch in the Auditorium.

Doors will open at 6:00 pm and the event will start at 6:30 pm. No registration is required. Everyone is welcome.

Questions about the program? Please email us at osstaff@tpl.ca.

title: Fashioning The Beatles: The Looks that Shook the World
description:
John, Paul, George, and Ringo were more than great musicians: they were the quintessential fashion icons of one of the most exciting and memorable fashion eras of all time. In author and cultural critic Deirdre Kelly's cultural history book, she takes the first in-depth look at how the Beatles used clothing to express their individual and group identities and, especially, to grow their following. She demonstrates how their inimitable style was not an incidental by-product of their fame but an integral part of their act and a key to their globe-spanning success.

Register in branch or by calling 416-396-3975. Held in Meeting Room.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Morris Lum, Arlene Chan & Linda Zhang: Chinatown in Photos
description:
2024 Toronto Biennial photography artist Morris Lum is joined by Chinese Canadian Historian Arlene Chan and architect and professor Linda Zhang for an intimate conversation about the vibrant history of Toronto's Chinatown.

Using storytelling and photographs, these stewards of Chinese immigration history in Canada will explore the history of Toronto's first Chinatown (originally located near present-day City Hall) and the transition to its current location at Spadina Avenue and Dundas Street West.

Q&A to follow.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Morris Lum
Arlene Chan
Linda Zhang

This event is in partnership with the Toronto Biennial of Art, Canada's leading visual arts event focused solely on contemporary art from around the world.

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

It is also part of our Asian Heritage series, generously supported by TD Bank Group, through the TD Ready Commitment.

This program is made possible through the generous support of Eleanor & Francis Shen and Partners in Art.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Matisse, Kandinsky, Macke et Klee, au Maroc et en Tunisie
description:
Les sjours en Afrique du Nord, partir de 1830, de Delacroix, de Chassriau et des peintres romantiques, ont profondment marqu l'imaginaire des artistes europens. Peu peu s'impose l'ide que le Grand Tour si formateur, ne doit plus s'effectuer en Italie mais sur les rivages mridionaux de la Mditerrane. Les paysages contempls par Wassily Kandinsky en Tunisie en 1905, Henri Matisse au Maroc en 1908, August Macke et Paul Klee nouveau en Tunisie en 1914, les invitent dployer des techniques et des figurations nouvelles. Tandis que Matisse hausse ses couleurs une intensit jusqu'alors inconnue chez lui, Klee bascule progressivement vers l'abstraction ; c'est en relisant l'mouvant tmoignage qu'il nous laisse de ces expriences dans son Journal que nous dcouvrirons les passionnantes tapes de ce voyage intrieur.

La confrence est propose par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art et fait partie d'un premier cycle intitul Les artistes voyageurs ; nouveaux horizons, nouvelle inspiration !

En collaboration avec Alliance Franaise de Toronto.

Crdit photo : Margot Richard.

Un pravis d'au moins trois semaines est prfrable. Composez 416-393-7099 ou contactez-nous par courriel accessibleservices@tpl.ca

title: Personal Essay Workshop for Post-Secondary Students
description:
Are you applying to post-secondary education and are required to submit a personal essay? Or maybe you're already in a program and seeking funding beyond OSAP? This workshop provides the writing supports needed to craft a compelling personal statement. Participants will learn how to tell their story in a way that resonates with the reader while respecting their personal boundaries.

Presenter Kathryn Barclay will guide youths through the process, helping them hone their written communication skills to potentially access scholarship and bursary opportunities, and gain entry to the programs of their choice.

Participants are required to attend all 4 sessions on November 4, 11, 18, and 25 at 4-5pm.

Registration will open in September.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Aging Well in Toronto Program Series: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
description:
The program is designed to provide older adults and seniors, residing in Toronto, with the information they require to age well. In partnership with Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community, this monthly program series is will run from July - December 2024.

Participants will engage in workshops providing information and tools related to the following topics:

Session 2: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
Tuesday August 13th, 10:30am - 11:30am. Room 1

In this workshop, participants will learn how to protect their assets from frauds and scams targeted towards seniors. With a guest speaker from the Toronto Police Services Frauds and Scams Unit, seniors will learn how to identify scams and how to protect themselves from becoming a victim. In addition, our guest speaker will provide participants with next steps should they become a victim of fraudulent activity.

Upcoming Program Dates (Room 1):

Session 3: Elder Abuse - Friday, September 20, 2024 - Room 101
Session 4: Mental Health and Cognition - Friday, October 25, 2024
Session 5: Physical Health and Exercise - Tuesday, November 19, 2024
Session 6: Aging in Place and Other Options - Tuesday, December 17, 2024

Registration is encouraged via Eventbrite. Drop-ins are welcome. For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

title: Toddler Time
description:
Stories, rhymes and songs for children ages 19 to 35 months and their caregivers.
2nd Floor Program Room.

title: Social Seniors
description:
Come and meet other seniors in the Yorkville neighbourhood.

From 1 to 2, make new friends, play games, do some art. From 2 to 3:30 pm, learn a new skill or listen to a guest speaker.


Fall 2024 sessions:

Tuesday, Sept. 24: Art workshop: Exploring watercolour pencils

Tuesday, Oct. 1: Mindfulness for Older Adults: Presented by Andrew Kcomt, Knowledge Translation & Research Manager at Hope & Me - Mood Disorders Association of Ontario.

Tuesday, Oct. 22: Memory and Aging: What's Normal, What's Not, and What You Can Do About It: Presented by Professor Nicole D. Anderson from Baycrest Health Sciences.

Tuesday, Nov. 5: Author talk: Donna Jean Mackinnon discusses her book Newsgirls: Gutsy Pioneers in Canada's Newsrooms

Tuesday, Nov. 19: Protecting your Family Treasures: Presented by Andrew Huot,
Bookbinder and Conservator

Wednesday, Dec. 4: Make your own Vision Board, 3-4pm

All sessions are from 2-3:30 pm except for the December session (3-4pm)
Free. No registration required.


If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: LSP: Nobody's Perfect - Parenting Program for Newcomer Families
description:
Are you a newcomer eager to connect with other parents and learn positive ways to navigate the joys and challenges of raising children in a new environment?

Join our Parenting series of workshops which offer a supportive space where you can meet other parents , share your questions and ideas, and work together to discover effective parenting strategies. Whether you are seeking advice or simply want to connect with a community that understands you journey, our workshops will empower you with the tools and confidence to thrive as a parent in your new home. Come and be part of a welcoming group where you experiences are valued and you family's growth is nurtured!

Register now! For more information, please contact - Nina at nali@culturelink.ca or 416-931-6536

In partnership with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, CultureLink Settlement & Community Services & Toronto Public Library.

title: Protecting your Family Treasures
description:
Conservator Andrew Huot will discuss ways to save, protect, and store meaningful family items such as books, old photos, letters, and other documents that might be old and delicate.
Participants will gain an understanding of the environmental conditions that can lead books and papers to degrade faster and how to slow the deterioration of these items.

Free. No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Topic: Financial Freedom in Retirement
Week 2: Tuesday, October 29, 2:00 3:00 p.m.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

title: NewsGirls: Gutsy Pioneers in Canadas Newsrooms
description:
Author and former Toronto Star reporter and columnist Donna Jean MacKinnon documents the careers of ten pioneering women reporters who worked in newspapers Golden Age (19301960) when reportage informed and shaped public opinion, often scooping newshounds like Pierre Berton.

If you identify as a person with a disability or a person who is Deaf, and require this information in an accessible format, or an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Northern District Library at 416-363-7610 or use the online form at tpl.ca/accessibility to make a request. title: Fabric & Fibre Fun!
description:
Calling all crafters! Are you interested in handicrafts like knitting, crochet, or embroidery? Bring your current project and join us for a social hour every Wednesday evening! Help yourself to coffee or tea, meet other crafters, relax, chat, and maybe even learn something new!

Registration is not required.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone (416) 393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.

title: Book Club
description:

title: Computers for Beginners: Use Google Search and Maps
description:
A class on using Google's filters, tools, and Maps for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this session you will:

- Use Google search tools more effectively to find websites, images, and news sites
- Explore Google Maps to find addresses and get directions for transit and road travel.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use more advanced search engine features and use Google Maps at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Basic mouse, keyboarding and internet skills

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

Register in person or call 416-393-7723

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Lucy Maud Montgomery Book Club
description:
Join us to discuss Lucy Maud Montgomery's classic novels at the Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books. In celebration of her 150th birthday, the book club will be reading novels from across Montgomery's career. We welcome new readers and avid Montgomery fans alike! Dates and books are listed below.

Thursday September 19 - Anne of Green Gables
Thursday October 17 - Emily of New Moon
Thursday November 21 - The Blue Castle

No registration is required and everyone is welcome.

Book club meetings will take place in the Osborne Collection on the fourth floor of Lillian H. Smith Branch.

If you need help getting a copy of the book or have any questions, please contact us at osstaff@tpl.ca or 416-393-7753.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Are you are looking to get together with a group of like-minded friends? Come join our Friday Socials at Spadina! Every Friday, we will offer a series of activities that will focus on social interaction and fun.

Each week is a new opportunity to:

Meet new people and make new connections
Play cards, board games, bingo, craft (bring your own projects), colour, puzzles and so much more!
Learn a new skill while having fun
Benefit from social interaction

All supplies are provided. No need to bring anything other than a smile and a good attitude. All are welcome!

title: NatureTO: Trees Around the Branch
description:
The Don Mills branch and its neighbourhood is home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to explore the natural world on a local neighbourhood walk. Learn how to recognize different species and fun facts about their cultural and ecological importance. For this walk, we will focus on the form, bark, twigs and buds of the trees during autumn.

Please note, the tour will start and end at the Don Mills branch. The City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff outside and around the neighbourhood where there may be uneven, unpaved surfaces will guide attendees. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date.

Registration is required; please register at the front desk or call the branch at 416-395-5710.

title: Travel Talk: Nepal
description:
Nepal is a landlocked Asian country situated in the Himalayas. The mountain range boasts some of the world's highest peaks including Mount Everest. Airline transport pilot, flight instructor, author and photographer Lola Reid Allin presents her recent trip to the country. We will begin our journey to Kathmandu, the capital city, and the surrounding valley, home to seven UNESCO Urban Monument Zones. Then, we will head into the Himalayas and trek around Manaslu, the eighth tallest mountain in the world, stopping overnight in tea houses and tents in remote villages along the trail.

This program is for adult. Drop in. No registration is required.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. title: Personal Essay Workshop for Post-Secondary Students
description:
Are you applying to post-secondary education and are required to submit a personal essay? Or maybe you're already in a program and seeking funding beyond OSAP? This workshop provides the writing supports needed to craft a compelling personal statement. Participants will learn how to tell their story in a way that resonates with the reader while respecting their personal boundaries.

Presenter Kathryn Barclay will guide youths through the process, helping them hone their written communication skills to potentially access scholarship and bursary opportunities, and gain entry to the programs of their choice.

Participants are required to attend all 4 sessions on November 4, 11, 18, and 25 at 4-5pm.

Registration will open in September.

Topic: Elder Abuse
Week 4: Tuesday, November 12, 2:00 3:00 p.m.
Topic: Mental Health and Cognition
Week 5: Tuesday, November 19, 2:00 3:00 p.m.
Topic: Physical Health and Exercise
Week 6: Tuesday, November 26, 2:00 3:00 p.m.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description:

Please register with the YMCA Newcomer Information Centre to attend the program. Space is limited and will be given on a first-come, first-served basis. For more information, please call 416-917-6717 or email Doris.Garcia@ymcagta.org.

In partnership with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, YMCA Newcomer Information Centre & Toronto Public Library.

description:

title: Short Book Club
description:
Are you interested in joining a book club but are short on time? Join the Short Book Club, focusing on books that are 250 pages or less. Join fellow book lovers for thoughtful discussions about a different title on the last Wednesday of the month.

The titles for each month are:
September 25: Moccasin Square Gardens by Richard van Camp
October 30: We Have Always Lived in the Castle by Shirley Jackson
November 27: Remembrance by Alistair MacLeod
December 18: Holiday's on Ice
Registration is required. New members are always welcome! Please register at Parliament Street branch or by calling 416-393-7663. Each month's title will be available at the front desk upon request.

Accessibility at Toronto Public Library:

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. title: Lies the Tobacco Industry Told Us:  Nicotine, Cigarettes, Vapes and Pouches
description:
James Wigmore, internationally recognized forensic toxicologist and author of "Wigmore on nicotine and its drug delivery systems" will discuss the medicolegal aspects and history of one of our more dangerous and addictive legal drugs, nicotine, and how it has morphed from pipes, to cigarettes, vapes and pouches.

Registration is encouraged, but not required. Drop-ins welcome until capacity is reached.

Register via Eventbrite.

For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science, & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

title: Computers for Beginners: Use Google Search and Maps
description:
A class on using Google's filters, tools, and Maps for absolute beginners with little computer experience.

In this session you will:

- Use Google search tools more effectively to find websites, images, and news sites
- Explore Google Maps to find addresses and get directions for transit and road travel.

Upon completion of this class students will be able to use more advanced search engine features and use Google Maps at a basic level.

Pre-requisites: Basic mouse, keyboarding and internet skills

Format: Hands-on with demonstrations

Register in person or call 416-393-7723

title: SP Book Club
description:
Discuss diverse and inclusive titles from a variety of genres on the fourth Thursday of every month!

This month we will be discussing In Five Years by Rebecca Serle.
Dannie has her entire life planned out. She knows exactly what she wants in the next five years: making senior associate at her law firm and marrying her boyfriend. After returning from her engagement dinner, Dannie has an experience that shakes her belief in her life plans. She spends an hour in her life, five years in the future, where she lives in a different apartment with a different man. Dannie spends the next four and a half years trying her best to stick to her plan, until the moment she meets the man she saw in the future.

Pick up a physical copy at the branch before the meeting, or find copies through our website in various formats. Registration is required and begins October 24, 2024.

Please call 416-393-7666 or visit the branch to register.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: P.A. Day: Making Comics with Kean Soo!
description:
Join award-winning graphic cartoonist Kean Soo (Jellaby, March Grand Prix) as he shares his process of writing stories, creating characters, and drawing for comics and graphic novels! Kean will be teaching basic writing and drawing techniques to create your own stories, and working with the audience, he will create a live comic to demonstrate how it all comes together on the page!

This is an in-person workshop for teens in Grades 7-12.

Registration begins on Friday, October 4th, 2024. Spaces are limited. For more information or to register, please call 416-396-8975 or email ststaff@tpl.ca

If you or your teen lives with a disability, and requires an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
description:
Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP) is an education and planning tool focusing on mental health recovery including concepts like hope, education, empowerment, self-advocacy, and interpersonal support and connection. This WRAP session is geared towards the 2SLGBTQIA+ community.

In an 8-week WRAP group, individuals explore:

- Self-help tools (i.e. peer counseling, focusing exercises, relaxation and stress reduction techniques)
- Resources for keeping themselves well and feeling better in difficult times

The Sanderson Branch WRAP Group will run every Friday from October 11, 2024 to November 29, 2024 from 11 AM - 1 PM. Registration for the 8-week group is required. Please register through the Gerstein Crisis Centre website. Language interpretation will be available based on participant request. Refreshments and TTC Presto tickets will be provided.

This program is in collaboration with Gerstein Crisis Centre's W.R.A.P. initiative.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

Each week is a new opportunity to:

Meet new people and make new connections
Play cards, board games, bingo, craft (bring your own projects), colour, puzzles and so much more!
Learn a new skill while having fun
Benefit from social interaction

All supplies are provided. No need to bring anything other than a smile and a good attitude. All are welcome!

This program is drop-in. No registration required.

library: Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre

Join us as we continuing our NFB Documentary Screening Series with our third film, "Inconvenient Indian."

In this time of radical change and essential re-examination, "Inconvenient Indian" brings to life Thomas King's brilliant dismantling of North America's colonial narrative, reframing this history with the powerful voices of those continuing the tradition of Indigenous resistance.

Drop in. No registration required.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

The book for September's meeting is The World of Pooh by A.A. Milne, a children's classic that entertains all ages. Registration is required by calling the branch at 416-394-5088. Copies of the selected book of the month are available for pickup at the front desk. Please speak with staff.

title: Joy Harjo: Fifty Poems for Fifty Years
description:
Joy Harjo - writer, musician and 23rd United States Poet Laureate - discusses her groundbreaking career and poetry.

Weaving Sundown in a Scarlet Light is a magnificent selection of fifty poems to celebrate Harjo's fifty years as a poet. In this gemlike volume, she selects her best poems from across fifty years, beginning with her early discoveries of her own voice and ending with moving reflections on our contemporary moment. Generous notes on each poem offer insight into Harjo's inimitable poetics as she takes inspiration from Navajo horse songs and jazz, reckons with home and loss, and listens to the natural messengers of the earth.

Joy Harjo speaks with multidisciplinary artist Jessica Lea Fleming about her musical, intimate, political, and wise writing, which intertwines ancestral memory and tribal histories with resilience and love that speaks "from a deep and timeless source of compassion for all" (NPR).

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Joy Harjo
Jessica Lea Fleming

Read more:
Weaving Sundown in a Scarlet Light: Fifty Poems for Fifty Years
Poet Warrior

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

It is also part of our Indigenous Celebrations series, generously supported by TD Bank Group, through the TD Ready Commitment.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at The Bram and Bluma Appel Salon, the premiere event space for Toronto Public Library's cultural and heritage programming, located on the second floor of the Toronto Reference Library (789 Yonge Street).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

title: Tanya Talaga: The Knowing
description:
Award-winning and bestselling Anishinaabe author Tanya Talaga discusses her new book, a riveting exploration of her family's story and a retelling of the history of the country we now call Canada.

For generations, Indigenous People have known that their family members disappeared, many of them after being sent to residential schools, "Indian hospitals" and asylums through a coordinated system designed to destroy who the First Nations, Mtis and Inuit people are.

The Knowing is the unfolding of Canadian history unlike anything we have ever read before. Tanya Talaga retells the history of this country as only she can - through an Indigenous lens, beginning with the life of her great-great grandmother Annie Carpenter and her family as they experienced decades of disenfranchisement.

Tanya Talaga speaks about The Knowing, a seminal unravelling of the centuries-long oppression of Indigenous People that continues to reverberate in these communities today.

Q&A and book signing to follow. Books available for purchase.

Ticket registration for this event is required: Free tickets for this event are available to book via Eventbrite.

About this event's guests:
Tanya Talaga

Read more:
The Knowing
Seven Fallen Feathers

***

This event is part of our signature Salon Series, where we host local and international authors, artists and thinkers in conversation about their new books and big ideas.

It is also part of our Indigenous Celebrations series, generously supported by TD Bank Group, through the TD Ready Commitment.

***

Note: This is an in-person event at the North York Central Library Concourse, Toronto Public Library's new premiere event space for cultural and heritage programming located at 5120 Yonge Street (west side of Yonge St, one block north of Sheppard Ave).

Arrive early, meet people. The talk starts at 7 pm, but doors open at 6 pm. Come early so you can chat with your fellow literature lovers, and make new friends.

Reminder! We oversell these events to make sure that the most people have an opportunity to attend. Tickets are only guaranteed until 10 minutes before the show starts, at which point we will start opening up available spots to the rush line.

title: Artistes femmes en Asie au XXe sicle
description:
Longtemps mconnus des historiens de l'art, les voyages des femmes artistes en Asie sont une rcente redcouverte, la faveur d'une exposition (vian et Pont-Aven, 2022-2023) qui remet en lumire de magnifiques oeuvres, sorties pour la premire fois des collections publiques et prives. C'est ainsi que l'on put admirer, souvent pour la premire fois, les grandes dcorations de Marie-Antoinette Boullard-Dev, les peintures de Simone Gouz et d'Andre Karpels, les gouaches de La Lafugie, les expressives gravures sur bois d'Alix Aym, sans oublier les photographies de Thrse Le Prat et de Denise Colomb. Qu'importe que ces noms ne soient pas clbres ! C'est la redcouverte inattendue de ces prcieux tmoignages ethnographiques et de ces nouvelles expriences plastiques que cette confrence vous invite.

La confrence est propose par Gilles Genty, historien de l'art et fait partie d'un premier cycle intitul Les artistes voyageurs ; nouveaux horizons, nouvelle inspiration !

En collaboration avec Alliance Franaise de Toronto.

Crdit photo : Margot Richard.

description:

title: Newsgirls: Gutsy Pioneers in Canada's Newsrooms
description:
Toronto author Donna Jean MacKinnon documents the lives of 10 leading female reporters who started their careers during newspapers' Golden Age. MacKinnon's fascinating, often amusing, presentation includes a slew of vintage photos and intimate anecdotes. Trailblazers in their fields, these adventurous "newshens," as they came to be known, covered every beat from art openings, fashion, crime, and politics to major social issues of the day.

Register in branch or by calling 416-396-3975. Held in Meeting Room.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Before Neon, Plastic and Digital: Toronto's Early Business Signs
description: This illustrated talk explores how commercial signs influenced the look and feel of Toronto's streetscapes up to the year 1900. Over the course of the 19th century, outdoor signs using wood, paint, and gas were joined by metal, paper, and electricity, with measured restraint giving way to flamboyant abundance.

title: Ancestry Library Club
description:
For beginners. Learn basic searches to find records of your ancestors using the popular genealogy database Ancestry Library Edition. For those with little or no experience with family history.

In the first session you will:
-learn the basics of compiling a family tree
-use sample searches to explore Ancestry records for birth, marriage, death and the census
-experiment with wildcards to improve your searches

Prerequisites: Basic mouse and keyboarding skills required.

In subsequent sessions you will use what you learned to explore your own genealogy with staff available for support.

This is an in-person program. Registration begins August 20th. Please register in person or by calling the Brentwood branch at (416) 394-5240.

If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf, and require accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: True Crime Club
description: This club is for those who enjoy discussing true crimes from next door to around the world. Each month we review a case and then we decide which cases we want to look into next month We investigate the cases on our own using a variety of true crime databases, podcasts, books etc. We then meet to discuss the theories and ideas around the crime with one another. We are a passionate group and always discuss cases in a respectful manner. Come and join us on the second Tuesday of the month for an intimate evening of True Crime.
otherinfo: June 11  Jack the Ripper was an unidentified serial killer active in the Whitechapel district of London, England, in 1888.

title: Aging Well in Toronto Program Series: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
description:
The program is designed to provide older adults and seniors, residing in Toronto, with the information they require to age well. In partnership with Toronto Intergenerational Partnerships in Community, this monthly program series is will run from July - December 2024.

Participants will engage in workshops providing information and tools related to the following topics:

Session 2: Frauds & Scams Against Seniors
Tuesday August 13th, 10:30am - 11:30am. Room 1

In this workshop, participants will learn how to protect their assets from frauds and scams targeted towards seniors. With a guest speaker from the Toronto Police Services Frauds and Scams Unit, seniors will learn how to identify scams and how to protect themselves from becoming a victim. In addition, our guest speaker will provide participants with next steps should they become a victim of fraudulent activity.

Upcoming Program Dates (Room 1):

Session 3: Elder Abuse - Friday, September 20, 2024 - Room 101
Session 4: Mental Health and Cognition - Friday, October 25, 2024
Session 5: Physical Health and Exercise - Tuesday, November 19, 2024
Session 6: Aging in Place and Other Options - Tuesday, December 17, 2024

Registration is encouraged via Eventbrite. Drop-ins are welcome. For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

title: National Film Board of Canada Screening: "Voices Across the Water"
library: Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre
description:
Join us as we continuing our NFB Documentary Screening Series with our final film, "Voices Across the Water."
There is a moment during the construction of a canoe when its true form is revealed. A hull drops into place. The elegant arc of a bow cuts forth. A similar process sometimes occurs in life, when a person finally discovers their true path.
The feature documentary "Voices Across the Water" follows two master boat builders as they practice their art and find a way back to balance and healing.

Drop in. No registration required.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

title: Quilting Club
description:
Our Quilting Club meets in-person Tuesdays from 6:30-8:00 p.m. Our primary goal is to make quilts for donation to children being treated at local hospitals. We typically complete and donate about 50 quilts each year, including both individual and group projects. All supplies are donated to the group.

During meetings we work on hand-sewing quilts while sharing donated fabrics, ideas and encouragement. Beginners are welcome. We are happy to help and advise, but please note we are not resourced to provide formal instruction or lessons.

There are no sewing machines at the library. Any sewing we do at our meetings is done by hand, such as piecing quilt tops, adding bindings etc. Outside meeting times, participants are encouraged to continue with their quilting contribution using a sewing machine if they have access to one.

Our schedule follows the TDSB calendar, that is no meetings will take place when school is out, e.g., holidays, winter break, summer (July and August) and the December break.

If you identify as a person with a disability and require an accessibility accommodation to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.

description: Join us for stimulating conversation about great books. You and your fellow book club members decide in advance which books you want to read. New members are always welcome. Please call 416-395-5710 for futher details.

description:

title: Knitting Circle
description:

title: Culture and Technology Book Club
description:
Friday, August 16, 2024
7:00pm - 8:00pm

The Culture and Technology Book club brings readers together once a month to discuss new and classic texts that raise important questions about the way technology transforms our cultural and political lives.

This Month we read: Household Technology and the Social Construction of Housework (1984) by Bose, Bareano and Malloy
[accessible here while on TPL wifi]

Has technology made our home lives easier? In an attempt to answer this complex question, Bose, Bareano, and Malloy argue against the myth of the labour-saving appliance and instead present a more complex picture of how domestic tasks have shaped and been shaped by technologies, and in particular how this dynamic has impacted women.

Registration is encouraged. Drop-ins welcome. Book your ticket through Eventbrite.

For more information, contact the 4th floor Business, Science & Technology desk at 416-395-5613.

Comments, bonus reading suggestions, or want to sign up for The Culture and Technology mailing list? Send an email to naomidavies@tpl.ca. Reading chapters of some of the readings will be sent out to members ahead of time. Reach out to us if youd like a copy and havent received one.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in these programs. Please let us know as far in advance as possible, and we will do our best to meet your request. At least three weeks' notice is preferred. Phone 416-393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca.
